author: Novinka
review: Tons of bugs and glitches but the game is good.

author: Luigi0pl
review: I can't recommend this game with clear conscience. Game aspire to be AAA, yet gameplay-wise is at the best good and is riddled with bugs (cars behaving like submarines - sinking in texture, cars learning how to breakdance - after small collision with lamp post, cars attempting to perform fusion technic from Dragon Ball - and failing with a lot of fireworks after gentle nudge). While on another hand the story and quests are quite fun really interesting and captiving.

author: Ennovative
review: The BIGGEST problem with Cyberpunk 2077 is that it is popular to hate Cyberpunk 2077. Most of the complaints are unwarranted, needlessly pumped up, and misrepresented. What a lot of people show you on Youtube is NOT representative of what playing this game is like. What they will not tell you is that they will be recording hours and hours of game-play and stitch together every instance where they encountered (or forced) a bug or glitch to make the game seem like its just riddled with those instances.Cyberpunk 2077 while not perfect by any means doesn't have to be. Bugs are not as common as you would expect given the reputation of this game. The game still does require monster hardware to play with Ray Tracing. You will need at least a 2080 ti to enjoy the ray-tracing on good quality -- A RTX 3080+ would be ideal. The world built here alone is VERY impressive. I do believe this was the most ambitious game to ever have been released within the last 5 years. If you listen to popular opinion and nit-pick every little thing that you see you are not going to have a good time. Instead I challenge you to appreciate everything that went into making this world live. Everything from the beautiful architecture and design of the buildings you explore to the "lived in" feel of the world is absolutley amazing. The cars that are in-game are also very original and imaginative This is a very fun game and well worth what you're paying for.

author: Nightserg
review: There's so much to write about and so little space in regards to Cyberpunk 2077 but I'll try to be brief. A huge warning to future buyers, the way the game was marketed was a complete lie. Cyberpunk 2077 is not an RPG at least not in the pure sense, it's an action/adventure game with rpg mechanics with a huge focus on linear storytelling rather than "making your own destiny in Night City" as CPDR claimed it will be up until the release date. That being said I won't downvote the game based on what should've been but what it is and as such, the gist is, Cyberpunk is a wonderful game, an amazing work of art when it comes to story and atmosphere, a world that will be hard to surpass but a flawed and janky experience ruined by technical issues.👍 +The best open-world atmosphere to date.+The story, especially the ones in the side quests are really impressive, emotional even.+Incredible voice acting especially from male V. +The quick hacking gameplay mechanics, aka the "mage" of cyberpunk were fun.👎-Huge amount of bugs, technical issues, and incomplete/"they didn't bother" missing mechanics.-Choices in the main story, besides one particular quest and the ending, don't matter at all.-Lifepaths are pointless.I'll be blunt, Cyberpunk 2077 is not a "make your own" kind of story at all and besides one particular quest at the beginning and the ending, nothing you do or choose will have any major impact. All the dialogue choices do is either allow you to access a story side quest or they change the next line of dialogue from the characters you talk to. Lifepaths that CDPR lauded are nothing but 20 minutes intros and have no impact at all. They did not even bother finishing the lifepath quest in the main game, for example, I played as a Corpo and the path starts quite nicely as you're thrown into a betrayal type of quest with powerful characters and intrigue and it just ends. You never hear about it until later in the game in the form of a 5-minute side quest. At the end of the day you should never trust a corpo, and that includes CDPR. Leaving the lies and bullsh#t out of the way, the linear main story and especially most of the side stories are top quality, good ol' CDPR stuff. The main story has its up and downs and even if you know what happens to one particular character because pretty much everyone saw the cinematic trailer years ago, it still felt incredibly emotional and it does not stop with him. Keanu aka Johnny has a cringe acting everyone knows this but you still love the guy. He has an incredible charm in his voice and it shows quite well in the game. I honestly felt like an as*hole for choosing negative responses to him. You will laugh and you will feel sad and many other emotions when it comes to how Johnnys' story is told but it does not stop there. The side quests, the romance ones are honestly among the best stuff I've seen. They're full of charm and emotions and the atmosphere of it all is incredible. I wish I could write more about the whole stories how random and stupid some are and how well written others are but I have limited space. Suffice to say, disregarding the lies, Cyberpunk 2077 comes with an incredible story and you won't be disappointed. Story rating: 9/10So CDPR lied about the stuff regarding the story but you may be wondering what about the gameplay mechanics? Well, it's a mixed bag, to say the least, but overall it's enjoyable. If I were to describe it perfectly it would be a great eurojank. You have a leveling system where you can spend these points in 5 main "paths" and each major path has a sub-path. These 5 main attributes are Body, Intelligence, Reflexes, the Technical path, and Cool and each governs your playstyle. The leveling up is simple, if you use quickhacks you gain xp in the quickhack path, if you take down enemies in stealth you gain xp in that respective path, and so on. Each of these attributes or paths or whatever you want to call them have their own skill-tree where you can upgrade V as you please. As with any skill-tree, there will be a lot of useless stuff, especially in the melee/brawling ones at least in my opinion.I tried to play as a Deus-Ex kind of guy, specialized in quickhacks and stealth with non-lethal upgrades. Stealth takedowns are bad, they just did not bother fixing and animating them properly at all besides the fact that the AI is a joke and random as hell but playing as a stealth "mage" never got boring.There are a lot of things to craft and upgrade and the weapon variety is quite decent as well as the fact that some of the weapons you can use are cool as hell but the armors you wear are below average and ugly as hell.  It's insane when you look at the other characters how well designed their outfits are and then you look at yourself in the inventory menu and you look like a fing clown. For people looking for stuff to do in the game besides the gigs, side quests, and main story you'll be disappointed. There are no fun activities to do or minigames. It took me 80 hours to complete the game and I did all the side quests I could find as well as some gigs to level up my character and I never felt bored which is quite an incredible achievement.Gameplay rating: 8.5/10As I mentioned above it took me 80 hours to finish the game and not once have I heard a bad voice acting in the game. Everyone does an incredible job voicing their character and I do have to give a special shoutout to male V for having so many dialogue choices and every single one being incredibly well-acted and his moments with Johnny and Panam were one of the best in gaming.The music in the game is quite nice as well, fits well with the atmosphere and I really loved some songs in certain special moments, not to mention certain radio songs will just force you to keep driving with the Night City in the background. Great stuff and it adds so much to the already incredible visual atmosphere of the city. Audio rating: 9.5/10Going to start with the bad, and that is the technical issues. Yes, the game is a fing mess, there are so many bugs that it would take me hours to list them all and they all range from UI getting stuck on the screen to dialogues not triggering and I think I've reloaded the game a thousand times to say the least. There are so many jarring issues with it that I was baffled how they did not bother fixing it. What the hell have they been doing all these years?The game can be incredibly taxing on performance but this is not entirely a bad thing. It's a demanding game for good reason. The world, Night City, is incredible. It's the best open world to date and it has a huge amount of details and you'll be shocked at how many places you can enter. People were disappointed that you could not enter every building in sight which is not fair considering this is a game that had to be released on last-gen consoles. It was just not possible unless they created loading spots.It's clear as night and day that the team that designed the map are on a higher skill than everyone else on the development team and it saddens me to see such an incredible world filled with bugs and dumb AI roaming the streets but I won't downvote the designers for stuff that will get fixed.Graphics, performance and tech analysis score:  9/10Take away the lies, the bugs, the incomplete features, and Cyberpunk as you can see by its score, is an incredible experience, probably one of the best but it could've been much more, something that would remain in history. Alas, the team behind it, just like all corpos, got greedy, overambitious and management ruined it.

author: jeffv0id
review: The bugs don't really bother me much. great performance and eye-candy visuals with RTX on but then again i got a high end setup. what REALLY bothers me is that this game has the dumbest AI i've seen in a videogame in the last decade. I don't feel like writing a freaking wall of text to say the pros and cons about this game, all i ant to say is that this game is a major flop and does not deserve the AAA rating. The world is lifeless even in a clogged NPC area. 80% of the side missions and activities are dumb and pointless aside from giving you money and stats. Well... idc what people say, Witcher 3 is my favourite game of all times, but this... this is just a overpriced sh1tshow. I'll come back in 1 year if they make a complete overhaul of the game and the AI.

author: decizion
review: It's exactly what i expected it to be.CD PROJEKT RED once again deliver a masterpiece.DOOM Eternal is my personal GOTY, Cyberpunk 2077 comes easily in second place.Unlike many others who probably expected too much i'm not disappointed at all.I'd say don't listen to the plebs who are downvoting the game, they are probably trying to play on their ♥♥♥♥♥♥ potatoes pc.Not surprising the game may runs like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on such garbage pc's.

author: Ryles
review: This game is all hype and no substance. - The marketing talked about being whomever you wanted to be, but you're locked into playing an edgelord.- Hacking is tedious and boring. Watch Dogs had this mechanic figured out years ago.- Stealth is tedious and boring. Deus Ex: Human Revolution and many other games had this mechanic figured out years ago. It's the same "hold crouch to be sneaky" as in every other game ever, except it's clunky as hell because the other things you want to do while you're crouched make it difficult to stay crouched, thus risking unwarranted detection.- Shooting is tedious and boring. Pick the gun with the highest DPS because nothing else matters. Aim at a head, hold down left mouse until the target's health bar disappears. The guns aren't interesting.- Melee combat is tedious and boring. Light attacks work unless the enemy is blocking, then you use a heavy attack to break the block. Counter by blocking just before you get hit. - All of the dialogue options within the refund period are a railroad with the illusion of giving you choice because it takes way too long to get started, concerned with trying to get you invested in a revenge story instead of selling to you why you should care about it.I haven't even mentioned all the glitches. It plays uncomfortably like an un-patched Bethesda game in terms of its performance and stupid things happening. You can tell me they're gonna fix it all you want but fixing the bugs isn't going to fix the fact that it's a mediocre game and absolutely not worth the hype.

author: Sarrow
review: To preface this review; I was a fan of CDPR's games since Witcher 1 days.  I followed cyberpunk's development for 3-4 years, pre-ordered the game, and was very excited to play it for the first time. Additionally, I played since the beginning on a 5800X + RTX 3090, and never had any performance problems.While I did encounter a number of glitches, bugs, and various problems during my primary play through they never really turned me off to the game as a whole. What really  killed the game for me was the realization that it is entirely dead, empty, and unfinished. Retrospectively, the entire experience has convinced me think that CDPR lacked the necessary experience to pull off a game of this scope, and deluded themselves into thinking it was possible based on their prior successes.What detracts most from the game is its entirely un-finished and inconsistent narrative, the promises of an interactive world that were never realized, and the extremely weak gameplay mechanics; all of which are, for all intent and purpose, impossible to fix. CDPR built a world that was too large for their ability to manage, they wrote a story that is rampantly inconsistent and implemented within an engine that doesn't support much in the way of dynamic story telling, and they implemented a rudimentary gameplay system that resolves around static spawns, extremely limited AI, and damage + skill scaling mechanics straight out of Diablo.I will say that I did, somewhat, enjoy my first playthrough when I did buy into the illusion of choice with respect to origin, quests, and overall outcome; but once you realize that you have no real effect on the world, the story, or anything else, it just seems disappointing. I can easily say that I would hesitate to purchase a CDPR title in the future, and would never pre-order from their company again.

author: Joseph Saintlin
review: Wake the F[_]ck up samurai we have great story to see

author: Vacuu
review: There's no better way to put it, a mile wide and an inch deep.

author: CDMC
review: It's been over a year and even after 1.5 patch the game has tons of bugs. Some can even soft lock the game were you need to reload your previous save or use cheats to fix it without losing your progress. When bugs happen so often that you don't know if its a bug or that's by design. It's just sad. I wanted to like this game, i really did, but this is just bad.Simple things like for example mouse cursor on in game PC's disappear and you have to navigate it blindly.After reloading a gun it starts shooting automatically for no reason.Audio problems, one person talks loud as hell, the other is silent, or there is no voice audio at all.Simple stuff like reflections, police cars rear lights sometimes become brighter than the sun to the point where you have to turn on first person camera while driving cause you can't see anything.Radio in cars doesn't change or start playing properly, there were times where i have to stop the car, get out, get back in, then the radio station changes.When you need to use a MOD to fix multi-core performance issues so it uses all the cores and actually boosts your FPS you know the game has serious issues.The fact that the bug that was on launch in 2020 still exist in 1.5 where when you're driving normally you suddenly get yeeted in to space for no reason is mind boggling.I can go on and on about bugs in this game, there are plenty, in the end, is the game worth it?Not really, don't waste your money unless you really, really want it and its on a sale 50+% off.Is it playable? Yes, but its not acceptable giving its been over a year and the game feels like its in Early Access. It's just sad.I played it when it originally launched and passed it in 2 sittings i was so exited(haven't touched it sense), now bought it on steam(to keep my games on one platform) after 1.5 was released hoping its better, but it kinda was a waste of money.Gonna finish my second playthrough and most likely never touch this game again, maybe in 2077.I really hope in the future i get to change this review in to a positive one, but for now;Not Recommended.

author: Kodijack!
review: (Reviewed un-modded version 1.31, absolutely no prior impression, no pre-order, ignored the hype-train and following disaster. I'm just a gamer who loves games!)HELL YES! I waited until now to give it a go and had set my expectations EXTREMELY low. I went in as an unspoiled virgin :-)Alas I have been more than positively surprised and enjoyed the ride tremendously.I won't comment on CDPRs screw-up and will just focus on the thing we have here right now. It's one of the very very rare dystopian SciFi (RP-)games, which despite being located in the USA is totally NOT US-centric, hasan incredibly majestic atmosphere, awe-inspiring world-building, sublime story-telling, and deep characters to care for.It's by far not perfect and has many flaws, but we're not drowning in choices and the overall experience is still superb nonetheless.Fair trigger-warning for those whom it may concern:The game does cover topics like Snuff, human trafficking, abuse, suicide, depression, PTSD, MPD, addiction and such. Sometimes blatantly in your face, sometimes very subtle.(My actual gameplay was way better due to a lot of mods)

author: TTV: Scratchproof
review: - Nice atmosphere and graphics but gameplay is seriously outdated. - Choices do not matter. You do not even have choices to be honest, conversations are just "answer A" and "answer B" and whichever you pick makes no difference. - Interactions feel clunky, looting is an absolute unresponsive nightmare. - Night City is gorgeous and the atmosphere is amazing but fails to feel genuine. It only seems to serve as a background to the main story.- NPCs act strange and their reactions are not realistic. Every NPC you try to interact with somehow seems to be offended for no reason. You may walk by them and they'll great you in a nice way, but as soon as you press "F" to interact, they'll be treating you like you slapped their mother in the back of a dark alley. Sometimes just walking by someone is enough for them to come at you.- NPCs walk aimlessly in the city with no purpose, bumping into each other and into you.- Bugs here, bugs there, bugs everywhere. Random objects floating. You're having a convo with an NPC and chopsticks are just floating in front of you. You park your car and when you come back to the area not only has it moved but also it's levitating 50cm above the ground. People just randomly flying across the screen as light speed (sure makes for a good laugh) amongst others.- Enemies are bullet sponges and combat is not very fun. Some handguns allow you to zoom and aim but then you cannot shoot???- Enemy AI is really bad regardless of the difficulty chosen.- Stealth is absolute crap and serves no purpose at all.- Interface is clunky and hard to navigate.- Way too many unnecessary items or pieces of clothing that serve no purpose whatsoever other than filling your inventory.- Story is confusing and most of the time you don't know who is who or why you are doing something.- Game feels like a million ideas from other games were crammed in there but none of them were properly implemented. - Character creator is quite awesome I have to admit.- Really like the graphics and the atmosphere and the art style.

author: R3alTime ♥
review: ✔️ Cyberpunk 2077 by CD Projekt Red  ✔️ | Pre Patch 1.5 |I've put a considerable amount of time into CD Projekt's  CyberPunk 2077 and managed to 100% the game on steam. This means countless hours poured into grinding for "Steam Based" achievements and completing everything and anything that the game had to offer. Now that I'm done with this, decided to put a very thorough review of the game and my experience for anyone that is interested in playing the game in the future, or wants to achieve 100% completion on steam. The review is spoiler free 🚫 and is for people that will and has played the game 😎Lets start-off with the General ratings.➊) Gameplay - 8.0 / 10 ( Still feels a tad bit unoptimized )➋) Combat - 8.5 / 10 (Melee combat & weaponized combat was pretty decent, but lacks more animation layouts for melee weapons such as Katana and batons)➌) Grpahics - 9.5 / 10  ( Ran the game on medium to high and averaged around 35 - 40 FPS & and it looks pretty decent, now imagine the game on' Psycho' settings along with RTX and DLSS turned on, that's bound to be a real treat to your eyes.➍) Story - 6.0 / 10 (The main story line felt Mediocore and very little was offered.➎) Questing - 6.5 / 10 ( Side questing felt a bit rushed and gave no unique alternative, it was always kill or save kind of quests.➏) Story-boarding - 5.5 / 10 ( When compared to its predecessor "Witcher 3" CyberPunk 2077 could not fully deliver in terms of connecting character arcs and making choices and emotional decisions made throughout the game have any significant impact towards the overall RPG quality nor the endings of the game.➐) NPC - 6.5 / 10 (NPC & Quality of life in Night City and in the badlands felt somewhat dull and most NPC's offered the same set of dialogue throughout the whole game.➑) Character Development - 7.0 / 10 (Throught the entire play-through of the game a medium level of character development was shown towards V and the rest of the side characters. Anyone playing the game would feel as if most characters have an emotional range of a celery stick 😒 and that everyone moves on or forgets in game incidents real quick.➒) Steam Achievements - 3.0 / 10 TERRIBLE ( Anyone trying to achieve 100% completion on whatever platform but specifically steam, you would have to sacrifice a lot of carefree and experimentative gameplay for that to happen. Mainly involves going back & forth on manual saves for god knows how many times ! 😡)➓) Customization - 4.5 / 10 ( From the get go, the game has limited customization of only a very few items, which then denies the player of a full immersive and role playing experience.)    |   FINAL THOUGHTS   |All in all this game did have its Ups and Downs, but I did somewhat enjoy my time playing this game.I can't help but feel bad for the review of this game by most players on the 1st year of launch, but I do feel that the expectations of Fans where aimed to that of Witcher 3 by CDBR, which is setting the bar really high! 😅😅😅. . . . . ╰──╮  A handy tip to anyone that wants more out of the game and to have a upper hand on it's set limitations, I highly recommend running the game through various MODS through Nexus Mods. Makes the gameplay and initial play through of the game a lot more enjoyable and offers up a lot more options in the game.  ╭──╯ . . . . .Lastly, I am still pleased with what CD Projekt has managed to put out and I sincerely do hope that in the years to come they start listening to the fans and audience more. Who knows, they still could revitalize ✔️   I Shall end this review by giving Cyber Punk 2077 a solid ►   6.0 / 10   ◄   ✔️                                       ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

author: Marsala
review: Good story, great npc's But the problem It's not the bugs, its the lack of content.The city is beautiful, but has nothing to do in it.My comments: Are there a lot of side quests and G.I.G.? SureAre they repetitive? Yes, lot of them.What I was saying in my review is about the city, the world of Cyberpunk 2077.The world is not functional, it is dead.There are a lack of mechanics in this game.The A.I. is bad.There is nothing to explore in the worldLocked doors, blocked buildingsYou can't even buy a street food.If Steam allowed to rate the game: 6/10The game is not bad. But the game is terrible considering what was promised and also the greatness of the game, its hype and the company itself. The game is not worth that price in its current state.

author: Azura
review: Crashes in menus, lighting glitches, shadows flickering, movement bugs. I can usually push through some bugs (my favorite game ever is Morrowind) but this is pretty rough. Don't play it yet.... Played on "MEDIUM - No ray tracing" setting @ 1080p on an RTX 2070. I figured lower settings would help with the bugs I've seen in reviews. It did not.

author: NoraNorz
review: I feel like even with the updates and quality of life improvements, this game feels lacking in many ways.While the game looks really good and has great presentation, the world beyond that feels pretty shallow, yes it looks very pretty and believable, but thats it, there is very little interaction with many elements of the world (not even a cab system, or trains). I also think at a certain moment gameplay starts to feel stale. I played with many builds, one example is a melee build. It was cool at first, but it got very samey quickly, When I did get mantis blades that changed it up a bit, but it didn't progress much after that besides other cyberware. Most perks tend to just add bonuses to different stats in combat aswell. One aspect where this game shines however are the characters especially in the main story, but these stories tend to play out quite linearly, which means the player doesn't have much agency (accept for the first act). The lifepaths don't influence much besides the beginning mission and a few extra dialog options. Compare this to clans vampire the masquerade bloodlines, or backstory options in mass effect, these can open up whole new quests and player homes (in bloodlines) and at least give more in game dialogue relating and expanding on these backgrounds (such as mass effect). Ultimately, I feel this game fails at being a good rpg (because of its lack of choice), fails at being a good shooter (gunplay feels good, but gets samey quick), fails at being a good open world game (because other than looking pretty, you don't actually interact much with the city in a way that feels truly immersive besides really surface level stuff). I really wanted to like this game, but I just can't. So many other games in these genres do it better (deus ex, VTMB, etc). I just wish there was a game that has the stunning visuals and general presentation and atmosphere that 2077 delivers, but with more actual substance.

review: Loaded in, discovered you could customise your penis, tits or vagina, looked into a mirror, saw lots of bugging floating trees in the middle of my screen, talked to a man about a women, boarded a flying car and drank only the best champagne, saw moreeeeeee floating bugging trees.... GOTTA LOVE THEM TREES IN THE MIDDLE OF MY SCREEN! and smashed a kids face in with a basketball. WHAT MORE DO YOU NEED!10/10 Would wait 8 years again :)ps, PLEASE FIX THE DAMN VISUAL BUG WITH THEM FLOATING TREES XD

author: Merrily lynchin'
review: My advise: Wait! Just wait. I know it's hard and probably nobody will do that. I didn't and I regret it.I guess the public (read: all of us) forced them to rush this game in the end. But in its current form I cannot recommend playing. Ever played a Bethesda game (I love them almost all) upon release? Well, this is worse...The bugs and unfinished mechanisms for me ruin the experience of what could otherwise - and I am sure at some point will - be a great game and might potentially be a next milestone, even though I am not sure about how revolutionary it is yet. It could also be just a very elaborate and lovingly crafted copy-mix of GTA, Deus Ex and Fallout / Elder Scrolls set in a Cyberpunk world. And given that these are some of the greatest franchises ever and Cyberpunk is an awesome setting, this alone would justify sinking a few hundreds hours of gameplay into it happily.But so far...Bugs I experienced in the intro, tutorial and very first mission (maybe 3-4 hours of slow net gameplay):- Game plain crashed for the first time after 5 minutes in when I tried to change my mouse sensitivity - Constant clipping of NPCs through stuff, even in very early scripted scenes (e.g. the nightclub).- Frequently too late rendering of stuff. This ranges from blurry blocks driving around instead of cars (at least for the first 2-3 seconds you look at them sometimes) to complete characters not being displayed at all, except for the drink they are holding, or you only realize they are there, because another NPC stumbles around themBugs can hopefully be fixed fast. What's potentially worse and more time consuming to patch is the lack of honed out gameplay mechanics:- The main story seems completely on rails so far. Absolutely 0 choice - even in situations where it is by now common in almost all games. This comes pretty unexpected- E.g. dialogue options so far (3-4 hours in): EVERY dialogue I had so far had options but I ALWAYS had to choose the one option that the story wanted to progress as plannend (the first one listed), everything else was just chitchat without effect (or any valuable info added).- Despite being on rails, the main storyline for me already lost track / jumped right after the first mission. Not to spoiler anything (I don't know what's going on so I really can't): I am suddenly supposed to go talk to someone to  for a specific job from a specific person that my character talks about having gotten, but none of that ever happened. This is in the - I think - first mission of the first act already. - A living city like this requires A LOT of of mechanisms to work, mainly in how the NPCs and city respond to your actions. Here it shows strongly that they didnt have Rockstars multi-decade experience with this on deck.- E.g. touch a random police tape anywhere lightly with your hip? Immediately get shot without warning (well they do warn you while they already shoot) by dozens of cops and chase you until death.- Or: You come across an ongoing firefight between police and a gang. The game tells you, you can intervene in such situations of leave it. You shoot the whole gang dead. Nothing happens. The scene just switches to 1 police standing around and telling you to bugger off. Around the corner are some of the same gang just hanging out. They wont react to or even talk to you. See below. - You can talk to most NPCs standing around. Not all, which is weird because you don't see where the difference comes from. But expect 90% of them to not move their lips while talking... Why?- Also, the only bystanders/NPCs you can NOT talk to are cops, bouncers, gang members, etc. Meaning everyone that would potentially have anything meaningful to interact on with (all displayed with a yellow sign above their heads). Guess this can only be a bug, but it is pretty annoying.All in all, this currently ruins immersion and I cannot really get into the game, which is a shame. I hope they will be able to fix/finalize this great looking game over the next half year or so, so we can all enjoy it, as it surely deserves.To end on a positive note: The game looks pretty stunning (as we all have seen before) and you can see the enormous amounts of detail work that went into crafting all the scenery especially. Very well done. Can't say I am a big fan of the whole "washed out" and blurry look, but I think that can be edited in the settings.

author: Inawayliving
review: Good things:» Fun game.» Lot's of action.» Combat Is Fun.» Night City.» Great voice acting and characters.» I enjoyed the story and side quests.Disadvantages:» Sometimes feels empty.» Lot's of bugs.Overall it's a good game but if you aren't patient with bugs then please save your money until it's patched.

author: Trippy
review: Despite the reputation this game has for bugs. After 1.5 this game is solid, it will never live up to what the general audience had expectations of what this game would be, but it makes sense why fans would hype this game up so much. After The Witcher 3 gained popularity and was widely known as one of the best open world games out there, its expected that Cyberpunk 2077 would do the same but fell extremely short. Pushing that to the side, Cyberpunk 2077 has graphically one of the most breathtaking experiences ever. Even on the lowest settings this game looks phenomenal. A major issue I have is the gameplay, guns feel extremely clunky in my opinion and a melee build is always 10x more fun. The story also feels pretty rushed overall, but its a bit too late to make major changes at this point. Honestly the side quests and side characters make Cyberpunk what Cyberpunk is today. I would honestly say that the side quests combined are significantly better than the main quest.uhhhhh 7/10 very cool

author: Solaire Bro
review: Cyberpunk 2077 is a game of grandiose ideals (that came with grandiose marketing), to the extent that it can be a chore parsing out the game’s fluff from its actual content. The ad campaign that surrounded the project was so invasive and ubiquitous that even after almost 60 hours of playtime, I’m still not fully equipped to separate what the game is from what it was intended (or advertised) to be. That’s not wholly CD Project Red’s fault, either. I ultimately bear some responsibility for creating something in my mind that no developer has ever fully realized. Part of that has to do with the high esteem that I hold for their previous projects, specifically The Witcher 3. So it’s not completely fair to CD Project Red’s creative. And yet, it was also  marketing that constructed the hype train I was riding. Regardless of how we got here, the sheer amount of dissonance from what I thought I would play (partly my fault) from what the game actually became (mostly their fault) creates a tricky ruleset for reviewing. Aside from the game figuratively crashing headlong into the hurdle of my expectations, the game is still sometimes fun. It’s a usually charming, occasionally dull, always buggy, relatively beautiful mess of a game. The exhausting vacillation between positive attributes and negative characteristics makes for a rather arduous game of mental tennis. Few parts of the game come without greatness. Likewise, no part comes without lethargy. The incongruity between the positive and negative makes a reviewer somewhat hesitant to state the game is good. Or bad. Or fair. But I will. With a lump in my throat say…The game is ok. And when it was over, I was ready to move on. There’s an RPG problem that exists. And it’s pervasive in two ways.Firstly, the character you control, V, is already a paint-by-numbers character for whom the player will fill in the canvas. I’ve seen this criticized in a general sense and I’m not completely on board. Thousands of RPGs like this have already existed without complaint. Geralt, from The Witcher, works in similar fashion. You never take the reins of characterization completely. This is no different (aside from a book series’ and three video games’ worth of establishment) from what came before, other than it seemingly contrasting from what was advertised. But make no mistake. V is already a person, and people have problems, goals, and aspirations. You will not decide these for her (or in my case, him). Occasionally, though, there are general inconsistencies with V. It seems weird, for instance, that a streetkid would work with police officers and politicians, yet he does if you allow him to. So should I simply not allow it? Or is it a mistake for the developers to have allowed it? The onus is ambiguous. The answer, unfortunately, appears to be of no consequence. V can or can’t: you decide. Any streetkid code in your head is just that — in your head. Which makes the roleplaying feel superfluous.Secondly, the main quest of Cyberpunk 2077 is time-sensitive (not actually, but story-wise). This is an enormous issue. It creates a story template that conflicts with the player’s desire to explore. If the main quest has a deadline, and that deadline not being met results in something terrible happening, why in the world would V (if this were real) bother doing anything else that CD Project Red went through the trouble of creating? The answer is that V would not. Because it doesn’t make sense.How can Cyberpunk 2077 justify that anyone with even a slight measure of intelligence (particularly its protagonist) would go through the trouble of falling in love, racing cars, beating up nobodys, having sex, eating, drinking, or shopping, if they had this totally separate issue that renders all of these earthly pleasures utterly meaningless? The main story breaks the world.  The player simply cannot, based on the game's own story, rationalize doing anything other than the main quest. And that main quest isn’t that long. Especially in comparison to the amount of side content. And because the plot moves so quickly, and V so slowly, a disconnect forms, and the plot can’t sustain itself. You see, it’s possible that V (the player) will be just too busy messing with hookers, or dirt biking in the desert, or getting drunk in a bar to adhere to the all-important details of the quest Cyberpunk 2077 says is the  important. It’s easy to out-roleplay the narrative because any main plot, particularly one that is time-sensitive, simply dissolves in an open world like this. Basically, why give the player tons to do, then by the nature of the plot, tell them there’s no time to do any of it? Because, as stated, if this were real — they surely wouldn’t.  V looks like an idiot for having fun. Despite the lack of sense it makes for a character who should be doing anything but, there are lots of fun things to do in Night City. I was regularly captivated by the vistas, the populace, the pulsing radio, and the night jaunts through the city’s underbelly. While not being revolutionary (I felt this much and more in the fantasy realms within The Witcher 3), it still achieved a high level of verisimilitude for the city proper. There’s something to Night City, even if it was less than advertised. Many of my favorite moments of the game were the straightaways, with my figurative foot on the gas, speeding into oblivion. It was in these moments when Night City felt alive…For a few seconds, at least, until I would suddenly glitch outside my car and be suspended in the air just above it, surfing on the hood.Bugs and glitches are prevalent. I casually surfed on top of my car often. You will see anomalies like this everywhere. And the real tragedy with these regular irregularities (other than their predictability) is that they ruin moments that would otherwise work exceptionally well. Imagine a sensitive moment between two lovers or friends — or a glorious shootout where V, against all odds, blasts his way through a legion of adversaries, only to be met with invisible goons, random floating objects, or decapitated people (who are still very much alive). Despite its potential for danger, bugs colored the whole of Night City in something goofy and unintimidating. It’s a circus clownhouse. Night City is supposed to be as much of a character as V is. And either by content, or unintentional moments of moto-surfing complete with floating inanimate objects (or people), that goal is never fully realized. And that is the biggest shame of Cyberpunk 2077. Cyberpunk 2077 does not feel especially innovative (or finished), which is shocking considering its marketing. Truthfully, it just kind of exists. Another contemporary. Neither truly offending nor pleasing. Owning nothing it really excels at, or really even anything it’s particularly poor at (save quality control).It’s a pretty, glitchy RPG/Shooter that exists in an open world. It grants the player the freedom of exploration and the freedom to level up via a skill tree. You’ll meet some interesting characters, do some interesting things, and in the end, spend 50+ hours completing it all.Sound familiar? It should. You’ve been playing it for years.

author: ¤ βℓооđч ¤ Nico-Kun!
review: Cyberpunk 2077... There's a lot to unpack here, so this will be a lenghty review. The game that was gonna revolutionize gaming as a whole, offering an unique experience we'd never seen before, hand-crafted by the masterminds at CDPR... And then, when it released, it was a bug-filled mess, practically unplayable on last gen consoles, and practically destroyed CDPR's reputation overnight. Still, after more than half a year since it's release, and having finally finished it, I guess it's time to share my thoughts on it.So, where do I start? The setting. Cyberpunk 2077, as its name implies is set not only in a cyberpunk world, but rather, THE Cyberpunk world, as in, the universe first explored by the table-top RPG that gave the cyberpunk genre its name. And I must say, I love the setting, and the design of Night City and the surrounding Badlands. As I played the game, I couldn't help but stop at every corner, just to admire the beauty of the city, with its glowing neon lights, its tall buildings, its mix of American and Japanese architecture... I was blown away by it all. Truly, despite its flaws (which I'll talk about), CDPR managed to craft a really beautiful environment to explore, though sadly, it gets dragged down by the issues the game has.As for the story, I think this is another strong point of the game. You play as V, and at the start of the game, you pick a lifepath which determines your prologue. While I praise the story, I do consider that having the lifepaths limited to a single, relatively short prologue mission, was a huge mistake on CDPR's part, and they could've built them some more. Anyway, I digress; once you're done with the prologue, you start the story proper, with V living in Night City, being best friends with Jackie, and getting ready for the heist of a lifetime... Of course, things go wrong, and Johnny Silverhand's engram ends up in V's mind, trying to take over his body. I won't go into further detail, but I gotta say, it was a pretty engaging story, especially if you're like me, and do everything the game has to offer.As a counterpoint to the previous paragraph, though, the story pacing has some issues. One of the main complaints I've read online was about how the main story was really short, and the ending, unsatisfying, and, in my opinion, those are valid points to an extent. If you focus on the missions the game marks as "main story", you'll actually miss out on some options by the end. Certain story-related side quests get lumped together with the rest of side jobs and gigs, and so, you might end up unaware of them.As for gameplay elements, it's basically an FPS with RPG elements, with Attributes and Skill points, and also perk trees. These can obviously influence your playstyle; certain attributes can help you open new paths, while skills relate to the abilities you use in combat or out of it. To make a clearer example, the Strenght attribute might allow you to force open certain doors, meanwhile, the handguns skill determines how much damage you do with pistols. Still, skill levels are capped by their related attribute, so you might want to take that into consideration. Being an RPG (or at least sort of), there's also equipment, clothing items, weapons with different stats. There's a pretty large selection, and you can even craft newer weapons and mods to install them. Also, given the cyberpunk setting, cybernetic enhancements are a given, with some really interesting options, like invisible camo, or my personal favourite, the Mantis Blades.I talked about the setting, but let's focus a bit more on design. The graphics are pretty great in this game, as I mentioned in the paragraph about the setting, the city looks beautiful, but again, the impact gets diminished when the game's shortcomings start popping up. While the streets are crowded with pedestrians and cars, if you pay attention, you'll soon notice their rather limited AI. Personally, this wasn't as much of an issue to me, as I usually consider NPCs as background dressing, and don't pay much attention to them, but I know it might break immersion for some. The sound design is very good as well, the many noises from the city make it sound alive, and the soundtrack is excellent.Now, for the shortcomings, because this game has a lot of them, and I already mentioned a few things here and there. When it first released, it was plagued by bugs (and still is, to some extent); I actually stopped playing for several months before coming back to it recently. On PC, it wasn't as serious as on last gen consoles; in my case, I was lucky enough that most of the bugs I found where of the amusing kind, though there were many instances of pop-up issues (and there still are to this day). Bugs aside, the game was also a disappointment to many due to what feels like a severe reduction in scope; the game that was delivered seems almost like a shell of the one that was promised. Although I really enjoyed the story and gameplay, by the time I was finishing it, I could still feel that there was something missing, that this game could've turned out amazing, but simply ended up being good. The story could've been fleshed out a bit more, and there's several instances, both on the main quest as in the side jobs, in which it feels like they had set things up, only not to follow up on them.Anyway, I think this review has gone on for too long. Personally, I had a great time with this game, and it's basically the main reason I got myself a decent PC last year, having gamed on laptops for the past decade. However, you should keep in mind it's a deeply flawed experience, and might never manage to live up to the expectation there were before release. Still, one can hope that CDPR can at least keep supporting the game with bug fixes and maybe some more content.

author: rayculz
review: I still remember when launch of this overhyped game got so many praise and so many backlash. It still a good game for me, despite all technical problem that happen at launch. But, I did abandoned the game and forgot it for a while. Time after time, updates after update and decided to go back to the game after Patch 1.05 and its was blow my mind. The game still good and became stable.And one thing that I did like of this game developer, they still update this game and try to accomplished what they promised. They still support this game, alongside with other media like Netflix's Cyberpunk Edgerunner anime and announce this game future DLC.Well, Cyberpunk 2077 still had good atmosphere, good soundtrack, good gameplay, good story, good lore and brilliant world building. It still the best game ever made in my humble opinion.So, I never regret to nominate Cyberpunk 2077 as Labor of Love in Steam Award 2022.

author: Scumbag Jim
review: As of right now, this game is too clunky and buggy to be enjoyable. Wait for some patches to stabilize the experience before buying.One Year on: A lot of the bugs were ironed out but the core mechanics of the game are just awful. Nothing feels good, the weapons, the hacking, the movement and basic things like reloading or using meds feels janky and unfinished. It's supposed to play like a high speed shooter/brawler but the overall clunkiness of the game makes combat unrewarding and infuriating.

author: Scyushi
review: despite some pretty bad bugs, the game is great. it's like an open world deus ex.the only thing is you gotta invest a lot of time in cyberpunk before you start to see all the crazy mods on yourself and enemies.. that's not a bad thing though, I like how slowly you progress rather than being a god at the start. I'm 7 hours in and I haven't even seen Keanu Reeves yet.*A note to RTX 3090 owners, I had terrible performance. Cyberpunk was running a very unstable 50-30fps with medium settings and performance DLSS. Maybe you won't have any issues, but if you do, install the Nvidia STUDIO drivers (instead of the game drivers) and try that. I'm now able to run max settings / maxed ray tracing at 1440p with a pretty stable 60fps on foot and only dip to 50fps when driving in 3rd person (driving in 1st person doesn't have any dip, so I guess the game struggles with rendering your vehicle.

author: Aary
review: As a person who loves the concept of cyberpunk, from the atmosphere and world, the lives that we infer they may live, to the violence as money takes hold of more and more people, I think this game brings a lot of that together. During launch day it was definitely a flop. There were many bugs; game breaking, the graphics weren't optimized, and it was very obvious that, this game was released in pressure from the community. However, as the years have passed, there have been many changes. The bugs no longer interfere with the game as heavily as they did before, the graphics have been updated, guns and items polished up, vehicles mechanics, driving, npc behaviours, and much more that you can only really feel while playing this game. Now I won't sugar coat it, it's  not what it was intended to be pre-release, but its a game thats still worth playing. Now this may be a biased review, but I will put both the pros and cons I see from this game. Pros:Atmosphere..It's beautiful. You may be thinking to yourself, is it really beautiful from what many people have said where there are headless npcs. Yes, of course, that's the best part. Jokes aside it truly is. I've ran about 80 hours into the game, and I can tell you, I don't think I can bored of the city. If you wanted to play a game, which brought the future infront of you, and made it realisitc. This is definitely it. As you drive around the city going from gig to gig, you will feel it. You feel the changes in districts, you feel the changes in atmosphere, the lives of the npcs, the buildings that surround you, even the parts that lay inside the buildings. They way you hear the news buzzing around you, telling you about the corrupt world that refuses to change. The way the npcs talk about trying to get out of their rough lives, thinking that maybe they've finally found a way out. The quite empty roads, to the gunshots in the distance, to gangs picking on innocent people; as the neon lights truly fill the street. The immersion is one that's truly taken from granted, and as you finally leave the grasps of the city, you can feel the quite hmm of the badlands, still crawling with action, and a thirst to find a way out. Storyline.. Each character you can truly feel. This game has been awarded story-rich for a reason. That's what it was made for. For you to get the feel, as a person working in corporate. Or starting out from the dumps, as you progress the story you feel every bit of the city. From the people you interact with, and people you change paths with, you grow more and more attached, wanting to spend more time, learn more, as to how did they start off; how it's so different for every character you meet, and how they got to where they are now in this buzzing city. You yourself, as you travel, fight, discover, explore, you can feel your own character grow, and your own sense of self blends into the choices you make throughout the game, and maybe how you would be in this world if you lived here. It truly is beautiful, and only something you can grasp when playing this game.Cons:Now there are always pros, and there are always cons, some games have more than others. I think cyberpunk, has its cons, its not the worlds greatest game, but it's not something that doesn't make the game not worth it. BUGS... :_)Yes yes, bugs are there, they have been there from the start. BUT NO, they aren't game breaking. CDPR has got, a lot, and I mean a lot of backlash for the buggy game they released back in 2020. However, I can say this much. Their game, is still, in my opinion, perhaps one of the greatest games ever made. They have spent, a lot, and I mean A LOT, of time fixing these bugs. From yes, the headless npcs, to you being chased by T-posing mobs, to even your car flying from a hit from, who knows what. It's been handled very well. You still encounter bugs, like for my case there have been times where the perspective was stuck in story mode while actually playing the game, which was fixed just by me going to main screen and coming back. As well as me driving really fast into yellow barricades, and them getting stuck in my car, which would send me for an inception time flying experience, which was actually a nice refresher seeing something so silly. It wouldn't stop me from playing the game, or have me miss out on something important. It still kept me going, and gave me a good laugh here and there. The bugs in this game are very subjective. If you are the type of person who's gonna bawl over a bug you found and never play the game again, thennnn... maybe you shouldn't get it, but if you aren't like that and don't mind your car flying every once in a while, and can even get a good laugh from it, this game will definitely give that you. The bugs are there, always have been, and always will be, but they don't outweigh the other aspects of the game, still making it worth your money.Storyline..?? Yes, I talked a lot about how this story line was beautiful, and it is, my only problem with it, is that it's too short. There are plenty of side gigs and fun people to meet, explore, and things to do, but the main storyline is short, and that's one thing I definitely wished was longer. CDPR is adding expansions and it's been rumoured that we will be getting more things to do while we wait for the expansion, but it's still short. Side missions can last from 5 minutes to anywhere around 30. I'm still playing the game and have more stuff to do, but the more I play the more I enjoy how well this game as been made. As for CDPR, they've done great, not what was promised, but none the less respectable. Conclusion:In my opinion, this game has improved a lot since it's release, and will continue to improve in small ways making the game more fun. As for expansion many players still wait to see what will happen with that, as well as future updates. But the current stage the game is in, it's beautiful, and worth trying. However, my only thing is that I would recommend getting it on sale. Is it worth the whole $80? Maybe not, is it worth 40 tho? 100%. And as long as you are enthusiastic about the world, the concept, of cyberpunk, you will come to love the game and what it has to offer. However, if you are playing for it to have the same level of depth as elden ring, choose elden ring. IT definitely is, something different, and something truly worth appreciating. If you decide to get this game, have fun playing. Chooms :D

author: BRUCE
review: It’s difficult to quantify just how good Cyberpunk 2077 is. It’s like trying to tell someone you’ve discovered the world’s best cheeseburger. We all know what a cheeseburger tastes like and, for the most part, they’re all fairly similar. But sometimes, a special, magical combination of ingredients comes together in a way that has to be experienced to be believed and understood. Cyberpunk 2077 is like that. It’s an open-world, first-person RPG with hacking but it’s also so much more. It’s a sublime experience from the moment it begins to the end of the (35+ minute) credits. No matter what kind of gamer you are and how you like to play, Cyberpunk 2077 caters to you.Playing as mercenary V, players are dropped into the fictional Night City and let loose. V’s personality, skills and class are all shaped and developed by the player while playing. And they’re never locked in to one specific thing. Are you a gung-ho, guns blazing, wise-cracking arsehole? Cyberpunk’s got you covered. Do you prefer to sneak up on your enemies and stay tight-lipped? You’re covered too.Do you want to tackle each and every situation, conversation, mission, combat scenario and traversal across Night City based on how you feel at any given moment? Well, that’s also an option. The freedom to play how you want and be who you want in Cyberpunk 2077 is nothing short of breathtaking and the fact it affords players this level of freedom while delivering a seamless, fluid and engaging experience is mind-blowing. Many games buckle under the weight of their own ambition, but Cyberpunk 2077 avoids this pitfall and instead, creates an experience which is never less than completely dictated by the player’s whims.In Cyberpunk 2077, CD Projekt Red has created a phenomenal tour de force and a game that’s unlikely to be matched anytime soon. It is an important game and one that demands to be played.

author: x_equals_speed
review: The publisher accidentally buried all of the "This game doesn't launch" threads in the general discussion rather than fixing the problem so I figured it'd be best to put it in a review so it's more visible.The unannounced update that made the game not launch for a large portion of the userbase with no option to rollback is something that can sometimes be worked around. I've not yet seen a solution which doesn't have at least one user reporting it doesn't work so you might be unable to play indefinitely, however these things have all worked for at least one user:1) Launching from the exe directly rather than through steam (Find it in your steam/steamapps/common/cyberpunk2077/bin/ If you can't remember where you installed steam you can also find it by right clicking on it in your library, selecting properties and then "browse" under local files)2) Find that exe, but rather than launching it, right click and select properties. Toggle "run as administrator" (I have seen both "turn it off if it's on" and "turn it on if it's off" reported as successful solutions)3) Go to your graphics card manufacturers webpage and manually download the latest drivers (Windows automatic update will tell you that you have the latest driver when you do not, check the version number against the manufacturer's latest offering)4) Verify game files (Okay, I've not actually heard anyone say this has worked for them, but always try it before doing a full reinstall. It's quick and some day it'll work!)5) Uninstall, delete all relevant files and reinstall. The files are (From a comment CrimsonRider made on another thread):Cyberpunk 2077 folder from here: ...\steamapps\common\Cyberpunk 2077Cyberpunk 2077 folder from here: %userprofile%\Saved Games\CD Projekt Red\REDEngine folder from here: %userprofile%\AppData\Local\CD Projekt Red folder from here: %userprofile%\AppData\LocalCD Projekt RED folder from here: %userprofile%\AppData\Local\ProgramsIf you're not using cloud saves you need to back up your save files or you'll lose all of your progress.If you have mods you have a more complicated time, but anyone who can install a mod should be able to figure out how to remove them properly.Unfortunately the game is 100% unplayable to some portion of the userbase, even unmodded, even trying every fix. Obviously that makes buying it a bit of a gamble, which is a shame, because it really is quite good.

review: CDPR: The hype is real! Players: RPG? Shooter? author: Namaki
review: I don't understand the hate this game gets. It is pretty good, the story isn't repetitive. On the other hand, it's pretty cool with more endings. Yea, sure, the Life Path doesn't change much but it's still a pretty cool idea. Overall, I really enjoyed this game. The driving is a little bit arcade-like but that's fine. After all the patches, it turned out pretty good and I think it deserves a chance. Lot of fun for 30 Euros in sale. I really liked some of the characters and the way they developed throughout the game. The love-hate relationship with Johnny, where he is the coolest guy ever at one moment and then a complete A-hole in the other. The songs were pretty cool as well, lot of genres. And one thing that I totally love in this game are the side missions. Like you have a self-aware gun at one point, guy that sees himself as the Messiah or Monks that still choose pacifism, even if it means one of their brothers get killed. There is just so much to the game than it seems. Lot of different cars, weapons and outfits to unlock as well. SO MANY individual fighting and play styles that replaying the game makes it something totally different with new builds. I know that it's not what lot of people expected, after all those years of waiting. But people like me, who haven't waited for the game's release that long, weren't really associated with it before the trailer with Keanu Reeves/it's release or the anime Edgerunners, this kind of people won't feel that wronged. As I already said, this game deserves a chance. The vibe of it is something no other cyberpunk game offers.And if you have watched the anime, it's something completely unique. I really want to stay at your house. IYKYKTo summarize this, it's a fun game with a great deal of stuff to do and places to explore.It isn't something world breaking but still a good game after being patched.Some bugs may occur but they aren't frequent anymorem they are a rarity just how it's supposed to be. The grame has crashed only once, with lot of mods installed.Characters and story isn't on the level of RDR or TLOU, but it's still appreciable. In the end, it's a 9,1/10. Little flaws and sort of repetitive contracts, but ultimately a satisfactory experience.

author: Gray_Paladin
review: Like millions of players, I've been waiting intently for the release of Cyberpunk 2077.  I have a special connection to this game. I bought the first boxed set of Cyberpunk when it was released in 1988--yeah, I'm that old--then I bought the updated Cyberpunk 2020 and GM'ed that with flesh and blood players--then I coauthored R Talsorian's Maximum Metal add-on system book for the paper and dice RPG. In summary, I've watched CP go from Friday Night Firefight through CP 2020 and owned all of the volumes and mags. It is its whole world now at least as deep and detailed as anything in Elder Scrolls, GOT, or perhaps even Tolkien. And I'll tell you why in a moment...The computer game is altered from the paper and dice RPG, of course. Paper and dice CP was made for a team of human players, with netrunners, solos, fixers, rockers, nomads, corps, and other classes. In this game, your character is basically all of the above. Netrunning had to come out of computer virtual worlds onto the street battlefields. The game does feature some of the trippy original concepts of netrunning, including re-experiencing a virtual world (a la Strange Days or Brainstorm), hacking machinery, and the potential of dying in the machine.Now, let's talk about bugs... I've watched the reputation of Cyberpunk 2077 suffer exactly as did Mafia 3, a magnificent accomplishment similarly bedeviled by bugs and performance issues for months after release. Did the devs catch up? Yeah, 95+% in both large, story driven games. At the time I write this in early-mid 2021, Cyberpunk 2077 runs very well, with very few bugs in PC play, and the devs are providing constant updates and hotfixes. Despite the continuing effort, negative Steam members still rant and flame. Respect!In truth, Cyberpunk 2077 is a breathtaking accomplishment. It features THE most immersive city EVER on a PC. The streets are crowded--I mean crowded--with pedestrians, and cops, and loiterers, and crooks, and... etc., with a wide variety in body styles, ages, races, health, sobriety, attitude, and socioeconomic status--and they have different walks. Watch em. Some swagger, some limp, some sultry sway. (No, GTA 5 doesn't have anything like the volume and variety of gen pop that walk these streets!) The game is also crazy deep, with more than half a dozen distinct regional gangs with their own styles and means, different cops, and different corporate mercs. There are dozens of hundreds of items in the game: a huge array of clothing, cybergear, weapons of all kinds, hacker attack softwares, a wonderful variety of cars and motorcycles, useless items and debris for the immersion, and the whole spectrum of buildings, neighborhoods, and residences you'd expect from a city mirroring LA. You can also craft your character from a very wide range of facial, hair, body, tattoo, and cyber implant styles--as well as your custom privates. There are bars and apartments and offices and elevators and shops and brothels and shops and vendors... And if you want sex... there are parts of town you can go to, or sometimes you can choose to let it happen in some storyline encounters. I repeat: I know of no other PC game of any kind, anywhere, with the immersive urban quality of Cyberpunk 2077. I don't know when we'll see it again this side of full VR. So, to the critics and hypercritics, "Get real!" Have some respect for the colossus. In addition to what I have listed above, there is the story. Oh... my... goodness... There is literally 30+ years of multi-author detail in this world and backstory. Tolkien, as one man writing over 30 years, could not have the breadth and depth of the multi-writer Cyberpunk authors and the backstory of this game. I know that sounds crazy--I do--because I also coauthored Iron Crown Enterprises' Lords of Middle Earth. But there's a reason that CP 2077's convoluted story fits together so well, a tale bigger than the original Bladerunner motion picture, but just as well crafted. This story progressed as an organic thing and it's had time to grow.So, how do I summarize? Cyberpunk 2077 is, simply put, one of the true magnum opus of computer gaming. It is fun and immersive and slick, with a nearly open world as you traverse the main story milestones. The many characters and supporting characters will get to you, whether or not you admit that to your gossip buddies. Every combat provides a variety of tactical options including better stealth mechanics than Deus Ex or Far Cry, and the ability to do cracking head shot ambushes. You'll feel the tension of enemy hackers burning you while you run and shoot, searching for them. The character attribute and perk development system will also force you to define your character. Go for intelligence and hacking, and at higher levels you will be like a wizard killing bad guys in groups and exploding machines from afar. Or you could be like one of my sons, and create a bat wielding brawler that can solve any problem with a piece of wood and a shotgun. The game allows many focused approaches to succeed.Is Cyberpunk 2077 perfect? Of course not. The devs are still putting out a catalog of fires that resemble California in 2020. But they're on it, and the game just keeps getting more and more solid. The game also suffers from a classic issue in PC RPGing, and that is that as your character nears level cap, you can become near invulnerable with godlike powers to melt multiple enemies while your armor turns bullets into gnats. I look at the mods people are creating and some modders are taking those late game balance issues on. You can build quick levels by farming respawns for XP. Finally, as a critique, some original R Talsorian concepts may be broken--like smart weapons. I tend not to use them. Someone who's ever read an issue of Popular Science will laugh at what these bullets do; they'd need intelligent micro fins and thrusters and everything you'd give a missile. So, yeah, they're comic book. If you're reading this for whether you should buy, I'll put it like this: if you like the genre--you MUST buy this game or miss out on the most legit representative of modern or near sci-fi urban fiction on a computer, not to mention the very best incarnation of cyberpunk genre available at this time. If you want to "spray and pray" and you don't care about depth and story, go back to Saints Row or GTA. But if you want to lose your awareness of when you live in a story that's bigger than a single writer can write, enter CP2077, and let it blow you away. It is finally here, and it is good. Scratch that. It's fantastic!

author: Oberain
review: After the launch of 1.6 I decided to come back yet again and give the game another shot; I expected the game to still be trash.It's actually pretty good now.The base game always had a lot of potential but was ruined by terrible design choices and an overwhelming amount of "you got to be kidding me" bugs and glitches.  The good news is most of these seem to have been patched out.  When I say "most of" I actually mean "I have not seen a single issue since I started playing again."  They still do weird things like have people txt you only moments after you talk to them, but eh, it's a video game weird stupid ♥♥♥♥ like that happens.I'm not even going to mention the quality of life additions...mostly because they are too numerous to list and frankly, I'm lazy.  I will say I was actually surprised how all of these little changes and additions genuinely make the experience much, MUCH more enjoyable on a massive scale.So...yeah I'd actually recommend people play this now.Original negative review:Played the game at launch and despite the game being stable for me, the constant graphical glitches and T-posing NPCs wore me down to the point where I couldn't give a ♥♥♥♥ to keep playing.1 year later and a few patches later I boot up the game...surely, SURELY they fixed the majority of the simple problems, right?Play the corpo intro and 10 minutes in Jackie and V start T-pose gliding down the street with V missing his head.Absolutely embarrassing.Edit: I am unable to pick up 30% of the items (vendor trash, rolls of money) that are strewn about the floor despite the game indicating they can be picked up.  Tutorial mission improperly updated killing the scav leader.  I'm in the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ tutorial and the game is already in an objectively WORSE state than it was when I played it a year ago. HOW THE ♥♥♥♥ DID YOU MAKE THE GAME OBJECTIVELY WORSE?!

review: when "never fade away" hits different

author: BubbleBlep (Violet)
review: It's sad, because you can tell with the glitches and terrible optimization that the game was rushed to release. You can see all the hard work put into the story and environment and game overall, but those last minute issues of optimizing and squashing bugs didn't get the attention it needed. Super odd since CDPR was doing all that crunching on their employees. The saving grace is the the actual game itself is good, maybe even incredible in my opinion, but the optimization is pretty bad. . I activated my windows and my FPS almost doubled. I feel like a moron, but I will say my friends who have more than the recommended specs (1660TI) are having a bad time with FPS. I am playing on Ultra with DLSS on quality and hit the 100-140 range which is something I can totally enjoy.But hey, optimization and bugs can be ironed out, fixed, and improved. I can quite confidently say this game is going to be one of the best I have ever played, but its just being held back by the formerly mentioned issues. I've waited years for this game and will be playing it multiple times in the future, so I am willing to wait for the future patches to come out.Was it worth the hype? In its current state, barely. Only if you can run this consistently at your desired frame rate. I can, which is why I give this review a thumbs up. The bugs are still a very real issue though. While it's very disappointing for many people, it isn't the end of the world. The game isn't ruined for me, nothing makes me more excited than to play this game on my second play through. Its quite obvious this game hit stupid hype levels that only games like Half Life 3 hit. At that point, it is your own job not to buy into those stupidly high expectations. I hope those people learned their lessons today.

author: Opifer
review: Been playing games since the 1980s. This is the best one ever. Can't wait for more games in this style of FPS/RPG, perhaps Shadowrun or Planescape. The 3 lifepaths are all great. Combat is rock solid. Dialogue choices abound. Characters are interesting. The future is now.

author: Lone
review: Cons: Launched in a broken state (currently still has many bugs 8 months and 3 updates later), many key rpg features missing from the game, the worst A.I. system of any game I've ever played, very little meaningful in game choices, bad game physics, poorly optimized may burn your gpu or cpu, no car customization, no character customization after the initial one, no content after beating the main story world is pretty much empty, Devs lied about included features, Devs also lied about game performance, Devs showed fake in game footage. Honestly the list could go on. Pros: Compelling story & cyberpunk theme.... yeah that's pretty much it.I wouldn't suggest you buy this game at all. But if you do decide to buy I'd wait for a GOTY edition to come out which will be many years from now. But even then I wouldn't recommend buying it. This company sold us a broken product. Gamers are the only consumer that get sold broken products and accept it. You wouldn't accept any other product that arrived to you in a broken state. Not a car, a washer and dryer, or phone. You'd return it and probably never trust that company again if they didn't replace your product with one that was 100% working because that's what we paid for, same expectations as any other product we purchase.

author: Salamand3r-
review: In the current state, I cannot recommend this game.With some significant graphical glitches still present, some inconsistent performance issues, the inability to fully rebind keys (completely sidelining ESDF or other non-standard keyboard users), a questionable HDR implementation, and a lot of toher technical issues it appears that, even with a massive delay, the game needs another 6-12 months of patches.This review WILL be updated as time goes on.  My full review will also take into account the absolute shadiness of CDPR in general.It does look like this game will still be an incredibly solid 8/10 once things get ironed out, but currently it's just not there.  There are indie early access games that show more polish.

author: ThePro Official ©
review: I play on a 1060, as the recommended says, yet I can't run 60 fps even on the lowest settings with a 1080p resolution. The game is good, but don't expect to play it on high resolution unless you have 2080 or 3080.EDIT: Okay, after playing for about 100 hours, tried all the options, finished all side and main quests, I have to admit... It was worth 60 eddies. Don't get discouraged by everyone complaining about the glitches. Sure, there are many of them. But as you get immersed into this world, you will forget about them. Pro Tip: I finished all the life paths, doesn't really matter which one you choose, only the first few minutes are different and only rarely it gives you an extra option in a conversation, other than that it does not change anything at all. Also, I finished the game on the "Very Hard" option and it was not hard at all, so do not fear it. This game can make you view life from a new perspective.Always remember: "The wider the smile, the bigger the lies."
