author: Hyokkuda
review: When I first heard about this game in 2013, I was slightly annoyed & puzzled at the same time! Many people were overly excited even though there was no gameplay footage or enough info at the time other than the Teaser Trailer, with comments from people who said that this would be the game of the year or the best game ever created in the game industry. Well! The game is finally here, & let me tell you that this has been more than engaging. It's been amazing! Since I played, I can't seem to put that game down. The main story just keeps on giving! It's like watching a really good movie, & I had a lot of fun playing it. The main story has been really gripping.For starters, I'm sure that most of you have heard about a large number of bugs in this game by now. I heard that The Witcher 3 was just as buggy at launch. However, I never played it. From my own gaming experience, I didn't encounter too many bugs, so I guess I'm one of the few lucky people. It seems that CDPR is quick on fixing bugs & listening to people.You start by choosing your life path & create your character with a poor choice of tattoos & color for the eyes & hair. Shush! I'm picky with that sort of thing. The character's face can't be seen outside of the inventory menu, in mirrors, in photo mode & at the end of the game. But to some people, including myself, it's better than no options at all. (We were told & shown that we could see our character in cutscenes, but there's been none in the game so far, minus the endings. Maybe in future updates!) Also, there's no turning back for you, which means that makeup on your character's face will be permanent in 2077! You should keep an eye open for those friends of yours who might want to prank you in your sleep...After about 30 minutes into the game, you turn out to be a mercenary who does various jobs for Fixers & activities for friends like races, shooting targets contest & help-out the NCPD clear out the streets from various crimes & from cyberpsychos. Sometimes you will also be asked to escort someone, deliver a package, or retrieve some item or evidence.There's also a small collectible activity available, which requires you to tag or scan 20 Tarot Card graffiti scattered all over Night City. There's also a dozen pre-added crime scenes & story-teller scenes for legendary or iconic weapons & items, free vehicles & data shards (notes) for the player to pick up that shares a few interesting Easter eggs related to some well known movies & other video games, which is a nice touch.The combat feels good, especially when filled with over 50 weapon types & dozens of Iconic weapons available in the game. Some are more loved than others, & even more when they also have weapon attachments available like different muzzles, suppressors, better sights & long scopes. Many weapons & attachments are available in various colors & paint jobs that might not be for everyone's cup of tea. But if you want to rock with a bright-pink futuristic AK-47 that carries a baby blue suppressor & a lime green scope for your flashy cyborg-killer, then that's a thing. Or if you prefer to shoot your enemies with your shiny-gold-looking shotgun & sniper rifle, that's also possible! Unfortunately, changing the color/skin of your weapon at will is not possible. No menu or NPC can do that for you, which is a shame.There's a vast selection of clothes & head accessories for you to choose from, allowing you to dress your character how you want it & without gender restriction neither. Earrings aren't an option, since it's part of the character creation. Most jewelry like necklaces, bracelets is either tied to innerwear, outerwear, or a one-piece outfit. The next thing I'm not too fond of is the color options. Luck & patience is needed to find the right color, not to mention the armor's stats that go with it.Fortunately! There's a crafting option allowing you to turn an uncommon or a rare item into a legendary item if you have the perks & attributes for it, & also to increase the DPS of pretty much all weapons & armor stats to match your character level. So you can stick with the same pistol you're carrying around since level 2 & still kick some butts with it!There's something that could confuse some people at first since this game has 3 different level systems. First is your character's level, which will allow you to use stronger weapons & armors but also match enemies to your current level. The second is street cred, which is your reputation. A higher cred will give you access to better weapons, armors, cyberwear, vehicles & other items like mods & so forth. The third is the skill progression, which will increase based on actions you keep doing through the game. Like, performing multiple stealth takedowns will increase its progression & allow you to get some skill rewards like increase evasion by 3%, or give +1 perk point & decrease visibility to enemies by 10%, etc.Vehicles play a significant role in this game. Despite the world map looking pretty small, it feels big even while driving 200 MPH down the road. Car handling varies from hypercars to sports cars & muscle cars. Muscle cars & sports cars drive & handle the best. As for motorcycles, I could only appreciate 2 types of motorcycles as the rest didn't feel that great. As of right now, there's no taxi/cabs you can take & that fancy train from the trailer is (at the moment) just for show. As for the AVs (flying cars), they aren't something you can drive. They only appear during missions.A few side quests are tied to the main story, which could change the course of action & even the faith of the story. The same goes for the life path you start with, making life easier or more challenging for you if you were a Corpo, a Street Kid or a Nomad. Some dialogue options can be available to you based on your life path. The same goes for your attributes. High enough points in Cool can give you the option to suggest a better plan to take on an enemy territory.The immersion & amount of details in this game always impresses me, like the News on TV & radio that shares details on what's been happening as you progress through the story. Or NPC near mission areas that talk about recent events the player might have caused. Or just the visual is sometimes shocking, making me wonder why the developers went that far just for that amount of detail, like the components under the cars.This game has some ups & downs. Let's go back to the voice acting for a moment. It's more of a personal opinion than a fact. I did create both character genders, & I might be crazy, but I have the feeling that the protagonist was meant to be a female character in the producer's mind from the very beginning. Either that or the woman who voiced V was much more experienced than the man who did it. Sometimes, the result from the male version of V was underwhelming to me. The "expression" in the voice for a lot of dialogues was missing. Like during an intense mission from Act 1, I could detect the sadness & disturbance in the female voice. Early on into the game, a quick example with female V as a Corpo who will whisper to Frank sharing info about her boss who is in a tough spot. You can see Frank's facial animation & body language, which tries to listen carefully to V's whispering. But male V never whispered while sharing the same dialogue & Frank did the same animations for that whispering sequence. That didn't hit me the same way. But again, it might just be me.Outside of the mission areas (free roam), the AI is terrible. Don't expect that to be like GTA or RDR2, as the developers seem to have put more effort into quest areas than anywhere else on the map. Certain action buttons like flipping a switch or sitting on a stool could use a larger hitbox. I often find myself having to wiggle my character or crosshair around.Well, I believe that's pretty much it for now. I hope that my review was helpful to you! ♥

author: .#𝚌𝚊𝚞𝚜𝚝𝚒𝚌
review: First: I think I have more hours spend in fotomode than in the actual game...The setting is really nice. When you are lucky and the game runs smooth on your build you get a really decent looking world.I just started back at release for some minutes to check if the game works and then I waited till now to play it (after the first bigger bugfixes and updates came). With my GTX1080 the graphics look really good and sharp. The only thing I have is some fps dropping (from 60 to 20) in downtown. 60fps for a single player game are okay for me (think that on consoles it was capped anyway + I get a much better graphic with this then on a console).I really liked the story. Do you remember in The Witcher 3, the decissions, that you hated, because there was no clear good or bad outcome, so you had to choose what you thought would be the lesser evil? Well, in Cyperpunk you have this all the time. It can be frustrating, but it also makes you reflect a lot. So a kind of hate love for this.BUT, as many others already stated: Most decisions don´t have any impact and most of it takes places at the end.I found the main story a little short to be honest, also with all the involved sidequests. Most hours I spend was doing GIGs and Street Crime stuff. You have much do to, but it is also a little bit too much. Some funny and nice sidequest aside, most are really repetitive. To enjoy the main story more I wanted to do all side stuff that was at "moderate" or "low" level before proceeding..well: I needed 2 full days to do so. The main con with all this side fill is: you forget about the story and you get dragged out of it completely.Many people criticised the armor/clothing system, but I like it. Ofc, if you only wear each clothing piece with best armor stats you look a little goofy, but I didn´t experienced any downside in wearing a shirt that had 10 armor points less than another. So I change from time to time. And because there is SO MANY clothing options I can choose from I always experience what looks good for me. Also some kind of "game in a game". BUT: why can´t we have a prelook in stores on how a certain item looks on ourselves?The part of the game that I most liked is, that you can choose your playstyle. I love playing sneeky and even in games that are not made for this I always try to do it that way. Here I am totally free to do so. First playthrough I played ninja. My second one with my nomad V I was more like a gunblazing berzerk. <3I must admit: I had a lot of fun with this game and still have, BUT while going through this world I always see how great it would have been if they would have implemented what they promised. I was not part of the hypetrain. I just heard that the guys from TW3 made a new game with cyperpunk setting and I was like: count me in. I even never watched a trailer or demo before release. So it is just my "feeling". I know you can´t compare Cyberpunk to some GTA, but I can compare a AAA Game from 2020 to games from 2014 regarding NPC/AI behaviour and environment, etc. And it is sad that in this parts even GTA IV beats Cyberpunk. After that I saw the videos of what Cyberpunk promised back then and I see how it is now. That doesn´t make me angry. It just feels sad, because I think the only thing that this game lacks is some time to go from a great game to an astonishing game. And I feel sad for the developers, because I know they wanted that too. In so many sidestorys or events in the world you can see it, with little references and easter eggs.

author: grinchfox
review: It's like GTA:V but with more plot and content. Controls are trashy, game has lots of bugs but overall its good simply for amount of content it gives.

author: Monarch
review: Deeply flawed game that under-promised nearly every aspect of interactivity. The story and narrative are flawed and the player choice and engagement is inconsequential. Every 'start point' and supposed 'choice' always leads to the same outcomes. The environment and technology is buggy, barely functional. Everything seems to have been hidden under a figurative rug when it comes to player interactivity. And sometimes, even the facade is nonfunctional and ugly to look at.The gamplay is flawed and extraordinarily boring. The focus on first-person allows for neat gunplay or combat as well as movement and other engagement aspects, but the game sorely lacks anything innovative or unique - as it claimed. All upgrades offer no dynamic change to the way the game is played - which is to engage interactive objects only at specific times and places. Combat offers nothing unique, and is overall weak and nonimpactful, while its upgrades offer only static numbers and modifiers to improve upon. It really just becomes a game of collecting loot and weapons and upping numbers while remaining the same.While it promised so much, it delivered so little. This product is just an ironic testament to the greed and the short nearsightedness of corporations - and what they will do to fantastic and rich ideas in order to commodify it for a community that is undeserving of its introduction. If you want to enjoy the cyberpunk genre, stick to literary circles because this media is a gross misrepresentation and a failure of a game. Extremely disappointing.

author: Theory
review: Tits, first 30 minutes.  Yes.  Come see, and I saw.

author: DrSomers
review: Game is enjoyable for the first few hours, but as you really start getting into it you notice the glaring lack of features and obvious rushing that happened in development. Will definitely go down as one of the most disappointing games of all time, and that is not an exaggeration. Of course there are people who say they had no problem with the story/gameplay/bugs/glitches/etc and that is fine, but it is important to point out the problems that alot of people have with this game. CD Project Red lied when marketing this game, it is a bare bones experience 99% of the time. There is 0 sense of choice or care to missions, compared to Witcher 3 where even the standard kill monster quests had some semblance of story and choices. The combat is boring, not that CD Project Red is known for great combat mechanics, but when every other part of the game is also mediocre then it stands out even more. The story is lackluster where it just becomes about Keannu after the 1st main arc, and the initial life path choice has no affect except for a few useless alternative dialogue options.  Character customization, which is meant to be a core feature of the Cyberpunk genre, is completely wasted here with no 3rd person or out of body cutscenes. After almost an entire year after launch, this game is still riddled with issues and no amount of bug fixes will remedy the core issues that this game has with story/choice/combat/progression/etc.

author: insait
review: TL;DR: Don't buy. It's unfinished and simply not what was promised. I personally enjoyed it tho.Also, Review is based on my experience with the game in 2020/early 2021.First off, I enjoyed my 50 hours with Cyberpunk so far.I encountered a small amount of bugs, which were mostly funny or dumb in nature, or a minor annoyance at most.Still, under no circumstances do I wanna overlook the horrendous state the game was/still is in on other platforms/hardware.In my opinion, the game should have never been announced for last-gen consoles.Also, the implementation of RTX appears to have made a huge impact on development. The game is poorly optimized, no doubt.Let's dig a bit deeper.I run a 3070 and a Ryzen 5600X at the moment. Decent hardware, one could say. Still, on Ultra Settings, 1080p, I get a measly 70fps average. City center dips to the 50fps range occasionally. Not bad, but still disappointing.The game changer here really is DLSS. Turn this setting to Quality or Performance, no further. (Everything beyond "Performance" is gonna look like cereal.) DLSS boosts my FPS by about 40% on average, which is impressive.Rendering and Texture Streaming seem to have been heavily gutted to make the game run on the old console generation, which is sad to see. I often encountered missing textures, or textures that were low quality popping in, suddenly becoming "HD".And these are just a few of the visual bugs I encountered.Now, I can look past that. Mostly. But it still leaves that feeling of "Oh god, I wasted money on this?"On the other hand, the game is simply stunning. Visuals and Textures are solid across the board. Lighting, even without RTX On is really nice. The game creates a lot of atmosphere just with the visuals alone.There is so much attention to detail in everything. The cars, the different city districts, the houses, the advertisements, etc. etc. etc.Character models are beautifully done. Don't get me started. I think Panam, Rogue, Judy, Kerry etc. are some of the most convincing and beautiful character models I've ever seen.The main characters are a total feast for the eyes. They are truly a sight to behold and make playing the side-quests so much more worth it.I had some big issues with the audio.The biggest problem is that some parts of environmental audio just keep cutting in and out randomly.There are cutscenes in which you only hear your character grunting, despite being in a fight, while beating someone to the ground. It gets extremely awkward at times.Also, people will deliver some sentences with completely different cadence, with a completely different voice filter/setup, as if re-recorded.And those moments aren't far and in-between. It happens all the time.Voice acting is well done for the most part.Even pedestrian one-liners sound believable.Especially for the main characters, their voices carry a lot of - well - character. Hah.Except for the two most important characters.HOW COULD THEY ♥♥♥♥ THIS UP????First off, V.I've only played female V so far, but it's been really disappointing and even cringe at some points.V just sounds so disinterested. At best, V manages to sound cynical and edgy, maybe sarcastic. The rest is some mix of neutral and tired. It's really weird. The female voice actor sounds like purposefully lowering their tone to sound tough.I hate it.Secondly, Johnny ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Silverhand.It's less bad than on V. I like Keanu Reeves as an actor, and I adore a lot of the roles he played.I think Johnny's voice acting is.... okay-ish for the most part. But there's little character in it. There are situations in which Johnny just sounds so out-of place.Have a listen to some of Johnny's voicelines during tense moments, and you'll agree with me.It feels like the actors for V, Johnny and some others (very occasionally) haven't been properly introduced to the scene they're playing.This only gets amplified by the audio bugs I mentioned above.It really hurts.The music in-game is some of the best and most emotionally impactful I've heard in any game.It is simply amazing. Give a listen to "Bells of Laguna Bend" or "Outsider No More".The score beautifully underlines the important story moments and perfectly builds tension where it is needed.Radio Music and Fighting Ambience are okay, but become stale quickly. Nothing special here.Gameplay is... I dunno. Alright.Most side quests are the usual "fetch/kill/bring and deliver". Add all the other stuff one would expect from an open-world RPG/Adventure.Story- and Side-Quests are done nicely, I enjoyed all of the "meaningful quests" thouroughly.Gunplay feels nice, the melee weapons are okay but kinda obsolete.Perks do basically next to nothing for you. For being advertised as an RPG, the skill trees feature next to no new "abilities". Only percentual bonuses to stats you or your weapons might have.Apart from quickhacking and stealth, the perks have little impact on how you play.The most impactful upgrades are the cybernetics.The whole skill system feels like a rushed afterthought.Bugs here are limited to certain quest triggers not happening, forcing you to reload a save file.Not too bad. I haven't had any quests hard-lock my game. (yet?)NPCs are laughable. Apart from the usual shopkeepers and vendors, or quest-related NPCs, the pedestrians are totally replaceable.All they can do is walk around, cower in fear, run away, or drive straight. It's honestly impressive how much CDPR was able to contradict their own promises.I mean, the NPCs literally disappear when you walk a block. "Daily routine" my ass.I would've loved more clothing and weapon variety. There are probably only 15 weapons in the game, varying in stats and paint finish, if at all. Clothing is a bit better, but it still sucked to walk into a store, look at the sleek designs on the wall-adverts and not being able to buy ANYTHING shown in the adverts.The story is nicely done, in my opinion.It's nothing praiseworthy. no intense heart-wrenching drama, no gigantic plot-twists...But the story and dilemma of V creates lots of stuff to think and talk about.The notion of self gets questioned, family, death, afterlife and personal growth play big roles. There's criticism on basically any modern way of living everywhere, but CDPR managed to not over-do it to the point of SJW-ism.I won't go into much detail here, but I enjoyed the story, extended through sidequests, a lot.Cyberpunk 2077 is.. a guilty pleasure?Maybe I am easy to impress, but if I can find one or two things that make a game interesting for me, it's worth playing and liking to me. The characters, story and love to detail really saved this game in my eyes.There are glaring issues that will definitely ruin the experience for many players.But to face the facts, this game isn't recommendable.At this point (January 2021) it doesn't come close to a AAA experience.CDPR "promised" to re-do big parts of the game until June '21, so maybe get the game then.

author: PureBusiness
review: Well, where do I begin?5hours in; Mediocre over-hyped Open World RPG. Clearly a rushed decision to release early. Definitely needs more work. Good story and heavy on narration but the gameplay sucks. NPC AI is buggy / nonexistent and for it being such an intense world and it feels rather lifeless. At the time of my review I'd played this game for 90 minutes. My review 90mins in; - They couldn't even release it on time (Even at 00:00 it wasn't playable until 00:20+)- They delayed multiple times (Partially thanks to the pandemic)- Even after release the game still feels unpolished and is really buggy- The start of the game is very boring and gives you little to no feel for how the actual game will be- Feels like it was made by Bethesda instead of CDPR- Chrome and Gold reflective textures dont do this games graphics justice- Character customisation is 'complex' but also limited? It gives you many options, but the options don't have many options. Lip stick colour for example is very limited. (Apparently more options will come in the future?)- Texture work even on things that should be obvious (The ground for example) are terrible. Max settings looks similar to GTA 5. (Texture streaming bugs apparently, even though I play on a Samsung 970 Plus NVMe SSD)- Doesn't do a great job of letting you know you've just taken a bullet, I didn't notice how low my health was until I bothered to look at my health bar. No hit indicator, no jam, no feedback (Is a bug, requires reloading the game save)- NPC likes to stand directly in front of you so you can't shoot (Generally buggy / lackluster AI awareness)- You cannot change Anti-Aliasing technique and the one it uses makes things blurry / soft and I hate it. MFAA I believe. Give me FXAA OR NOTHING! (TAA is forced and cannot be disabled. However Nvidia overlay works to sharpen things up)- Graphics options don't have much effect on performance. DLSS does though.- You cannot rebind things that should be able to be rebound. For example, the F key (interact). Apparently this will be fixed in the future.Positives;- The world is open, really cool and lots to do. However it all seems a little boring and lifeless. Hopefully this will be better when they improve the NPC AI.- Feels like Division 2 in terms of how spongy the enemies are (Depends on difficulty I guess, I played on Very Hard but switched to Hard, seems better now)- The sound stage is excellent. Audio is very crisp and directional audio is great as well.Overall so far? 5.4/10. Just about passable only because I know CDPR will work out the bugs in the future but for now, avoid this title.I'll update if I change my mind but so far this game needs work. This is either Cyberpunk 2077 but it's just not finished. This does not feel like a game of the same quality that Witcher 3 managed to achieve. I hope the story is good but I'm yet to complete the game and do anything rememberable.Edit: To respond to those people berating me because of my playtime or choice of FXAA - FXAA still shows jagged edges and has the least smearing out of all of the AA options (if there were any lol) and I understand 1.4 hours probably isn't enough to review the actual game story itself which is why I didn't say much for it. This review is mostly for the state of the game NOT a review for the story. However to counter that, 90 minutes into the game I found myself quite bored. This feels a rushed release. The fact you cannot change some of the keybindings or anti-aliasing options makes me believe so. It is missing options every PC game should have.Edit 2: Tried to play the game again today and the REDlauncher crashed as I was signing up for extra in-game loot... Off to a great start. (probably due to millions playing the game)Edit 3: To clarify, all my drivers are the latest they can be. I'm running the game on an Intel Core i9 9900K, 32GB RAM and a RTX 2080 Ti. SSD is a 1TB Samsung 970 Evo Plus NVMe. I've played on RT Ultra with DLSS on (60fps) and off (25fps) but I seem to have found "High" to be a decent mix of performance and visuals. Ray Tracing doesn't seem to work on all textures like the glass in your apartment does not reflect your character like it does in Watch Dogs Legions for example.Edit 4: Last update to my review, 5 hours in and I'm still bored. Think I'm going to wait a while for updates to be released... the NPC AI is killing the fun for me because it's so "Ubisoft", in that I mean the NPC are lifeless and lack any kind of awareness. For example a dancing NPC will say "I don't have time for this" in an angry tone but yet their character is dancing in a club...????

author: dinkie
review: As much as it pains me to say this, this game is inherently awful. First, let's go over the pros:-Story is fantastic. I really do care about the characters and the world they created really does feel real-Gunplay is decent-Gives a good variety of side missions and different gigs that fixers give you-Voice acting is great..And that's it!Before even listing everything that is atrocious about this game, let me say this: The obvious thing that many have heard are the optimization and bugs, which are EVERYWHERE.  This no longer is an issue for me as I've upgraded, but the game still shouldn't run horribly with specs that are near/better than recommended. This game is also plagued with visual and audio bugs. The first 5 hours of the game, the audio was crackling. Sounded like firecrackers during music or dialogue. It literally hurt my ears and I had to hunt for a fix. NPCs will T-Pose, hold the same pose for minutes, and bodies will black in-and-out. And while we're on the topic of NPCs, lets talk about the absolute worst part of the game: the NPC AI. The NPCs in this game are a joke. Sure, there is a good variety of them, but they don't do ANYTHING. Have the same generic one line they say, all have the SAME animations (walking, running, crouching, etc.), and are terrible drivers. Park your car in the middle of the street, and when you come back there will be a line of cars behind it like at Disneyland. Driving NPCs cannot turn, swivel away, drive around it, literally ANYTHING. They don't react to you pulling out your gun or shooting their car other then running out of their car. The cars also handle absolutely horribly. Turning is slippery as ♥♥♥♥, drifting is nonexistent, and why in God's name is there not a CAR DEALERSHIP? The only way to obtain new cars and call them to your location is buying them from fixers. You can't even steal a car from the streets and save it. Not to mention no car customization whatsoever.Another thing, customization. For a game that was so heavily marketed to create the character of your dreams and roam the great streets of Night City, customization is a complete joke. You can customize the appearance from the beginning of the game (face, body, tattoos, even genitals), but after that if you wanna change it, you're ♥♥♥♥ out of luck. Can't change your haircut, can't add tattoos, not even edit the CYBERWARE on your face. No plastic surgery, so if you're not satisfied with your ugly face, better start a new save file, or endure that for 20+ hours. While there are a lot of different clothes you can choose from and wear, some genius at CDPR thought to give them armor values. So it's either look like a clown and have high armor, or be stylish but potentially sacrifice armor. A torn up T-shirt should have armor, and not the CYBERNETICS ON YOUR BODY! Night City looks very pretty and well-made, but the streets are essentially empty. Can't go into most shops, clubs don't offer anything outside of missions, no mini-games, NOTHING. Night City ends up feeling so lifeless and is barebone when it comes to an open-world game. I could go on and on about the frustrations I've had with this game and how much of a let down this was, but the most frustrating thing is this: The high praise this game is receiving. It drives me absolutely ballistic that this game has a 90 on metacritic, 9/10 from IGN, and high scores from countless other outlets. Did they play the same trash that I played? This game is at best a 5/10.After finishing the game and having a few days to think about it, I would say I genuinely enjoyed my time playing this game, but I still wouldn't recommend it because of the state it's in. Even after CDPR's updates and half-assed apology, this game is still going to be unfinished for the next 2-3 years. It really is sad the state this game came out in, because this is one of the better stories I've played in a video game (even if your choices don't mean ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥).

I enjoyed the story and gameplay of the game and I can confirm that you will see the impacts of your actions in game.I had fun while playing Cyberpunk and I don't regret the time I spent in this game. The story of Cyberpunk for me is as remarkable as games like Bioshock and Half-life. in short term, it was a "breathtaking" experience.PS: I want to emphasize the importance of side missions in Cyberpunk. they are good crafted and some of them are really important for the game lore and/or your endings.

author: hyperbolicsyllabicsesquedalymist
review: TL;DR: This game is DEFINITELY not ready for release and should have been delayed for at least another year. Filled with bugs, annoying combat, and terribly optimized, even with newest drivers and well above recommended specs.BUGS-------------This game is immensely unplayable in its current state. I'm astonished it even got past QA testing. There are so many bugs in this game that make it downright unplayable. It has been a long time since I have played a game with such an immense amount of bugs. Not since Half-Life: Source. And even Half-Life: Source seems bug free compared to this ♥♥♥♥. For a quick rundown of some of the ♥♥♥♥ I've experienced:-Multiple instances of characters clipping through each other, NPCs disappearing, and weapons turning invisible-Keybind for switching weapons stays at L. Alt even though I CLEARLY set it to not be-Falling through the floor-Physics engine giving up on life-Visual bugs that render some parts of the map as an invisible void-Characters talking over each other and calling during scenes which shouldn't be possible, temporarily breaking the conversation with a mission character-Missions getting really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ confused on where I should be-V being very ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ confused on what animation I should be playing-And endless more that I have forgotten by now because they were overshadowed by above bugsCOMBAT/GAMEPLAY-------------The enemies you fight feel like bullet sponges, and you'll need to spend at least two magazines trying to kill them. There's also a thing where a camera can overheat you, which is really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ annoying when it happens in a room that the camera isn't even in.This game also has a lot of something that I have come to hate a lot: cutscenes.Since Half-Life's debut in 1998, it has been painfully obvious to every single game developer on the planet that there is absolutely no need at all to have a single moment where the player is not in control of their character, except when it is . And there are a lot of moments where the character is needlessly not in control by the player, even when it isn't integral to the plot of the game. And even though they have implemented a feature that allows you to skip some dialogue, it's very finicky about what counts as a moment that can be skipped, and it doesn't work half the time. Probably the most fun I've had in this game is when the story is happening while I am in control of the player, and when I explore the vast beauty of Night City and mess around with it.OPTIMIZATION (TL;DR THIS GAME RUNS LIKE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥)-------------And the optimization. Hoo boy, the optimization.I am well beyond the recommended specs for this game (not even minimum) and at high settings, I'm getting 10-20 fps in most scenes. In low settings, it's around 40 fps. It's only when I turn down the resolution scale to 75% that I get playable performance at Low settings.According to what everyone else has to say, it's a mixed bag what experience you get. Some people claim they have flawless performance with similar or worse specs to mine. Some claim that their computer is practically catching fire even with specs like a 3090 and an i9-10900k. Some are console players and are complaining about how the game runs terribly on their 1st gen PS4 or Xbox One (boo hoo).When you develop a game, you want performance to be consistent across all devices, and not an issue for people with the right specs. This is not the case for Cyberpunk. If you are in a situation like mine, this is most likely the dealbreaker for you.CONCLUSION-------------Most issues were discussed above, so let's make it short and simple here. No. No. Yes, if you are willing to deal with these issues. If you play this game for more than ten minutes, you will realize that it is not a finished product. Not even close. This needed at least four more delays before it could even qualify as a finished game.

author: Junketo
review: A labor of love that ended up ultimately being a bit of a mixed bag of a game that broke my heart.I feel real bad for CD Projekt Red - you can clearly tell a super talented team poured their hearts into this, which makes it extra frustrating when there seem to be a lot of missing pieces and a lot of sloppiness in terms of gameplay.I got pretty immediately hooked with this game, and had very few expectations going into it - I was captivated with the story, visuals, depth of the city and its various characters. But after the initial honeymoon fades, and you realize how hollow the world really is outside of the main storyline, you can't help but start feeling really bitter.I'll get right to my biggest gripe of all, which for me is gameplay - Combat, driving, even minigames all seem to be a bit... dull? And also WAY too easy? Ultimately, the majority of the gameplay feels more like an afterthought that is more meant to supplement the storytelling, and that is NOT what one would expect from CDPR. But to add insult to injury, they also completely fell short on the only other thing that could've made this game more exciting and that's actual customization.COMBAT:Enemy AI is kind of mediocre - I wouldn't say it's BAD, but it's highly predictable and unvaried. What's frustrating is that the combat difficulty goes down dramatically around mid-game once you start getting better weapons and whatnot. But it just gets to a point where combat is not even fun, just tedious / annoying. Especially police interactions where cops just.... spawn out of thin air a few feet away from you? The implementation of this is atrocious. The guns are great, and they feel good to shoot, but the melee combat is honestly garbage - very disappointed with it. It feels clunky, awkward, uncoordinated... Nothing at all like the buttery smooth, almost orchestral sword dancing you'd get in the Witcher. I get that 1st person melee combat is totally different, but there are ways to do it right! This is not it. Also the fist-fighting is utter crap and so buggy, it takes A LOT of luck to finish those damn boxing missions.DRIVING:Personally, I don't mind the mechanics - reminds me of the old Driver games as far as the cars handle, just takes some getting used to. There's definitely room for improvement. Some vehicles feel great, while others are almost undrivable (Quadro Turbo R, looking at you). What really needs improvement here is vehicle MASS, which you can really feel during collisions. Crashing into another car feels so so so fake and unrealistic - it's like both cars are made out of cardboard. And some cars will literally just... drive right under other cars at high speeds? The worst part of all this though is the laughable racing missions - the opponent vehicles don't even actually race you, but just spawn alongside you if you get too far ahead / too far behind, and they can't actually blow up your car when they shoot at you (or vice versa). What in the world were the developers thinking here, I have no idea - these races COULD be SO MUCH FUN if they made them actual races, with intelligent driving AI and realistic vehicle mass and damage. Instead, once I realized I'm not racing at all, these missions were so dumb - no challenge at all. And they are the only racing offered in the whole game, so clearly they didn't intend to flesh out the racing idea, which is really frustrating. Why even bother teasing us with the idea? Why pour so much attention and energy into the vehicles in this game, and not even have more missions that revolve around driving / racing?CUSTOMIZATION:This is where the game gets a major "Huh?" They give you the option to create your own character in the beginning from scratch, going so far as to change your ♥♥♥♥ size. You get setup thinking, wow, I'll be able to do so much customizing in this game...! But nope. For one, no personalizing your character after creation - not even haircuts or color, or tattoos - nothing. Guns??? You can add a few mods (that aren't visual), switch out a couple of scopes, and choose between a couple of silencers. That's it. And vehicles? Nothing. You can't even pick the color of your car. Clothes? You can add stat-changing mods, but that's it - no customizing, or color changing, or even a way to neatly organize them. God forbid you want to put together a cohesive closet for V - good luck finding the exact shade of that particular jacket you're looking for. Big thumbs down here for an RPG game that heavily flaunts customization and screenshot photography tools that implies it cares about aesthetics.All in all, to say I'm disappointed is an understatement. Even if this game ever fully address its myriad of issues and adds more content and customization features, at the point things are at now and from what I've heard regarding the devs prioritizing shareholders interests over team concerns really just leaves a bad taste in my mouth. I just have no interest in replaying this. Wasted potential.

author: Skullzi
review: Don't believe the clickbait.  in my 22 hours of gameplay thus far, I have only encountered 4 very minor visual bugs.  If you play this on PS4 or Xbox One I feel bad for you, but crossgen games always have issues on old tech.  This game is a rare gem, 10 out of 10 easily.  The immersion is akin to a Bethesda Game Studios game, and the world is beautiful and handcrafted literally down to the trash in the street.  I love this game, and it will always have a special place in my heart.  Easily in my top 5 best games of all time.

author: Morgan
review: If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pieDirections:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing

author: ellbent
review: The effort it takes to enjoy Cyberpunk 2077 is monumental. Nothing in Cyberpunk 2077 stands up to anything but the most cursory scrutiny. You wind your way through lively city streets packed with vendors, but the one ramen shop that is functional sells you the same equivalent of Capri-Sun and Hot Pockets that you can get from vending machines. Night City has no taxis, mass transit, or public transportation of any kind available to the player, despite a mission (and an  annoying side job) prominently featuring the most luxurious taxi service Eurodollars can buy.At best, there's a conspicious hole where any player would expect a function or feature. At worst, it becomes unclear why some systems were implemented at all. The only mystery is whether it was poorly conceived or poorly implemented -- whether the feature was too ambitious to include from the start, or whether out of sunk-cost fallacy it was abandoned instead of removed altogether as it should have been, and these strangenesses blend into oneanother.For instance, every single  can be turned into crafting components, but not any , and to do so means selecting each functionally identical soda and recycling them; a harrowing idea when you first open the easily-ignored Backpack icon tucked away in the corner of the inventory screen and realize you're carrying varying amounts of sixty different beverages with no way to do this in bulk. The game does offer you the ability to sell all your junk items en masse, but  the ability to mark anything  junk -- a feature that's been offered in every other game to come before it where a stream of slightly higher numbers cycles its way through your equipment. Furthermore, an early perk automatically disassembles any junk items you pick up, permanently obselescing the "sell all junk" feature anyway. Is this two half-baked ideas, or one attempt at user-friendliness rendered inconsequential by a hasty later addition? Which one is which?The game and setting are highly concerned with appearances, but yours isn't customizable in the least outside of character creation. Not hair, not makeup, and certainly not clothing. Clothing is the entirety of V's protection, and comprised almost entirely of what you gather from the corpses of the gang members that the police pay you to summarily execute -- an act that gives you street cred, somehow? -- which understandably vary wildly in quality and character. If you find a particular article of clothing that you really like the look of then you can upgrade it with components, but at higher and higher amounts that quickly outstrip the cost of buying better equipment altogether. It's hard to find what Armor does or tell a meaningful difference, so maybe the point is moot anyhow. The key for "Reload" and "Pick up the weapon I'm looking at it" are the same, meaning no less than once every other fight does my mercenary decide in the middle of combat to trade their favorite shotgun for a revolver lying on the ground that he has absolutely no perks for. Annoying for sure, but insufferable when I have to go to my inventory and re-equip that shotgun every time. It could be worse; they could have had V drop it instead, a dangerous proposition when a gun can be plainly visible but unable to be picked up except from a specific position or angle, or until giving up on what amounts to just one more assault rifle to sell to the nearest food stand that also buys secondhand firearms.As for the story, Cyberpunk 2077's narrative has a inconsistency of tone only exacerbated by its structure. Depending on which jobs you take and in what order you complete them, events pivot at a moment's notice between comedy and tragedy, invoking unremarkable primetime TV action (which unresponsive naked woman will V carry today, the murder victim or the rape victim?), surface-level vignettes about life in Night City, and the rare glimpse of a science-fiction story that might live up to the genre invoked in Cyberpunk 2077's title if only it was explored. Every opportunity for a truly compelling interrogation of alienation, or identity, or the power of that odious machine that is not stopped but only further lubricated by the application of bodies to its gears and wheels, ends neither with a satisfying conclusion or introspection but an abrupt "pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up, huh?" before V recieves another phone call.You can't steer the course of any of these various stories short of simply not doing them, and characters that openly hate and distrust V in one segment will share a friendly beer or offer romance two jobs later, even if the player has made every attempt to make it clear they'd rather this person ♥♥♥♥ off. Story outcomes result in a single line of dialogue, or a slightly more annoyed text message. The most signficiant change I've experienced is that if V murders a character's friend, that character  ♥♥♥♥ V. Be warned!Johnny Silverhand, flatly, sucks. I'm sure Keanu Reeves is trying, and some of the more somber moments do allow him to pack some performance into a one-sentence rejoinder. However, Johnny's not an extremist, he's a contrarian, and the script certainly doesn't help. When V is serious, Johnny is irreverent. When Johnny tries to get real, it's V who cracks wise. Johnny's attempts to "get along" with V amount to blackmail, ultimatums, and repeated attempts to violate V's bodily autonomy. Early on, you're given medication to suppress Johnny and to . In 40 hours of play, I was only given the option to take these pills once, despite Johnny's unbearable presence and V's worsening condition. If I could have, V would have been popping them like candy.It's the kind of thing where you try to put yourself in the head of Cyberpunk 2077's decision-makers. There are cars in the game, but they're not customizable because that would mean more development. There's no store to buy these cars from, so they're sold to you via text message by your many fixers, presumably because they couldn't get the voice actors back into the booth last-minute. There are races in the game, for no better reason than that there are cars, with the races arranged by a bartender for some reason, but you'll never be outraced in the story no matter how slow your truck is. You can steal cars if you're strong enough to rip out the driver, but your car is summonable and fast-travel points are plentiful, so why? Because the game has crime and cars? Would it have been a disservice for V to have his or her one car? How many man-hours could have been saved, how much better of an experience would have been delivered in the end if only a few of these seemingly automatic inclusions and the ever-expanding checklist of ultimately needless features had been pruned? As the player you can barely control the pants V puts on in the morning or get V a haircut despite being able to buy new arms or a second heart, so an inability to choose between a compact or a van a seems inconsequential in comparison to that kind of rigidity.Johnny and V's situation is presented early on as a crossroads. Will Johnny change V, or will V change Johnny? The reality is that the latter never happens, and the former is presented as something that you the player should encourage and pursue. You'd think that an anti-establishment figure like Johnny would understand more than anyone that compromising your identity is just death of another kind.Cyberpunk 2077, with all its attempts to be anything but a game of its own -- it has shooting, it has RPG elements, it has open-world, it has wanted levels and hacking minigames and skill trees and origins and street races and item qualities and everything else you could ever want from a AAA game! -- should have learned that lesson, because the only thing Cyberpunk 2077  have is a good reason to play it.

author: nakkid goolies
review: really not impressed with this whatsoever. even the technical bugs like trees popping in sporadically aside, the gameplay is unbelievably clunky and the writing is both bland in concept and bland in delivery. i'm a huge stealth fan and went into this with that in mind, dumping the majority of my points in the sneaky stats. i then sit through what has to be, what, an hour of molasses pacing with nothing really happening? no, really, i picked the corporate tree and here's what your fun, fun first hour consists of: walk out of bathroom, walk down halls with little of interest, sit in elevator, walk down more halls, talk to my boss for ten minutes, get a fun sounding mission, don't go on the mission yet, sit in helicopter, fly for five minutes, go to bar, walk around bar, sit down, another ten minute conversation with another guy discussing the fun mission, other guys come over, they tell me i don't get to go on fun mission, i frown, my character's friend gets mad and makes it seem like something's about to happen, nothing happens, the guys go away, and then i'm treated to a big montage of my character doing things that i wouldn't want him to do, which is weird because this is an RPG, right? actually, that's the weirdest thing. why am i not getting any choices? whenever your main character is prompted to say something, the options both seem to offer the same sentiment--that is, if you get any options at all. sometimes, you just get a line that you're  to say along with the choice to get a bonus throwaway line. still gotta pick the forced dialogue in the end. and this really sucks, because my character keeps saying things that i really don't  him to say. it feels very fallout 4 all over again, and that pisses me off. compare this to deux ex's last two entries where the player is offered multiple dialogue options straight from the  that all have different intentions and, more importantly, give the player a 100% view of what the hell they're going to be saying.and speaking of which, it's that  that bothers me. the delivery of the lines are just terrible. your main protagonist, should you choose to be male, sounds like a dumb yokel, and this is particularly funny if you start your background in corporate. he's not hick or anything, but he sounds like he's down a few braincells--there's one line in particular when he mocks his friend for "not being nice" and he sounds like a damn child. there's an encounter with an asian police officer too featuring some real poor English and some even poorer interaction with the player's friend that's just eyerolling. while we're on that topic, there's a part where you get in the car and your friend starts driving, and this... just  beat starts playing and i could not have frowned harder. i went into the options to see what the radio key was--F, or R, or something--and i mashed the hell out of it. a fruitless endeavor. trapped in the trap.i said something about the writing, right? it's not really bad or anything--just boring and uninteresting. i won't go into this too much because it's unfair to just say something's bad and not elaborate, and i literally can't remember what any of the dialogue was. nothing memorable. also, any given scene just looks like a generic synthwave album cover. giving credit to deus ex again here, that game's developers saw the writing on the wall and were very forward thinking in their aesthetic compared to this, a vague idea of what cyberpunk looks like.anyway, i want to end this talking about the gameplay--specifically the stealth, since that's what i cared about going in, what i built my character around, what i brushed up on in the tutorial, and what i set out to do, clearing the entire first mission with no deaths.it sucks. here, i'm going to describe the process for you. i might mis-remember some exact keystrokes but the sentiment is the same: FIRST, you hit your crouch toggle key. oops, hold on, the crouch toggle key broke, so you have to go into the options, bind the toggle key to the other crouch, and then bind it back (you'll be doing this a lot, so get used to it). okay, what were we doing again? right, stealth. so, you crouch , your first hurdle accomplished, and then you see some enemies. NOW, you have to hit tab and go into batman vision mode. now, you highlight enemies and mark them (with a different key, of course). why are you doing this? why aren't you just going in and sneaking?because there's no. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. . in a game. with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. stealth.why is leaning important? because it allows you to take cover behind objects and peek to see where hostiles are and what they're doing. what's the alternative? you literally have no idea what direction someone's facing so you just bumble out from behind cover and get immediately spotted. therefore, your  solution is to have to highlight enemies so that doesn't happen. but then, this means you're having to spend the damn game constantly with these glow-in-the-dark villains, something that's a powerup or unlockable in games like dishonored or, again, deus ex. anyway, i'm getting off track, let's continue with the stealth process.so now you've successfully highlighted them, and now you're ready to hunt. you sneak up from behind someone and press F. now you have them in a vague chokehold? it doesn't really... look right. anyway, now you have to decide if you want to kill them or knock them out, so you press F again or whatever the key is. a weird animation plays where your character looks like he's grasping at air, and then, congrats, he's on the ground. NOW, you have to look at the body and hold R to carry it. okay, now we've got to bring it somewhere. you go to a hiding spot and you press--what? what do you press? oh. oh you know. E. and congrats, you've finally achieved your first stealth takedown. now, just to sum it up, let's go through all the steps one more time.you hit control, then you hit tab, then you hit your second mouse button, then you unhit tab, then you walk forward, then you press f, then you press f again, then you hold r, then you walk, then you press e.i want you to imagine an exasperated AVGN face right now because i keep bringing up deus ex but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, in that game you just hold q, they're automatically being dragged, and then you let go and continue on. no need to highlight enemies either because the game goes in third person when you take cover. or hell, if you don't want that, dishonored lets you, in first person, you guessed it: LEAN. YOU CAN LEAN. i don't really know where the story goes from here, and i don't know how the other backgrounds start, and i don't know how much more fun it is to play the game like an action hero--but i don't care. this was enough. now, i'll probably be back after a year or two of patches and updates, but for sixty dollars? you could do a lot, lot,  better.[EDIT: apparently you can lean! you have to specifically have a weapon out and then attempt to aim it while at a corner. seeing as i was playing as a stealth pacifist, i saw no reason to have a gun out at all. that's a good thing! there is definitely still way too many buttons for what should be a simple action. but this definitely makes this more playable, now. i'll update these first impressions with a fuller look if i continue on][EDIT 2: yeah it still sucks. play deus ex]

author: s0laris
review: I bought it this week based on recommendation of a couple friends.Should have stopped at 120 minutes and refund it. Its a mess. The AI is non existent. TONS of visual bugs. Driving is a mess. NPCs ignoring obstacles and just walk through stuff, including walls. Joke level stealth system. Random conversation with NPCs make no sense. Teleporting cops. Inventory management and the items are a mess. The conversation options do not matter. The shooting part is a hit and miss, depends on you if you like sponge shooters or not. The melee system is a joke.To say some good:The game, when works, looks fantastic, assuming you want to overlook the 40-50 FPS on max graphix in 1440p on a 3 grand euro PC. The story is good. Some elements like the diving of recorded memories is nice, definitely an upgrade from its predecessor in Remember Me. The voice acting of the main cast averaged from mediocre to really good. The characters are also distinct enough in personality that i do not forget who is who. V's voice changing based on what is happening was a pleasant surprise, when his life is threatened, you can hear it in his voice (only played male, dont know about female V).If you want to buy the game only for the story, go for it. However, if you are looking for its open world aspect, dont. Its an empty world that requires like a year more of fixes and additions. If you want a cyberpunk game that doesnt want to be everything at the same time and failing badly at it, go for DeusEx Human Revolution or Remember Me.

author: bjerk
review: I will never find a person who will love me like Panam. Today I will live with the reality of it :(

author: Saibot
review: Now, after 72.7 hours of play I can say that if you strip the game of the fancy looks etc, it is just a basic unoptimized, totally unbalanced, pretty looter-shooter at this stage. One might ask why would I complain if I sank 72.7 hours into this, and why would it not worth the full price? Answer is simple: I do not weight my enjoyment based on Hours played. I mean I can happily waste my time on youtube/facebook etc for hours, so playtime is not a good argument for the price of the game, sorry. 10€ for a movie in the cinema might be worth it, while a game I've paid 1€ per hour is not. Overall enjoyment is individual.The bottom line is that CDPR should have waited for another year at least to release this, but they were greedy, so shame on them big time !! They also shouldn't have created such high expectations with over promising on features. It is good that they were ambitious, but should have done reality checks waaaay more often, and sync with / slap their PR/marketing folks. Especially the "Gameplay trailers" and "footages" where you see 80% of things you can't do ingame. The big customization for your character? yea you got 3 types of genitals - Penis 1, penis 2 and Vagina 1. I've seen better Customization in way older games.The signs are everywhere: some elements of the game are brilliant, and finished, like car interiors, most details in the buildings of Night City.Most are half-baked, like the combat mechanics (all combat, but brawling is the worst), weapon usage and stats, merchants and stores (very simple), hacking, even the character creation at the start.. It is not an RPG, no consequences, no intricate changes to the story based on character decisions, nothing.Some are downright a disgrace: the economy and trading in the game, including ripperdocs, the crafting system, police AI and AI in general for that matter. Many praise the graphics, but if you look in the details, there are issues there too: just check the shadow of your player character: shoulders are detached (wtf?), cars in the distance are a joke (just jpgs moving on a canvas), and were put there in the last moment to save on computer resources apparently. Don't get me started on the bugs which are totally immersion breaking - and there are a lot, I mean a lot.. trees are glitching, characters / cars respawn from mid-air and break/blow up (wtf?), V dies while walking, characters/weapons are sunk into the ground frequently, many times you cannot even pick them up, and the list just goes on and on..No, this game was far from ready to be released. None of the versions, including the PC, which CDPR is "proud of": they shouldn't be in this state. They should be ashamed that they gave in, and released it like this. I don't think they comprehend and anticipate how much they lost on the long term. And for what? They should have invested more on investor relations and manage the expectations there, rather than pouring millions to promoting the game.This game could have been a brilliant masterpiece, but would have needed years more of development. If they promised less features, they would have been able to deliver a relatively polished version in 2021. But of course they should have fired everyone who did the PR and marketing for them first: those guys are completely detached from reality in terms of what is possible in 2020 in game design and creation.Cut Content & 2018 Demo comparison. Several elements that were promised in pre-production were cut in the final release. Things like 3rd person cut scenes, metro rides, wall climbing, corrupt cops. I also think the 2018 demo version looked much better, not as overly bright, HUD of cars, character models in general. The downgrading of the graphics is not on an epic (negative) scale as in WITCHER 3, but still noticeable. Several storylines feel cut as well. It seems the entire wanted system was implemented 5 minutes before the game was rushed out the door and it is very apparent that they thought "well, it's better than nothing?!"Finally, while we are on the "waste of space" topic... I don't get how the game critics gave 100% and 10/10 for this - the game review industry is clearly broken, and shouldn't be trusted.

author: BrunoXmega
review: Amazing game so far!Now I just need a new PC to play it in Ultra. :DUPDATE:Just finished the main story of the game.While Cyberpunk 2077 is certainly a flawed title which could have benefited from more development time, the game is still worth playing - as long as people play it on the right platform... That's plenty of reason for some players to be cautious, but the game is still 100% worth playing - at least, the PC version is.Is a great game with huge focus on story, characters and world building. I dont remember last time when the rpg story absorbed me so much, besides, ofcourse, The Witcher 3. Yes there are few bugs here are there, but nothing gamebreaking. Usually minor visual glitches. If you like story RPGs this is simply a perfect game for you. If the small bugs bother you too much, then this will be a game for you after few updates.Even with all those "bugs", for me this game still a 10/10.I TOTALLY RECOMMEND!

author: ANTHEM
review: Pros: - The map and scenery looks really cool- Photo mode is really fun- Melee feels satisfying and viable- Main story seems interestingCons:- Optimisation is awful, nowhere near the recommended/suggest specs that CDPR officially announced. (I'm using GTX1080 and it's really not a smooth first-person experience)- Very little life in the city, little to no interaction with the city or environment- AI is awful, super poorly scripted reactions (from regular NPCs and Police)- Not much side/fun stuff to do- Lot of cut content that was initially shown off and talked about during the development. - The game seems clearly rushed and needed at least another year or so to polish all of the features.Currently the game feels like a 7/10 for me, decent but just too many issues/drawbacks for me to recommend it anyone really - especially if you don't have a really good PC (at least an RTX2060 or above). Maybe in the next few months when we see performance improvements, and maybe in the next year or so if we get more implementations of features, then I'll change my mind about it. In the current state, I don't really recommend this game.

author: The Dogfather
review: What can there be said about the disaster of a release that was CDPR's hotly anticipated follow up to one of the best games of the last generation, , that hasn't already been said and then regurgitated ad infinium on various sites and message boards the internet over. I initially had a joke review in the review section for this game (which I am replacing with this one) because at the time of posting that review,  had become one giant meme - not a place I would have expected one of the most hotly anticipated and most talked about games in generations to land. I know CDPR has been tolling away hard at work trying to deliver on the game they promised but the reality is that  destroyed a lot of trust and goodwill the company had built up over the years with its followers and fellow gamer's and I for one will forever look at them with the eyes of a sceptic. A lot of 's problems stem from its core.  is technically not much of an RPG at all (which is disappointing given the table top source material), but more of an action FPS with light RPG elements. Many of its interconnected systems either fail to make an impression or simply don't work (point in case I couldn't use a single replenishable item in my inventory for my entire playthrough which begged the question why was I even bothering collecting all that sh*t).At least on the PC it ran pretty well and while not quite as cutting edge as many believed it would look in the graphics department, if taken as a whole it could look impressive at times. I did find the main story line gripping and most of the side quests were pretty enjoyable to complete when I had convinced myself I was playing an action FPS and not an RPG at all. I did feel like the end of the game was incredibly rushed, as this was where I acutely felt that the team had simply run out of time and couldn't deliver on the ending they had originally planned, especially after the boilerplate missions that ratchet up the tension before entering into the final mission. The end felt almost anti-climatic because it was over in such a jiffy.  The final boss felt like a joke, given that we had been built up to fear him and he ended up being a complete pushover.At the time of play I did initially find all the various graphical glitches quite hilarious but in the end it did start to subtract from my experience. I can't speak for the game now (October 2021), as it would require a replay, but hopefully most of those have been sorted out by now. Whoever decided that crouch and skip scene should be mapped to the same button really didn't play test the game properly because they would have immediately seen how annoying this is when you accidentally press the "B"  button on the controller thinking you are gonna stand up and then end up skipping a cut scene. The traffic system and A.I (Police, NPC, Enemy ) needed some serious attention, hopefully that has also been addressed now. Also  open world didn't quite revolutionise the genre in the same way  had done prior. That was disappointing.If you temper your expectations,  can be an awesome thrill and there are genuine moments where you can see the brilliant game waiting to be unearthed lying underneath its mess of systems and visual bugs and glitches. The sad thing is with probably another two years development, CDPR would have had the classic game everyone and his dog thought they were delivering because the puzzle pieces are all there, they just needed to be joined correctly. I do believe it could have been that genre defining game that all other games aspire to be like had it been given more time in development so it was sad to see how it got kicked out the door in such a poor state. Most people would have been fine with further delays (well at least the adults among us who I like to think outweigh the emotionally stunted death threat script kiddies living in Mom's basement),  because we have jobs, families, other hobbies that also keep us busy we don't have time to tweet sh*t. I get that there are investors, and that they want results and they want to see their investment materialise, but the 8 million pre-orders should have been enough of a sign that demand was incredibly high for this title. Sure some might have cancelled their pre-orders off another possible longer delay but excellent reviews across all platforms would have driven them all back. One has to ask, was this all really worth it? As Miyamoto put it "a rushed game is forever bad, a delayed one is eventually good". Those should be words you live by in this industry. In the end, while I thoroughly enjoyed my time with , the fact of the matter is given the hype and the marketing campaign I fully well expected  to come in as my favourite game of 2021 but sadly that has not been the case. In fact, come year end,  it might not feature in my top 10 games played for 2021 at all.  I can't help feeling a pang of disappointment about this, especially given that  ended at #1 back in 2015.

author: mrbalaclava
review: I'm so disappointed. It's a really mediocre game, with a generally interesting main story and some of the side missions are okay, but none of the hundreds of mini-distractions really have any meaning or impact in the lifeless city. The shooting is crap, the melee is much worse than Skyrim, and the arbitrary stealth system isn't satisfying either, especially when entering sudden hostile areas with no warning whatsoever. It'd be nice to highlight these areas on the minimap or something.Driving is absolutely joyless, and it takes forever to get anywhere - even at an indicated 150mph, the metres on the HUD creep by with depressing lethargy.There are lots of immersion-breaking glitches, and the ending of the main story makes no sense whatsoever - it feels like there is so much left unexplained.It's hard to care for any of the characters, as most of the time I have no idea who on earth they are. They are catapulted into the story with little or no introduction, and then disappear equally quickly. The supposed nemesis Adam Smasher is an absolute bit part at best, and yet we're supposed to have some kind of internal monologue to decide his fate... I couldn't care less!I wouldn't recommend this game I'm afraid - it could have been really good, but it's bland and fairly soulless. The mechanics are most to blame for this, but the character exposition is also pretty naff.

author: KiXSTAR
review: I'm going to wait until the game is REALLY done.You should too.

author: amvince
review: , from the infamous Tpose npc, Stealth bug, Flying items, but for me all of those bugs doesnt really matter bcs  fragmented long stories, mesmerizing graphics of the Night City, and intensity of the gameplay combat wise and non combat. P.S: They keep updating the fix on the bugs though, I noticed some bugs are gone already.

author: stevensen
review: Damn it! It's now August 2021 and the game is still filled with bugs up to the rim. After completing the story shortely after release, I quit the game and reloaded it just now to see how well they improved it. But dang! Not a single session without bugs. In mid game suddenly my sniper rifel is unable to shoot, ammo still at max.. Quiting to menu and reloading fixes the problem. Pistols disappear suddenly, running around with empty hands and shooting  just looks stupid. Don't  even bother that you cannot pick up things while you should be able to do so. The critics on this game are really justified.

author: ¡ardito!
review: After 70~ hours of a nomadic playthrough, I know that I want more! Never been so amazed in my whole life, I was blown away by the graphics, the story, the complex city. Yes the game needs polishing, but I never enjoyed a game that much.. Really really looking forward to the patches, mods and what the future of this game will look like. Cyberpunk 2077, my game of the year and of my whole life.

author: Dasaleet
review: Annoyed with the positive reviews without substance or trying to be funny skewing the numbers.Very disappointed with the game, not ready for release. Clearly rushed for Christmas as its far from finished. Trees clipping through a third of the screen making it impossible to see anything. Many restarts, many graphic changes. nothing fixes.Its like one of those games in Alpha, but for 50 QUID!

author: applo
review: The lack of patches and 0 responses from the Dev team makes me wonder if they took the money and abandoned this game. They still haven't released the "February Patch" we were promised, including the free DLCs.This game is a wasted potential. With all the performance issues and bugs everywhere, it did not deserve the hype it got before the release.

author: Jack of Games
review: My first interaction with CD Projekt RED game was around 2008. Some random guy told me about The Witcher and i tried it. I loved the game even with poor and strange combat system. Usually i try to play games with original voices/language, because translations are often inaccurate, voices are too artificial and you'll miss some jokes. CDPR games on the other hand are good with full translation and i personally enjoy them that way.Since then i became kind of fan of CDPR games and was waiting for Witcher 2. I loved new models, improved combat and few more features, but the game was too linear in terms of map. Optimization wasn't good, as far as i remember. Then came waiting times for Witcher 3.Witcher 3 trailers were interesting. Final product wasn't disappointing. Open world for the first time. Horse. Good amount of main story time and decent side quests. I can tell much, but in short, it was a good game. DLC introduced few hour content and second DLC was one big expansion. You know, old classic expansion with many missions, weapons, etc. It had a new map! After waiting for Cyberpunk for years, after watching more trailers and getting more "hype" and after many delayed release dates, we finally received the game...It wasn't the company i loved anymore. I heard few things since then. It looks like some developers left the company and it was a case of negative experience not just for players, but for employees too. It was the start of the fall. I bought the game and played for the first time recently. December of 2021. Winter sale. By now the game should have been patched, fixed, improved and so on. If this is the case, the may the tech gods have mercy on CDPR souls. I completed the game, finished most (probably all) side story quest, had tons of Legendary stuff etc. Story side was good enough. Character models are good too. You may ask, what was so bad about it? What makes me not recommend the game to people? I will tell you, boy. After years of mentioned delayed release dates, the game not only was released in a terrible state (beta-like), but it's an average game in some aspects and horrible in others. I will tell you more.Game has poor optimization. I'm not talking about just performance (which according to some players with better PC/GPU than mine is still problematic. I do have good PC, other than GPU and have good performance in most games). Audio volume is sometimes low and sometimes high. I almost can't hear the radio songs, but i hear the damn engine. Your audio software settings/presets don't matter here. I have gaming mobo and use slightly modified gaming audio prest in SS3. It works in all other games, so it's a game related audio problem. There are more reasons to have negative opinion of the game. NPC/transport appear and disappear  out of nowhere sometimes. I had to waste a lot of time near city dump, because my car stuck and all the cars on the road disappeared, and there was no fast travel thing nearby.Poor world load after you return to the game from menus. A lot of objects can get stuck in other objects. You can't pick some loot at all!Driving physics is terrible. I played many racing games and this is terrible even for non-racing game standard. GTA 5, game from 2013 with very "Arcadey" physics feels amazing after Cyberpunk. Here it feels as if indie developer tested physics. Don't get me wrong, CP physics is not just "meh". It's really, really bad. Speaking of physics. Other physics related things are bad too. There is a funny comparison video on Youtube, where author compared Cyberpunk with other games. CP looked like an cheap indie game made in garage. Shooting at water takes me back to PS2 times.You can't customize protagonist after start. For Arasaka's sake, why the cyberhell you can't change even the simplest things like hair? Eyes in this game are impants, so why not change them too? Tattoos, cyber stuff, piercing... I mean, even in modern times we can change faces. In Cyberpunk we should be able to change almost everything. Arm implants look generic. Thanks to modder, this can be improved a bit. Where is other models? Where is visible leg implants model?Armor choice in this game is poor. You can look like Sci-fi clown with good stats or have poor stats and look better. Too many Iconic weapons. Most skill categories are poorly balanced. Stealth is good even without proper skills. Some other categories can be also ignored. Some impants require high levels in mentioned skill categories. You have to waste points on poor skills to buy some decent implants.Some implants require high Street Cred levels. Legendary arms, for example. Other than that Street Cred thing was useless for me. I had to grind just to buy the damn arms.Too many consumable items and no proper way to use them. It becomes a hassle.You can't continue playing after game ending. Load save before final mission or return to menu. Witcher 3 changed this. Why return to the old formula? AI is dumb. Police appears out of nowhere and won't chase you at all. NPC reaction on danger is very poorly executed in the game.Upgrade option for some of my weapons just disappeared at one point, for no reason. I was left with cool but weak gun. It's a bug!I hope that i haven't forgot anything.Can't pick loot Empty road/cars disappearedBike acted weird (jumped in air) and got stuckObject (loot) stuck in another object Lightning bugIf CDPR won't fix the damn bugs, improve optimization i mentioned above and at least change few things, like allow us to change character appearance and free roam after ending, then i have no more hope for this company. Expansion, for potentially fixed game, can be a good sign too. Fixes first, of course. If you want to play for CDPR style story, then buy with the biggest discount you can and be prepared for bugs.: I mentioned few other problems, updated text and added some screenshots.
