author: Duthy
review: They put too much effort into creating a massive and visually stunning world but didn't focus on the depth of the world. This is essentially a crap version of GTA. Everything just feels so superficial. Can't sit on seats or order a drink or engage in any activities outside of quests. No car customisation or apartment customisation options. The only way to interact with the game is through the superficial quests. As a result the game lacks depth, crap customisation options and poor immersion. I don't know if they can fix all this in the dlc's. I'll check back on the game in like 2 years or so ... maybe that's enough time but not getting my hopes up again.

author: czMarv
review: So hard for me to stay focused on the storyline, almost 2 hours playing and i still don't understand single thing. You meet someone, then someone else calling you, then u meet another person, everyone keep talking at you stuff you don't even understand. You need to do this and then you need to do that and it feels like it's not even connected or giving any sense. Maybe it's because i played only for 2 hours, but still. I just simply missing the "wow" moment.Enough chit chat, here are my reasons!- Gunplay is hard and not fun because the game is not smooth (feels like 0.2 second delay on mouse input)- My pc is not that trashy but sometimes it drops almost below 60 fps- Feels like you don't have much options > just go how the game wants you to go (but yeah, 2 hours)- Problems that people have in this world feels so edgy and childish (you got problem? let's kill each other)- I was yawning, not wowing- I don't like reading books but this game thinks that i do- Where is the freedom and options? Do i need to play like 5 hours to finally enjoy the game?Oh man, it seems that i am kinda mad... I am not, i am just feeling sorry for myself that i ate the hype again...My opinion, if you are enjoying the game, don't even think of giving a single f*ck about this review.

author: DeadBabyJuggler
review: All I wanted from this game was a modern competitor to Deus Ex. This isn't exactly it but you can absolutely see the inspiration and I am incredibly happy with it so far. Contrast to many peoples experience I've had barely any bugs. Your mileage my vary. Fantastic game.

author: Kazzy | Team K4L
review: Okay so I'm one of those people that jumped into the game with no expectations and not as a ''fan'' and to be quite honest, I'm glad I was one of those people. Overhyped games tend to kill my vibe (TLOU2 for example and I waited for that for 8 years, the same amount of time people have been waiting for this) but that's besides the point. Time to edit the review since I ended up finishing the game and pouring 60+ hours of gametime into it. Let me just be clear and say the overhype that this game received was 100% not worth it at all. It's a really good game, yes but was it worth it to send death threats to the developers due to it being delayed 3 times? Most definitely not. The story, the graphics, the way the characters were written and the photo mode are the highlights of the game for me. The city itself looks beautiful that's for sure and it's pleasant for the eyes (especially when you have a high end PC and running everything on RT Ultra) but the things that of course let me down were the bugs and the glitches. Not to mention on top of that, the lies and misleading promises from CDPR about the content which was initially going to be in the game pretty much not ending up in there at all. The customisation is bland. You can only use the character customisation ONCE throughout your ENTIRE playthrough and that's right at the very beginning when you choose your life path, that's it. What happened to the wall-running that was being spoken about and the way you could alter the way your character looks throughout the game and not to forget the vehicle customisation which was teased when spoken about? None of this was added in the game at all. I wanted to see plastic surgeons, barber shops and even tattoo parlours so I can change how my character looks yet I wasn't able to apart from changing clothes from my inventory. The combat is okay, not the best I've seen and not the worst. It's alright for me but the thing that bugs me the most is how I can't use guns when in cars or riding bikes. I can't even use gun poses when I'm on a bike during photo mode, in fact, I can't even use ANY poses when I'm on a bike AT ALL during photo mode. I'm kinda glad I didn't buy into all the hype and insanity people across the globe put into the game because if I did I would have been left with a sour taste in my mouth but negatives to the side my overall experience with the game was a good one, not the best. This isn't GOTY material and it certainly isn't a gods creation as how many hardcore fans perceived the game to be. It was a fun, enjoyable game but with bugs and glitches which definitely need patching. I simply cannot recommend the game to anyone yet until it's in a decent, playable state. Once everything is patched I'll end up changing my review to a positive one since Steam doesn't have a ''Neutral'' button.

author: Terminus044
review: EA: Single player games are dead.Cyberpunk crossing the player base of CSGO on steam :)

author: Tumas Altaawus
review: Less of a review more of a warning.Regardless of the 9s and 10s, this game is far from worth it. As well as the Steam reviews of people with a handful of hours praising it to be one of the best games of all time.Suffers with massive performance issues. Graphics were clearly downgraded and are on par with the console versions, even at ultra. Yet you will struggle to maintain 40FPS on medium, even with higher end cards.Vegetation is terribly done. Grass and small plants are static. Small trees and bushes are made entirely of light, and pass through Geralt with ease.Game has many bugs and AI issues too.It's clear not much effort was put into the game performance and visual-wise. Lack of optimisation makes the game far from worth the $60 asking price.Developers lied about exploration too. Remember when they said "If you see it, you can go there"? Well... You can't. "No invisible walls" ring a bell? False too. Whilst they're not invisible walls, if you stray too far from the enclosed map, you get a warning that you've "reach the world's end" and must "turn back". If you fail to turn back, the map opens up and you must fast travel somewhere.Do not trust CDPR. People always went on about Valve being for the gamer, and yet they aren't. The case is the same with CDPR.Finally, to put things into perspective:My rig:r5 3600GTX 1080ti 16 gigs of RAM, and all the rest.I get 40 FPS at most with plenty of drops running on medium at 1440p. The game looks like something from 2013.Disgusting.

author: Ken Xyro
review: Spoiler free review• StoryI felt the story was short by CDPR's standard but it was definitely not short when you compare it to other AAA games. I did a fair amount of side quests before progressing to the main story and I finished the game at 60 hour mark. I still have tons of side quests remaining, if I did them all then the game is probably 100-150 hours long, but the main story itself can be "rushed" in about 15-20 hours. Doing it in 60 hours didn't feel like a grind and it was pretty intertwined - doing side quests opens up opportunities for completely different endings and I'm not talking about Witcher 3 levels where you simply get more help in your final battle doing side quests, but I'm talking completely different scenarios playing out depending on which side quests you have completed. I think it is worth mentioning that according to Steam stats, 70% players never even found Ciri in Witcher 3, so 70% of the players never finished the main story. I think the number for that will be much higher for Cyberpunk.• Gameplay+I'm really loving the gameplay, it's probably my favourite part of the game. All different guns feel unique, weapon animations are done extremely well and cyberwares add another layer to the gameplay. I definitely prefer guns + Projectile Launcher cyberware combo but I also have fun running around and chopping up enemies with Mantis Blades too. Gun mods exist and they're pretty fun to play around with too. Whether it is to add different scopes or adding a silencer in a gun to increase its headshot damage from stealth, it's fun to mod guns differently according to different play style.• Driving-I find driving in the game very annoying, specially with cars. If you're driving freely out in badlands, I believe there are no issues, but when you're driving in the city or following the map GPS, that's when issues start to pop up. This makes me believe it's not the actual driving that's the culprit here but something else - one specific thing I could note was that the minimap is too zoomed in so if you're following the GPS, you're not able to slow down or plan a turn before it's too late which leads you to either crash or take a very sharp turn using handbrakes. Sadly due to this reason I almost never drive cars in the game, I only use the Yaiba Kusanagi bike which can get through traffic really easily and also turns sharp corners very quickly causing me very few troubles.-The first person camera in car is absolutely horrid. I can't see a damn thing and am pretty much forced to use 3rd person which sucks because I would love to look at the cool interiors of the car while driving.+Bikes drive very differently from cars and are much better. You're pretty much forced to use bikes if you wanna avoid headache that comes with cars.• Open-world-Believe it or not, in terms of open world design Cyberpunk is a step back from The Witcher 3. I'm not talking about the design of Night City but rather how quests, stories and activities are laid out in Night City. In The Witcher 3, you could at times even complete quests before ever accepting them from the quest giver. If you decided you just wanna explore, you could find certain characters who you're supposed to find in particular quests. Later when you talk to the quest giver, they respond accordingly and thank you for finding or helping the characters earlier. This is amazing, this type of open world design is unbeatable. In comparison, Cyberpunk features rather linear quests in it's open-world, in a way similar to Rockstar does with it's games. Cyberpunk and games from Rockstar follow the same pattern: Quest giver -> Task -> Task CompleteWhile in Witcher 3 you can go from:Task -> Task Complete -> Quest giveror even:Task -> Task failed -> Quest giver -> Different outcome• Open-world map+Now, lets talk about Night City itself. Right off the bat I'll say that the design of Night City itself is the most impressive game world map you'll ever see. Nothing else comes even close to what CDPR has done with Night City. The layers of exploration in buildings is insane to the point you'll probably have to rely on your memory rather than the map while exploring buildings. My friend has 50 hours in the game and he was surprised when I showed him a portion of V's building he hadn't seen before. This is the very building at the start of the game and 50 hours in he still missed a good chunk of its backside.-The game offers very few incentives to actually go through this type of exploration. As I said earlier, the quests in the game are quite linear so while exploring is fun by itself, the rewards for doing it are very few.-Though Night City itself is impressive and unmatched, it kinda falls flat on street level due to very basic AI of NPCs and the minimum attention to detail that is given to these NPCs. They say a very generic answer if you try to them, don't respond naturally, do weird things at times and just feel out of place. They're background noise during your gameplay which makes Night City on street level feel very dead.• Character+A huge plus for the game is the cast of its characters. They feel authentic and respond in a very human level. Some characters like Judy show very human emotions and it's a treat to watch. These are the types of character whose quests you would wanna do before progressing the main story. And after you've done their quests, you'll miss these characters and their stories. That's a testament to how well written these characters are.• ReplayabilityGame definitely has some level of replayability. I can already see certain scenes going differently depending on my lifepath but apart from that there's also different choices and consequences. How deep these go remains to be seen, I'll probably need to spend another 100 hours in the game before I can answer that truthfully.• Performancei7 4770, 8GB ddr3 RAM. GTX 1070Running the game at medium-high, 1080p at 50-60 fps.It's not terrible but could be better with optimizations• Bugs and glitchesThroughout my 70+ hour playthrough my game didn't crash to desktop even once. The glitches experienced during gameplay were funny rather than being annoying. Maybe I've just been lucky, but personally I didn't face any bugs or glitches which ruined my gaming experience. At most I just laughed looking at a glitch and moved on with my game the very next second.• ConclusionSpending 70+ hours with this game only made me feel hungry for more. Game needs fixes like the dumb AI and what not, but I find myself wanting to spend more and more time in Night City.

author: Epi
review: The game is, in a word, gorgeous. However, there're some bug and I want more ending lol  Spoiler alert!========================================================================As far as we can tell so far, the endings in Cyberpunk 2077 have a few different paths. 1. Side with Hanako: take up Hanako on her offer2. Get Rogue’s Help: let Johnny take over your body and go to Rogue for help3. Call the Aldecaldos: if you’ve completed their side quest, get the help of the Aldecaldos Nomads4. Refuse: give in, and end things on your own terms5. Secret Ending: take Johnny up on his hidden offermore ending else? :(

author: 💕𝓢𝓱𝓪𝓭𝓸𝔀🐾
review: First off, I just want to say that I bought this game without ridding the hype train that so many did. I only found this game during the 2021 Fall Sale, so my expectations weren't set all that high. I watched several YT Vids, and looked at a few reviews that didn't sound like some self-entitled individual.I looked at the forum, and found many of those self-entitled there too, wrecking any positive feedback from those that just simply enjoy the game. So I took my leave from that toxic place, and read some more objective reviews However, watching the YT Vids was really the clincher for me. I saw this lady that showed off each starting scenario up to, and including the Training Tutorial. I was sold on the game right there.So I bought it, and did those early game missions as she did to see just how everything worked. I was not disappointed. Remembering some quick key commands to do this or that, was my only challenge. Driving was a challenge too, but that can be fixed by one of 3 Mods I saw on the Nexus that doesn't make driving so sensitive, as if you were driving on ice.. I think the hardest decision in this game is figuring out where you want to start. A Nomad, a Street Kid, or a Corpo. Then what path you want to follow. A Stealthy Hacker or Assassin. A Mercenary, with guns blazing, or a Tank, to bulldoze your way around. Maybe a little bit of everything?The Graphics, Soundtracks & Sound Effects, are far better than I expected. Character Creation, is extremely diverse, and Voice-overs are spot on. Plenty of missions, and story to follow. It's been a while since I found a game that gripped me like this. Mass Effect 1, 2 & 3 were the last games that had this kind of effect on me.As for us shutterbugs... I think the Photo Mode the game offers will give NVidia's ANSEL, a run for the money. There's countless expressions, poses, and views to make you just snap that shutter everywhere., Give it a try for a couple of hours, and see if you like it. If not, well you know what to do.𝓐𝓼 𝓐𝓵𝔀𝓪𝔂𝓼,𝓚𝓮𝓮𝓹 𝓞𝓷 𝓖𝓪𝓶𝓲𝓷𝓰! 🐱👍

author: gwiyeoun
review: For the first half of the game I was at 45 hours. Reason why it took me long was because I was doing side quests and I listened through all the dialogue of the main storyline. By last night at approximately 3:30 am, I finished the game with 117.7 hours. I kind of finished all the gigs and side quests, but some were still left out. I finished Judy's, Panam's, and River's storyline as well. I only did one quest for Kerry's storyline, but will go back to finish it today. I would say that a person can finish the main storyline without any sidequests, gigs, and romance's storyline(s) in about 45-50 hours. I still enjoyed this game a lot even with the few minor bugs that I encountered. I played this game on high settings with the average 60-69 fps. The graphics were beautiful. The storyline was intriguing and having Keanu Reeves butt in to comment stupid ♥♥♥♥ sometimes has made my experience in the game more enjoyable. For combat play, I love the aspect of quickhacking. I didn't have the full build for quickhacking yet, but it was still fun to kill enemies from afar with the Short Circuit and Synapse Burnout ability. I heard that the Ninja (melee) build is quite fun too so I will do that in my next playthrough. I focused more on handguns and assault rifles throughout the entire game and it's quite satisfying to get headshots on the enemies with almost one hit. If there was anything I would change in this game, it would be to pick the personality of my V. I feel that this game would be more complex and people would enjoy to make certain decisions if their character's head wasn't coming out of their ass at times or just plain sympathetic or nice. The hype for this game was real and it was very unfortunate that it was delayed because of the pandemic. Besides this point, this game has lived up to it's expectations. I recommend this game and I applaud CD Projekt Red for a job well done. 10/10

author: S7RIX
review: After 100+ hours the only conclusion I have to come to is that this is a game that I really like, but I wish I could love it.  At the current state it is disappointing to see a company like CDPR falling short in so many things not just the game.  It was never going to meet the lofty standards and hype people put on it but still it is sad to see it be riddled with bugs and glitches and an overall incomplete state.  I wait for the time when it shapes up to be the game the Devs wanted it to be.Is it fun? Absolutely. Even with the problems and glitches it was incredibly fun. Whether it is bashing enemies' heads open with a Dildo or making them fight each other while they cough to death or just good old fashioned shooting , there are a lot of ways to rain misery upon your enemies and a skill tree for refining each style . There are tons of tiny little things to find across the world that made me smile throughout the journey and made me realise how much love went into these little things. Small stories ,texts , props, enemies trying to patch things up with their girlfriends, the list goes on.STORY was the thing that I loved the most. It was short,sweet and impactful . I wish it was a bit longer giving and bit more flushed out background and important role to things like Militech (They freaking defeated Arasaka in one of the Corpo-wars and now they account to so little to the things happening to our story)  It felt like lot things were scrapped out of the game to fit within the schedule.Graphics and Soundtrack are incredible , The Night City is beautiful and when you take the time to pause and look and listen around the neon lit city, there is so much to love and take in. RPG, while it isn't anything groundbreaking, it  is something that was fun until I realised that there is a bug that can corrupt my saves if it goes over 8mb (My saves are still at around 5.9mb with everything completed) ,that is a shame as I was collecting every single thing I found around and scrapped stuff to craft new weapons or just for the heck of it . This needs to be fixed, there is no excuse for it to be a thing , this is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ RPG (This has been fixed as of update 1.06)If you were overhyped by all the media articles, trailers you may get disappointed at what you get but if you are like me and tempered your expectations there is a fantastic game underneath the glitches and bugs, And while bashing CDPR is the cool new thing to do for some , I definitely have faith in their ability to come back from this make this the game that was promised.

author: Neeno
review: It has the vibe of obviously Watch Dogs also Sleeping dogs and of course Grand Theft Auto, but it tops them all in terms of immersion to story and side activities, I've recently noticed for the past few years that most open world AAA games, usually has this repetitive feel of side quests or activities all over the map to makes you play longer and tease the completionist in you, which becomes a chore after a while and a bit tedious, but with Cyberpunk 2077, i noticed that every single side mission or activity has its own back story which makes it fun same as doing main missions, graphics are good but i expected something more of it to exceed what is currently in the market, i hoped that you can switch from first to third person view but it isn't there and to customize controls more freely but as we know it is a CDProjekt game so mods will come and do that for the matter. Also ray tracing enabled has a heavy toll on performance even with high end PC, so it needs a bit of tweaking stillSo in my book i would give it 8/10  Pros. : Story is amazing you will feel attached to the characters very wellYou won't feel you are wasting your time doing side activities or exploring in general as it doesn't has that repetitive feel at all.Free to do any part of the game your way your play style so it is near the definition of true sand box.Cons. : Not able to switch between First person to Third person view (I want to see how my character looks like after i got him new outfit).Controls Needs to be more customizable.Ray Tracing needs tweaking (not sure if its nVidia or CDPR fault on this.)

author: Mordefire
review: Cyberpunk is an immersive open world game. Engaging story, interesting characters, plenty of play styles available. The gameplay feels very smooth. The "cutscenes" don't lock your characters in place, neither do dialogues. You will very rarely see the loading screen, they appear upon death and fast travel. The side quests feel just as fun as the main storyline. I also encountered no crashes, and 2 bugs. (npc walked and vanished, npc walked through the elevator doors). Despite having medium settings i felt like the game looked really good too.

author: midori
review: Ehh, so far so good honestly. I've run into 2 bugs that aren't that bad. And performance in the city is kind of brutal. But still playable. I'm sure they'll patch it and fix performance a bit more. Fun game, fun open world. Lots of ways to do stuff. It could be much worse.

author: Torch
review: This game could be bug free and it would still be just alright. It is nothing beyond another basic open world game. 6/10.

author: HenryDavis1900
review: Very sexy women

author: Olberic Eisenberg
review: after playing this game for hours , i tried to open my door with my eyes.

author: Bustock!
review: Wake the f*ck up, Samurai. We have a city to burn.

author: Regilkent
review: Fun fact:Cyberpunk2077 is based on Mike Pondsmith's Cyberpunk franchise and one of the games in that franchise is called Cyberpunk2020 and it’s a classic game. Cyberpunk2077 is released in the year 2020; this game is going to be a classic game in the year 2077.Review:This game may still have some bugs in it, but that’s just normal for games that have just been released, I’m sure that the bugs will be fixed soon, so you guys should definitely give this game a chance and try it out; whether it be today, tomorrow, or even next year. I’m pretty sure that this game will be worth your time ツ

author: Dani
review: Overly hyped. Fails to deliver.After several delays it still is released with a plethora of bugs that even the day 0 patch did not address.Poorly optimized and just overall poor performance with huge demands for what it delivers in terms of graphics. Sound gets cut out. Dialogues overlap.  Falling under the map bugs. Getting launched in the sky bugs that lead to your death and potential progress loss/mission failure. Skipping lines leads to weapons disappearing from your hands, items held being doubled (chopsticks for example), lines being skipped or just terminated early.The world (NPCs) is dull, similar to a ghost town. Outside of missions/gigs you have nothing to do really. You cannot interact with pedestrians, scare them off, piss them off to start a brawl fight, recruit them, flirt with them - you can't do anything really. They are just there to populate the word, to occupy the space and to give you an impression of a bustling city life.Poor customization. There was absolutely no need for the genitalia customization while you only have a couple of hair styles to choose from, eye color, facial structure. Fallout 4 has a way better character customization option in comparison.Graphical glitches, artifacts, low textures, bad meshes, etc. - very noticeable throughout the game. Outside of the main questline the game is pretty boring, forgettable.I like Keanu as a person. Do not like him a lot as an actor. Definitely do not want well known actors in my games and strongly disliked seeing how big a role he has in this one.Would have liked to see more settings too: Ability to disable the loot display on the HUD that takes minutes to clear up after looting a bigger area. Cannot remap the M key for the map. Cannot sell multiple items fast. Cannot lock items to not mistakenly sell them. Can't mark as junk to then sell all junk at a shop or dismantle. Car control is way too sensitive. (depends a bit on the car you're driving)Not a lot of variation in cyberware you can buy. 2-3 options on average for each part and that's it. Not that many different approaches. And your origin hardly makes a difference. Sure it grants some different dialogue options that are pretty much not important. You either go guns blazing or try the stealth approach - that's it. Sometimes you get to decide if someone lives or dies.Comparing this to the witcher 3 is honestly insulting the witcher 3. Way better in all regards.The only really nice thing I liked so far in Cyberpunk is the

author: Mina
review: After now nearly 100 hours in this game and 100% Achievments, I had to write about it. First I was angry about the publisher. Changing the release time again and again. Then I thought why not, that only will make the game better. So I kept the Pro Order and hoped for the best.And then on the first day I started to play. And it was great. I was lucky, I did not encounter all the bugs many had. Also, I was lucky to play it on PC and not on the Consoles. But then later I had a bug after bug and only by exchanging save games I could finish all achievements. But here already stopped the negative part about this amazing game. This game is the first game I just enjoyed driving to the next Quest, the next location. I never even sipped the automatic drives. The music is amazing, the characters are great and even playing parts (especially the endings) again and again was ok.  I like to collect all and it never went boring. Every small side quest was special and interesting.I have nothing more to play for the moment, but if the deals will be as good as the game so far I will for sure will play all of them, even that I normally hate to come back after half a year. But this time I am sure I will come back and try to finish all 100% again. So I can only say, get the game, try it out, do not look too much on some bugs and enjoy this totally different world. Just drive threw the desert and enjoy the lights during the night.

author: funkyterminator2003
review: I waited 9 months to play the game hoping it would be somewhere near the game that was originally promised. Even though I purchased at launch and started playing in December but like many others hit a myriad of issues I decided to unhappily wait until I thought it would be more ready. That time was recently and I am again just massively disappointed. Disappointed in the lack of open world things to do, it's complete lack of RPG elements, the bugs are still very apparent so god only knows how bad it was at launch. The weapons are all pretty basic and boring, it's far too easy a game with everything dropping for you as you make your way through the story. I can't seem to hold a steady 60fps in 4k with Raytracing and DLSS on Auto with my 3080, the police are hilarious, the npc's have no AI what so ever, the driving is terrible, the list goes on and on. The game is so far from what was promised I feel completely let down for my money. I won't be making the same mistake again with CDPR. I do not recommend. (unfortunately)

author: Teangeolai
review: This game looks incredible and I'm really enjoying the story so far. It does have some bugs still, but nothing I've come across has particularly bothered me, much less ruined the game. It's incredibly immersive and detailed, the voice acting is really good, and the gameplay is fun.

author: Ziph
review: Just wanna start with saying that I do enjoy the game and will keep playing it. Granted I only have 10 hours of playtime so far, but I still definitely feel like that's been enough time to gather some criticism. I have already been drawn into this beautiful world. If you haven't got it yet however, just wait a while until/if they release the full game because let's be honest here, the game is not done. The art is gorgeous, the music is amazing, I am somewhat attached to my V and the world is incredibly beautiful. It has many small little details that are fun to explore. The character creation was lackluster, and once you've made it you won't be able to change it later. Unless they patch that in at a later date. At the moment it feels like a mix between GTA and Mass Effect with some Witcher dialogue, and all of those games are better at what they do.The AI is a joke to be completely honest. Kill someone with no witness in an apartment two storeys up, and have cops spawn right outside. Walk next to a cop, minding your own business, and start a fight with 'em. Save some NPC in a quest, there is NO reaction from said NPC whatsoever except it just keeps cowering on the ground. The game feels alive in the way that it feels like it will keep going despite you. But it also feels quite stale. The NPCs were said to have their own routines and if that means they spawn out of nowhere, and tell you to ♥♥♥♥ off if you speak to them, then yeah sure they have their own routines and dialogue.Who thought it was a good idea to make you a loot machine? Wherever you go you're gonna be looking at the ground for the million pieces of junk you have to get to craft, to get a gun that is ever so slightly better than the last. If you like that sorta gameplay then you'll have a blast with Cyberpunk 2077.Maybe I'm playing the game wrong but it feels like the enemies are bullet sponges, fun combat does not equal wasting all of your bullets on one big enemy. In general it's fun to play at this point, but it really does feel lackluster in many ways. It's clear they have many things they decided to cut only to bring back later in a "free DLC". You'll probably get the best experience by having patience and waiting a couple months. The game has so much potential to be absolutely amazing, like CDPR's previous franchise.

author: dimm_ddr
review: This game remind me of classic games like Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines and Arcanum. Amazing games that was also complete bugfest. If you are not a crybaby and can manage to look for creative solution to avoid some side quests bugs, can stand some things of questionable quality (like driving) and can abandon nowadays "meta" of minmaxing and read about everything in the guides and wiki - you will get tons of fun. World of Cyberpunk 2077 is absolutely stunning, most quests are great, there are tons of small details that shows that devs actually cares and hell lot of easter eggs.Avoid this game if you can't stand a thought of potentially not being able to 100% this game because one of small side quests will bug out on you or if you want absolutely polished game without any issues or weak mechanics. Not sure what exactly you can play instead then, but not my problem, you will manage.

author: RWBY CHIBIIIIIIII
review: Ok, so where do I start? I have finished the game, tried 5 endings and I cried in 4 of them, I pretty much only liked one (), but I still want to play more and more and wish to see DLCs that continue the story.I gotta say, this game was terrific, amazing, stunning, from the beginning till the end. I barely ran into any major issues (got only a major bug but whatever). The soundtrack, the characters, the main and side quests, the story, the world-building, everything is stunning.A lot of characters won my heart: JUDY, Brendan, Evelynn, Jackie, Misty, Panam, Cassidy (he's a cool man), Rogue, Johnny (yeah, he's a jackass but in the end, he's a good guy), my list could go on - each character was iconic on their own. Judy has a special place, I kinda made her my comfort character for several reasons (being lesbian and having a crush on a girl when she was younger was two of them).I gotta advise, all choices in the game matter, and they affect both big and small details in the story.The soundtrack? Gods, the soundtrack was amazing, doesn't matter the music gender, I felt engaged with most of them.Thank you CDPR, for this fantastic masterpiece.I haven't felt this way in years. I have no regrets about pre-ordering it as soon as it was available to do so.

author: Chaser324
review: Didn't actually hit credits but decided to just go ahead and uninstall for now. There's good stuff in here and I have mostly enjoyed my time with this game, but you need to be very willing to overlook a constant barrage of bugs, cut corners, and generally messy gameplay/balance.CDPR management did wrong by both "gamers" and CDPR employees, and they've done potentially irreparable damage to the company's reputation for their handling of this launch. I truly feel bad for all of the employees there that had to go through the crunch death march to release a game that they knew wasn't ready.Maybe eventually this becomes an unconditionally great game if they continue to improve it, but we'll just have to wait and see. Unless you feel like you absolutely must play this game now, hold off for 6-12 months.

review: Guess all the money went to the demos and trailers.

review: I will Load Checkpoint every time I beat Smasher, I seek vengeance.

review: Been good to know ya.

review: While I am enjoying the game I can't really recommend it to anyone yet as the optimization is currently a joke. If it ever gets patched then I'll edit my review.

review: ===[Audience]===☐ Kidss☑ Everyone☐ Casual players☐ Pro players===[Graphics]===☐ Potato☐ Really bad☐ Bad☐ OK☐ Good ☑ Beautiful☐ Masterpiece===[Price/Quality]===☑ Full price☐ Wait for sale☐ Average☐ Refund it if you can☐ Don't do it☐ It's FREE===[Requirements]===☐ 90' PC☐ Minimum☐ Medium ☑ Fast☑ High end ☑ NASA computer===[Difficulty]===☐ You just need 2 arms ☑ Ez☐ Easy to learn / Hard to master ☐ Hard (first few hours)☐ Dark Souls===[Game Time/Length ]===☐ Really short ( 0 - 2 hours)☐ Short ( 2 - 8 hours)☐ Few hours ( 8 - 12 hours)☑ Long ( 12+ hours)☐ Endless===[Story] ===☐ It doesn't have☐ Still better than Twilight☐ Average☐ Good☑ Fantastic===[Bugs]===☐ Game itself is one big BUG☐ Bugs destroying the game☑ Lot of bugs (wait for Bugfixes)☐ Few Bugs☐ You can use them for speedrun☐ Nothing===[Others]===Multiplayer: maybe soon?Singleplayer: YesTip: Performance Boost (Nvidia User) Enable DLSS in the Graphics Settings.Tip2: Turn off Full Screen optimization.

author: Zach
review: So this is going to be one of my First reviews but I was so disappointed with this game to the point I will attempt to give a run down of the current state of this game so please bear with me.So my reviews Negative, but I hope to change it to a positive sometime in the future but for now I'll try and explain my reasoning. I'll start with the positives:- A fairly varied skill tree, a lot of it is just some modifiers or numbers going up but it offers various ways to play the game such as melee focused, hacking, shooting focused, stealth etc.- A very beautiful looking city in many areas (If you're lucky enough to run this game on a stable frame rate). Areas of the city have different styles to them and are nice to drive around and look at. - Quest design offers a few ways to resolve quests and offers a fair degree of player choice compared to other RPGS, however it seems lax when compared to Witcher 3 or Fallout New Vegas- The Main story and Voice acting is pretty good so far and is keeping me fairly immersed. (This is subjective but I may as well mention it) - A really good Soundtrack with various genres of music.- A good enough character creator which offers a fair few options to customise your character. Could use a bit more options in some places but its good enough for a game that primarily has the player in first person.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Very Buggy, and I mean  buggy. It's hard to play for more than five minutes without seeing some kind of visual, audio or physics bug. I've only had two game breaking bugs where I was forced to restart the entire game but I feel like I've been lucky in not getting the worst of it.- Poor optimisation, I have a RTX 2080 TI, 16gb of Ram and a fairly good CPU and I manage to have 55-60 FPS with RTX off and settings on max (This is with DLSS on quality setting) but I feel like it stutters where it shouldn't and there is still massive amounts of texture pop in on vehicles and some NPCs. Apparently other players who meet or exceed the recommended specs can barely manage a stable 30+ on Medium which doesn't seem acceptable at all.- Awful AI, and this is a very distracting issue for me. The AI in this game is something you'd see from 2001 or even earlier, NPCs on the street barely react to anything around them and seem to just idly walk down the street or pound on a vending machine. You can punch people in the face and they'll stand there and let you punch them or if you're lucky they'll actually try and run away. I've also noticed as soon as an "aggro'd" civilian NPC leaves your vision they'll immediately despawn, meaning whole streets will disappear if you fire your gun and turn your back.NPCs driving cars follow a strict rule of simply driving forward on their preset path, if you park your car in the middle of the road cars will just stop behind it honk their horn once and wait there forever, they'll never try and drive around any obstacle. The fact this AI is so minimal and shallow means the city feels dead and hollow as its essentially a bunch of poorly scripted AIs with absolutely no impact to the environment around them. It seems odd that a high budget game in 2020 has worse AI than GTA San Andreas, I don't know if it'll be expanded upon in patches or expansions but I sincerely hope it is.- The NCPD. This ties into AI but I feel like it needs its own point. The police in this game are a complete joke, either being a non threat or completely over powered. If you commit a crime you'll gain a wanted star and within about 2-5 seconds a NCPD Officer will be spawned behind you and I mean literally about 2 meters behind you, doesn't matter where you are if there's a space for them they'll spawn there.At first I thought it was it a bug as it was so jarring I couldn't accept that it was intended, but after playing for 20+ hours I can see it was fully intended. This is because there are no car chases in this game, absolute none outside of the scripted story ones. There is no AI that chases you in a vehicle, it just straight up isn't there. If you manage to just drive for about 10 seconds away from where you gained the wanted star it'll just disappear because you managed to escape the cops they spawned in behind you and there's no AI capable of giving chase, meaning they HAVE to be spawned behind you.On the Flip side if you don't manage to escape there'll most likely be about 5-10 augmented cops spawned behind you who'll quickly overwhelm you, if you're very unlucky you'll commit a crime beside a NCPD rocket turret which will very quickly instantly kill you, especially if you're in a vehicle.- Stilted Combat, this is kind of a "meh" point for me but it definitely needs some improvement. The gun play and melee feel more like you're shooting or hitting brick houses rather than people. There's not much reaction from the NPCs you shoot or hit, I know most are augmented super humans but at the minute its very unsatisfying to fight people and I sincerely hope its improved in the future. (Another subjective point but I feel like it needs mentioned)There's also close to no feedback you're getting hurt, eventually you'll be on 20 HP and your screen goes red but there seems to be no feedback or sound design of your character getting shot, meaning you'll quickly get shot to death if you're not closely watching your health.- Beautiful city unfortunately lacking depth. So I previously mentioned that I enjoy the styling of many areas of the city and a lot of it looks beautiful, but that's unfortunately where it ends. Aside from driving around doing some random missions or finding a set gang shootout the city feels like it lacks depth. There's barely any interiors to buildings and not a lot to actually do in Night City which is very unfortunate. This isn't helped by the extremely basic AI I talked about above.I recall Witcher 3 didn't have reams of things to do in it's cities but Cyberpunk 2077 desperately needs something more to do in Night City. There's no patrolling gangs or cops that start fights in the streets (They only spawn in specific areas around the city),  there doesn't seem to be any random encounters that can happen to you when walking around the streets (as far as I know), and I don't even think there's any activities or things you can do on your downtime. I only found myself wanting to walk around the city to take screenshots rather than do anything worthwhile.- No level scaling, or seemingly no level scaling. Areas seem to be set to specific level ranges, meaning you might accidentally wander into an area where enemies will kill you in one shot or you'll have to fight a whole bunch of bullet sponges, which becomes fairly tiring pretty fast. This can lead to you being stuck to one area for a while grinding out levels.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I was very disappointed by what I saw in Cyberpunk 2077, especially after all the crunch time the devs had to endure. There's a lot of bugs which I can tell they knew about but just had to leave in for the release to fix later and there's a lot of seeming bad management or game design choices. I have no doubt CD Projekt will patch this game to be great and more enjoyable, but until then unfortunately Cyberpunk 2077 is not worth your time or money. I look forward to giving a more positive review in the future.

review: 9/10Cyberpunk 2077 is an amazing game. I believe it's finally time people stop living in 2020 and finally give the game the chance it deserves. author: Ashelia
review: In short, I loved this game. Its story, Night City, and the nihilism contained within its streets are ugly beautiful. Without bugs, it would be a solid 8.5/10. With its bugs it's a 8/10 for anyone with a good rig (and likely 6 or 7 for those without). That said, I hope history is kind to this game because what it's saying is poignant as well as well-written, the concept of engrams and what it means to be alive is fascinating, and the characters of Silverhand and V are interesting juxtapositions. It has flaws, it has bugs, but it's one of the better open world games in the past decade--especially if you like world building, if you like good characters.One caveat: play the game thoroughly. Don't rush to the end, or save side quests until after the end. You can beat it fairly quick, but it won't have much meaning if you do. Much of the meaning of the game are in the side quests and even side gigs. Yeah, sure the side gigs can be a bit cut and paste (a lot of them are simply variations on fetch or escort quests), but it's so cool seeing inside these buildings and really getting to know Night City as well as its denizens.  Plus it's interesting to some degree the variation of characters; some people you save are wretched, some are opportunistic, some are tiring. Even the Cyber Psychosis quests take a long time, but their stories are sympathetic and it's interesting (I still remember the reality TV sister one). You'll feel like you really tried to make it in Night City, you'll feel like the city really chewed you up and spit you out, and you'll feel a lot more emotion during the various ending paths of the game.It's important to note that while the bad list is long, they're actually so minor compared to the benefits. Basically what it offers is stronger than the weaknesses. I just want to be thorough about how it's far from perfect.

author: Flare
review: I have very mixed feelings about Cyberpunk 2077. There's a good experience buried in there somewhere, but it's hard to look past all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you have to put up with in order to get to the good stuff.First off, I've tagged it as a Yes recommendation because I still think it's worth playing even if my final opinion on it wasn't particularly good. There's so much that Cyberpunk 2077 does so damn right: the city's design and realization is absolutely spot-on, the writing is impeccable as we've come to expect from CDPR, and the score couldn't be more precisely put together. Any game which can flawlessly pull off moving between hard pumping synths, head banging punk metal, and a solo piano rendition of 'Round Midnight has done something incredible in my books.But despite the utterly phenomenal artistic accomplishments that CDPR have managed to cram into the game, I think somewhere along in development they forgot that they're a game company, not a film studio. The RPG elements seemed promising at first, but they're ultimately pretty shallow, and most unforgivably they're just overshadowed by the fact that they've made your mechanical interaction with the game that of a first person shooter. Why would I bother with any skill tree development that boosts my damage output by 6% after 5 levels when I can pump it all into headshots and get 300% damage boosts because I can actually aim? Hacking is a poorly disguised reskin of the magic systems of fantasy games, except instead of mana they call it RAM. Fistfights are an utter slog. The economy is a total joke, market manipulation through soda almost mandatory. We're not even going to discuss the bugs. To sum up, I couldn't help but be reminded that I was playing a video game at every turn."Immersion" is a term thrown about with reckless abandon by people nowadays, often without understanding what it really means. It's not as simple as writing good characters that the player can enjoy interacting with, or creating a gorgeous world that players love walking around in. If I can't talk to those characters in ways I consider obvious or necessary, I'm not going to feel immersed. If I can't navigate that world in an intuitive and unobtrusive fashion, I'm not going to feel immersed. At its core, immersion is about the systems through which the player engages, not the "content" that the player's supposed to engage with. And to hammer home my point, just look at how much engagement people can have playing stuff like Minecraft or Gmod, often in environments with next to no "content" ready to go! All you need are to provide tools the player can understand and utilize, and to put as few roadblocks between them and the virtual world as possible.It's a chore driving through Night City. The cars don't drive like cars, they bounce and screech around like go karts. The AI swerves through turns like they're intentionally making your journey as difficult as possible. Fast travel has made studios lazy when it comes to designing locomotion, because they now expect you to just skip through it all.It's a chore to work through the interfaces. It's like they knew they were building it for mouse and keyboard so they didn't attempt to make the fifteen thousand different contextual menus easily accessible for the player, or to implement something as simple as allowing you to craft multiples of the same item.It's a chore to talk to the NPCs. Don't get me wrong, the writing itself is usually pretty damn good, but that doesn't matter for ♥♥♥♥ when actually working through the conversation interface forces you to stop and stare at them like a lost puppy and move your hands and fingers off their usual positions to hit the other seventeen buttons that are dedicated to the conversation interface.Almost all three of these are examples of times when less is clearly more. Skyrim and Witcher don't suffer from issues with locomotion because they didn't overcomplicate their navigation methods: you're either on foot or you're on a horse and that's it. Locking you in place during conversations actually makes things significantly easier since you have less choice to overwhelm you, allowing you to focus on just enjoying the dialogue.Cyberpunk 2077 is not a good Game.But Cyberpunk 2077  a really damn good Movie.It's always easier to run your mouth about the things you didn't like about something, so my positives will be significantly shorter and sweeter, but I do want to emphasize how truly excellent these artistic aspects of the game were. It's hard to quantify the number of times I just strolled through Night City, taking in the entirety of the city, the grime, the vertical expansion, the way the skyscrapers block off sunlight from population centers like we're back in Kowloon Walled City. It's hard to describe the genuine engagement I had when the characters lament the pieces of humanity either they or the world around have lost, filtered through their own experience. (Looking at you, Kerry. I'm incensed by the Pon Pon ♥♥♥♥♥ of the real world, too.) It's hard to say just how often I'd stop to see a little piece of that virtual world unfold and say to myself, "Yep. That's exactly right. That's the truth right there." It's hard to really laugh at those NiCola ads with its scantily clad mascot when we're that close to having the same exact ♥♥♥♥ already.I wish the people who made games like these wouldn't make them as games. Their hearts clearly aren't in it for the "game" of it. But they would make fantastic, insightful films or books.

author: Black Seven
review: Cyberpunk 2077 is simply "The Best Game from the year 2077 that you can try to run on a PC from the year 2019!"I have an I7-9700 with 32Gb of Ram and a 2080 TI OC, running on an M.2 Drive and I get single digit frames if half the options are not turned off. I wish steam had a third choice beside the "yes" or "no" choices. The game is actually pretty good, I just have three questions I would ask the Devs and whoever is thinking of buying this:1 - Is Quality Control (bugs, functionality) and Optimization of a game important to you? Because if you enjoy lots of minor bugs, one or two mission breaking bugs and the game chugging along with pretty bad performance, this game is "Fantastic"! 2 - A game with such serious undertones and I still need to put 15 rounds into a guys head for him to die, who thought it was a good idea to make everyone and their Cyber Mom into a big fat bullet sponge? In terms of "bullet spongyness" this game makes "The Division" look like a Hard Core 3rd party Arma 3 Mod. No matter how good and tight the gun handling, sounds and ADS are, it is all for nothing when you feel like you are using an airsoft toy. 3 - Dialogue options are regrettably poor and most of what the character does is on the rails. Why even put these dialogues options there if you make us select each one and go through the motions regardless of choice? I was not expecting Mass Effect/Fallout/Elder Scrolls character freedom in this game, but I was surprised how shallow it was. So All in all, do you need to play this game RIGHT NOW? Because it is a fantastic game, with many awesome aspects, even with a few seriously questionable design choices, although much of that is subjective and relative to your tates. It is also a game with many technical issues that should not be there with such a long development cycle. I would wait until the technical difficulties are ironed out and hopefully some mods come out, before purchasing it. Buyer beware. P.S. *Update* -The latest Nvidia driver made DLSS make a world of difference. it is somewhat running now and GPU usage shot-up dramatically. So I guess there is hope.If you want to know more, just watch this:

author: Moshmadess
review: First off, I'd like to say, if you are looking to potentially get this game don't believe all the bs the critics and game magazines are saying about this game. Yes there are some minor bugs but I have yet to come across anything game-breaking to the point that made me not want to play anymore. Most of the issues they are complaining about from what I've heard people are having are for consoles (which lets face it if you're reading this you are part of the PC master race and consoles will never be as good as a high end gaming pc).  The story really sucks you in and even though it can almost seem a little overwhelming  at first you never have to stop and wonder what you are going to do like in the GTA series or other open worlds. You constantly have a list of different missions you can do and work on outside of the main story. The graphics even without going 4k are absolutely amazing and realistic. Highly recommend playing it (just make sure you got your drivers up to date as some people have game issues if there graphics drivers are not up to date)

author: iMatrix7
review: ..with an MSI RTX 2080 and Ryzen 7 3800XT (32GB Ram)So let's sum up my first impressions.Today, at the time of this review, game is absolutely playable and enjoyable. I really enjoyed what I saw. From the beginning you start to build your own story, defining your background and making a few minor and important choices that will shape your character. Customization is also great: the game allows you to personalize even the smallest details of your body, even those ones you rarely touch in any other games (who played already this game knows what I'm talking about, hehe). Immersion in this futuristic environment is absolutely gorgeous! Everything is so well polished and alive, letting you feel a part of what the world really is in Cyberpunk 2077. A few tutorials and concentration are recommended to learn the basics, but nothing so complicated or boring. You will master all the techniques in no time.Minor bugs are still in the game, but nothing game-breaking. I don't think we still reached the best optimization this game could get. with everything enabled at max settings (RTX ON), with my specs (listed above or in my profile for full specs) I reached 30/40 fps. The most concerning thing, is when I disable the Ray Tracing, since I start to get only 70/80 FPS, and I say concerning because I was expecting something a bit better.. but I'm not complaining, since I know it could run much worse than this. However, if you play this in a "smart way" setting everything enabled, no ray tracing and reduced post processing stuff (which I reduce everytime because I just hate those effects), you are guaranteed to reach 100/120fps and even more in certain situations, which makes the game really smooth and that's how the game should run.If you're just scared to buy the game because it just launched and it could be broken, relax. As I said, game is totally playable and enjoyable, so go grab it, and reach Night City to start your adventure ASAP! <3

author: FrozenShiver
review: Cyberpunk 2077 is a first person role playing open world adventure following the story of V in Night City.The best part of the game is the futuristic city, the cyberpunk theme and the story that has enough choices and endings to feel personalized. Everything in this game is created to exist for you, but the characters and story are written well so that it feels organic. Both the main story and the side missions offer a lot of different experiences along the way to become Night City's legend. There's a heist, comradery, love interests, belonging to a clan, sympathizing with hookers and obviously seeing Johnny Silverhand party first hand. But the story doesn't stop there, it builds up this dream and illusion to crush it down, having endings and conclusions that are mature and not happily forever after fairytales.Playing the missions consists of scripted events that you go through mixed with cinematics. You are just an errand person. Combat can be approached with the classic range/melee weapons, stealth and hacking. None of them are too challenging and difficulty mainly comes from being stat checked, needing enough levels and stats to take down your enemy. The combat handling feels good enough, but you won't find the extra satisfaction you can find from playing games focused on combat and the enemies can feel like bullet sponges. Driving is the worst part as vehicles tend to lose control quite easily, especially the faster ones. The AI in general isn't very smart.It has some player customization, not on the detail level of some RPGs. You can customize your genitals that aren't shown in game and it seems like it's a feature to bring out a reaction from the player. There are 5 different attributes each with 3 or 2 perk sets and each containing around 20 perks to help you specialize your character. Weapons have special types like power, tech and smart, but they don't make a big difference to go out of your way to get them, selecting the dropped weapon with the highest DPS gets the job done. Only several cars and motorcycles are available for driving.Just like in Witcher 3, the story suffers from trying to be urgent and then leaving you in the open world where you can take months doing side content before returning to the main mission. But the conclusions of the endings have a stronger effect from the game being open world, it's definitely a strange mix.For the technical issues, I experienced some visual bugs that got fixed by updating the graphic drivers. Only one crash and one time where I had to restart the game due to scan not being available. Some silly bugs where the person you are talking to in a cinemtic slides, T-posing characters, answering the phone and V talking to 3 different people at the same time, dropping a carried body resulting in a big splash leaving a pool of blood.Overall, Cyberpunk 2077 has an engaging story that is fun to experience once, but I doubt the gameplay or open world will leave you wanting to come back for more. There are some bugs that can be fixed, but they aren't major to stop the game from running.For achievement hunters:There are some combat challenges, completing all the side content in all areas, collectibles, missables for using your attribute and perk points, choosing dialogues and the different endings can be reached by saving at the point of no return

author: Cevius˂◇˃
review: Pros:> Great story writing/characters, probably some of the best I've seen since TW3> Side missions as good or better than the main quests> Game looks gorgeous with RTX on (but you'll need DLSS to get a semi-decent FPS)> The Internet Historian video on the development of this game will be entertaining in 6-12 months or so...> BEEP BEEP M*THERFCKR> 100 hours gameplay so far, probably another 30 hours left to complete all the gigs and try for additional endingsCons:> Hacking rapidly makes you overpowered, and since you've sunk all your unlocks into those skills, you'd need to do a reset (100k from rippers) in order to correct that without being weak as hell elsewhere.> Various bugs. Visual ones could be ignored but ones that trap you inside the floor, or fail to register an NCPD incident has actually completed or not requires reloads to get past.> Tech weapons can punch through walls. Combine this with Ping and you can just scan a combat zone and pluck people off with ease, while they can't do anything back. Favouring tech weapons/hacking should modify the defences found in some missions so more enemies are hack resistant, or use tech weapons back more consistently. > Power weapons ricochet seemed far too unreliable early on to be worth using. Probably can counter that with character unlocks, but it would be better if ricochets were set to auto bounce back at a target using "tech" and the tech guns that punch through walls being listed as "power" weapons.> Some features are just entirely undocumented. Like the Caps Lock button will keep the hacking/scanning view open so you don't need to hold TAB. Was this ever mentioned in game? The few times I accidentally left it on I assumed it was a bug and reloaded a save, as it doesn't have any  onscreen mention of CAPS LOCK - TRACKING LOCK or something similar.> Driving on keyboard and mouse is a bit awful. Nothing really new there, a common issue with many games also designed for consoles.> Wildly inconsistent FPS. Could just be down to RTX, but any scene with a lot of NPCs in it, or in bars/clubs generally dropped to 10-15fps on an RTX 2070s @ 1440p with DLSS in performance mode. Otherwise it would be around 50-75fps.> Choosing your life path didn't seem to matter as much as I thought throughout the game, just  a smattering of custom responses in missions. Final notes:I very much enjoyed my time with 2077, but unless you're a massive fan, give it 6 months to iron out the bugs and performance wonkiness.

author: master baiter
review: I have no idea how this game has such good reviewsAll they did was a bunch of false advertising for a "revolutionary" open world fps-rpgThey said that with every new title they make a better and bigger game.Witcher 3 has easily 100 hours of content and in Cyberpunk i finished the Story after around 38 hours.With almost all side quests and a lot of wasted time collecting taxis and tarot cards i got to 48 hours.The guns feel greatYou don't need any cyberware at anytime. That's not a bad thing because in my playthrough at Patch 1.03 all the cyberware was such a buggy mess that it barely worked at all.The knives out of your arms do little to no damage compared to ranged weapons.The grenade launcher has the most glitched model of all time and no reload animation or cooldown. it just shoots?Tranquilizer ammo in the grenade launcher just doesnt work. it shoots and explodes just like a regular grenade. bye bye stealth abilities.the only thing that seems to work fine are the gorilla hands or arms whatever. they seems pretty cool but you either need an insane amount of armour or a lower difficulty to properly go into melee combat anyway.The cars are all horrible. They look amazing but drive worse than cars in GTA III. YOU CAN'T EVEN CHANGE THE COLOR OF CARS YOU BUY. You can farm money for like 10 hours to finally buy your favorite car and it has a fixed color and if you don't like it you better reload you savefile.Cops spawn right behind you if you do "bad" stuff but after running away like 50 meters or driving your car for 10 seconds they lose you immediately.Difficulty setting are weird. On the highest difficulty you can easily play "stealth" without spending a single skill-/perkpoint on stealth. But if you get into combat you better watch out because you are are two shot kill most of the time and sometimes a oneshot. But because the enemies "AI" is as smart as a toddler, you should be fine.In all Bossfights you can just walk away from them while shooting and if they get too close you just double tap either W,A,S or D to just dodge.They talked about the "insane" variety of characters all around night city. Well, if you go anywhere you will sure notice the pedestrians walking around from their spawnpoint to the other end of the sidewalk. They don't do anything but walk. Either they spawn in a chair and sit down forever, or they spawn walking around and then they walk around forever.By having the ability to randomly be able to give every pedestrian a different look, it is unbelieveable how you can sometimes see 3 characters with the exact same appearance (hair,face,clothes etc.) next to each other.Night City is the "City of Dreams" and there is absolutely nothing to do.The Game looks amazing, but for people without a 2000 or 3000 series Nvidia GPU that don't have DLSS, it's nearly impossible to get above 60FPS.Choices don't matter at all.If you watched all Night Wire Episodes on Cyberpunk's YouTube Account you will surely remember when they talked about "Lifepaths". They should rename it to "Different Tutorial", because all they do is change the first 15 Minutes of your story and give you a bunch of dialog options later in the story that like i said don't change the outcome of anything.Everything i just wrote has nothing to do with bugs and glitches. I don't care about them because they can (maybe will) be fixed in the next few weeks/months. The Game is lacking content to an extreme amount.It's emberassing that they even had the idea of releasing in april. If you look at the state of the game right now after a few hotfixes and see how bad it is, imagine the state of the game at the beginning of 2020. Who in their right mind would even think about releasing this in april.Big shoutout to the Map- and Model- designers. The Map looks amazing and the multi level town squares and markets feels like the city of the future. The Badlands are empty as they should be with a single gas station every once in a while.If you compare the 2018 gameplay trailer to the released game you will see that the look and feel of the map has improved a lot. It has become more realistic and colorful. All the grey concrete seems to have disappeared.The cars look insanely good on the in- and outside. the guns look just as amazing. characters (especially Misty) have the best models and textures i have seen in any game ever.If you want to play this game anyway and can't wait another 6 months until the bugs are gone here are some tipsJust play The Panam storyline and then just stop.Either way im super mad at CD Projekt. They always talk about how much they love games and how much they want to deliver the best experiences. This is just the exact opposite of what they always talk about.I surely will play this game again. It has a lot of potential to be amazing.But until then it gets a dislike from me.I'm outI will come back to review it againwhen the game is ready....

author: NP • Group4K
review: i have reached no point of return in game. It's time to write my thoughts. This game had amazing marketing tactics. Promised more, gave less. Those who are looking for true RPG game, this game is not for you. Some people are crying over it being faulty mess. I agree. It is faulty. But doesn't stop you from playing. Game doesn't crash as often as it does on consoles. In fact, it only crashed 2 times in my 40 hours of play time. I very rarely play a game this much. I have been playing 6-7 hours a day since I downloaded. Meanwhile GTA 5 crashes every 3 hours or so. Why did I mention GTA 5? Because some people think they can compare the whole game and say one is better than other overall. No, you braindead, only thing they share in common is driving vehicles and shooting and open world. One can be better than other only in open world aspects. Rest, depends on player choice. Nothing else. Core, gameplay are completely different. And there are those who compare Rockstar who has been making open world games for 20+ years to a company that recently released its 4th biggest game. You can see how stupid people can be. Ignore them. Night City is alive, full of things to do, and pulls you in more and more. Every street corner feels like perfect work done for designing the city. Gameplay, well, your choice. You are given many approaches. You can hack, stealth-kill, go berzerk (which is actually very very fun, feels like doom), or just avoid killing, sneak and pass objectives. Main storyline will not greatly satisfy you if you don't do sidejobs. And trust me, majority of these side quests have their own stories and correspond with main story. Soundtracks, sound effects of this game are very beautiful aswell. Graphics? Well you have the right for blaming CDPR for issues but if you don't have a PC that can run a 2020's AAA game on high settings (at least medium to feel the city and beautiful views), then it's also your fault. Plus one more thing, If you liked Mr. Robot TV Show, you will like this game too. Not just because of hacking and tech stuff, but also the similarity between Johnny Silverhand and Mr. Robot (P.S. not Elliot but Mr. Robot). Overall, if you weren't hyped for this game, you will love it. But if you have been dreaming about it for like a year, filling your mind with things about this game, then I can't tell the same for you, hence 7-8 billion people don't share same mind. It will get updates in upcoming months and get better than what we currently have in hand. I would recommend you to get the game when it gets fully polished. But if you are eager, you can still try. Game breaking bugs are rare. Most are minor bugs but the problem is they are too much. Anyway, forget the filthy console peasants who are crying for a bad port meanwhile PC players were recieving many unoptimized ports (later got optimized with patches) like RDR2, Horizon Zero Dawn, Dishonored 2, GTA IV. Even Witcher 3 was unoptimized at launch for every platform, but look at that game now. That's all I gotta say. Have fun. I'm sure you will :)

author: GOONMONGER89
review: alright final (maybe) edit of my review.The game is honestly better now, but it's still a 6/10.  Characters are well written, the story is interesting and fun to learn more about, the game is beautiful, and the soundtrack goes hard.  The gunplay is mediocre as well as the rest of the combat, movement is weird and very unpolished feeling sometimes (just a nitpick honestly, not a deal breaker,) and the driving is... not that bad anymore actually, it's just your average driving now.  Decent game, but not worth 60$.

author: inky
review: Wait until a few updates or even expansions come out. Very buggy. Very linear and poor story line. Bad rendering and texture overlays. Stealth sucks. Can't edit character after creation. Very limited character creation options. Buggy game mechanics. THICK plot armor on some NPCs. Nothing new compared to other "open world" games. All the flashy red neon doesn't make up for the rest of the game. 2 out of 5. Needs some work.

author: JSG280
review: Cyberpunk 2077 is an engaging experience unlike anything else. the open world mechanics are top notch , and there is almost always something to do on the map. Hundreds of weapons, augmentations, upgrades and side missions. In my opinion this game will be one of the most significant titles in history of gaming ... you love it or you hate this game, and i love this game !!

author: Legendary Hitman
review: fantastic game that i have never experienced before, and is a window into the future of next-gen gaming and what it's capable of. But game has lots of bugs and need a optimization update for fps drops mainly in city streets area.

author: Ganjirah
review: As a fan of the genre, I was extremely delighted to finally see a game of this scope be released in this setting. From the moment the game was revealed, I decided I would go in totally blind. No trailers or teasers, no forums or comment sections. No overblown expectations of what the game will or should be. I wanted it to be my own experience, through my own eyes, not, let's say," polluted " by hype. I wanted it to be pure and personal. Here's my thoughts on Cyberpunk 2077. I've always been drawn to the cyberpunk genre and the nature of it, it's such a great canvas for storytelling and reflexion. From Blade Runner, Ghost in the Shell, to Deus Ex and Matrix, the genre has always had something different and interesting to say about humanity, technology, the nature of power and civilisation as a whole. Often set in oppressive, gritty, violent, dystopian worlds where power is centralized and empathy, justice and freedom are just a fading memory, it's the perfect premise for a thrilling story and an even better setting for a video game. The main protagonist of the game is not you, V, the player. It's the city. Exploring every inch of it told me more about itself than language could explain, and I found it to be more interesting than almost any character in the game. From the aesthethics and sounds of night city, everything screams decay, violence, inequality, tribalism and obsession for power and control. It's the perfect representation of a society where technology has surpassed its economic system and the consequences of it, a world not so far from our own. But there's beauty to be found in all of this chaos. In terms of design and aesthethics, I dare say it's one of best cities ever made in a video game. A momumental and terribly ambitious project, probably too much for its own good, that I could only ever dream of when playing games like Deus Ex : Human Revolution and Dishonored a fews years back and imagining what these would be like if they were set in open worlds. From the highest corporate buildings to the lowest crime riddled back-alley, immersion in Cyberpunk is to be found at every corner... absolutely exquisite and found in no other forms of media on this scale and at such quality. Whether it's a new toy or a new perspective, every part of the city has its own biome and rewards the player for exploring. I treat video games in a kind of " sacred " way in a sense that I just like existing in this offered space for a while, just taking it all in, and cyberpunk is the perfect game for that. Despite the main story having some glorious moments, it is not where the game truly shines for me ; it's in its side missions, activities and exploration. Take the farcry formula with its outpost system and gunplay, sprinkle some deus ex/dishonored type of gameplay, freedom of approach, level design ( verticality ), put it in a open world settings and you've got a dream come true for many players, me included.This is how I've had the most fun in the game, mostly roaming. It's a unique and memorable experience, one I love to go back to once in a while, more than anything else the game has to offer.

author: Ashe
review: Just... such a magnificent game on so many levels. Two full playthroughs, a year apart. Both wonderful. Would be emotionally destroyed all over again. 12/10

author: Flaws
review: Insane but still buggy. Nothing game breaking so far, nothing a patch or two won't fix.

author: slawa
review: Good game. Got better after patches.

author: GVO. ct
review: Wait for patchesI can't really recommend the game in its current state. This game as much as I hate to say it, Cyberpunk 2077 should have been delayed again.The game is incredibly buggy and unoptimized. Even with a Ryzen 5600x and RTX 3080 I'm getting drops to 40 FPS with some of the settings lowered and DLSS on.The AI in the game is a joke and it makes combat and stealth unsatisfiying.The driving is horrible, it's Watch Dogs 1 levels of bad.This is inexcusable by CD Projekt Red, this is far worse than Witcher 3 on launch. My game has crashed multiple times, I've had to reload saves over and over because missions keep glitching in progress,It was a huge red flag that they did not allow reviewers to show footage of the game and only B-Roll footage from CD Projekt Red themselves.Cyberpunk 2077 is clearly not a finished game with how it is, I'm really let down by this launch.I'm still going to play through it to get my full thoughts on the story and everything but as of now if you haven't bought the game yet, wait until the game has been patched before diving in for a better experience.

author: Eagle5
review: Positive:- Soundtrack- some quests are really creativeNegative:- severely cut content and false advertisement beforehand from CDPR- no public transportation- your decisions in the gameworld don't matter- Personal story (esp. CORPO) is cut off short and doesn't really matter except for some dialoge options- censorship - lack of promised styles in clothing shops- graphic/shadow issues with and without Raytraycing- absent AI- missing braindances (you can still by them as useless items)- NPCs spawning/despwaning (promised was a day/night cycle)- the wanted system spawns police forces right by your side until you are dead- car physics- bad keyboard layout wich is for some parts not changeable- vehicle handling with keyboard and mouse- car customization- and many many more!As others have stated, the release version of CP2077 saw the light of day too prematurely; it is more or less in alpha state. The amount of content that was promised even days before release and then cut is immense. It will take months (if ever) to get CP2077 in the state it was meant to be.Unfortunately, I played too long to refund because I hoped it wouldnt be so bad and others were exaggerating.I would not recommend Cyberpunk 2077 in this current state!

author: Reaxt
review: Ok redoing this review cause im a good bit in nowI really really like this game, not everyone will.Me and a friend talked about it a lot and basically concluded that this is our current generations skyrim.There is a REALLY good game here, but its covered in bugs. Very, very good bugs.There have been moments where the bugs have straight up had perfect comedic timing to the point where I swear it was planned.On top of all that, the writing for the main quest has be captured so far, side ops are fun, I personally have grown to enjoy the combat a lot. I highly recommend this game if you eitherA, think these bugs are funny and enjoy watching them.B, want a good story with very good setpieces in a cyberpunk game.I have yet to feel any significant impact from the choices and my actions throughout the game, but I am fairly early and have been neglecting the main story a bit. I will update this review as I play more.
