author: Alexander Vagrant
review: Okay, that's not a bad game but I can't truly love it no matter how hard I try. The main coolest thing in this game is the plot. It's attractive, catchy, and fueled with a cyberpunk spirit. Seriously, the setting, lore, and characters — I like it all extremely. Of course, there are QUESTIONS about certain aspects of worldbuilding, but in general, it's damn cool. The problem is gameplay. Every aspect of it is a bit odd and uncomfortable. In the early stages of the game, every step is painful. You move around the city trying to blend with furniture — God forbid you will catch the eye of a random bandit who will finish you off with one shot. But as soon as you upgrade at least one characteristic, the game turns into walking in the park. In the middle of the game, I got pretty bored, because by running a couple of scripts I was able to take out small gangs.The whole combat system is a mess. Especially a melee one. Yes, the game has a special subsystem with blocks/counterattacks and other things — and it's useless. The most effective way to kill an enemy is chaotic clicking until the endurance scale runs out. And this, to be honest, great illustration for the whole game. It has great ideas and concepts but half of them just don't work properly.But the worst part is that in the middle of the game, its slides into a dull grind. You carry out most of the orders purely mechanically. They assume neither plot depth nor variability: kill, steal, deliver — get a reward. That looks like MMORPG for those who have no friends.I played about 80 hours of it. Because of the great plot, I do not regret this time. But I suspect I would get much more pleasure from Cyberpunk 2077 if it was a linear mission-based game for 30 hours, and not a monstrous mega-RPG with a bloody open world.

author: Luriam
review: People love to exaggerate and sensationalize when it comes to Cyberpunk. One side is immeasurably in love with it, to the point of ignoring all the flaws and critical oversights. And the other side hates this game's guts and all those who dare play itI only found out about the game in 2020. I didn't even care to watch any trailers or announcements until my friends forced me to do it alongside them. Even my copy of the game was a gift. So if you're interested in an opinion that stems from a neutral party and a pure love for gaming - I hope you enjoy reading my reviewMy first few hours spent playing the game were really fun and enjoyable. I was satisfied with the way my character looked. I liked how the short little prologue set the stage and gave me the motivation to reach for the stars. I truly had a great time, and that first mission with Jackie was a blast. But there was this odd suppressed sensation starting to creep inAnd that would be the immersion breaking bugs, glitches and general lack of polish. How everything felt ever so janky and off. And even though the game is completely playable from start to finish there's hundreds of these smaller issues that pull you out of it. A lot of people say it's only the bugs that ruin an otherwise perfect game. But I strongly disagree, and I believe that aside from that, the game is also incomplete and often feels like a Beta versionThey advertised this game as a first person RPG. And yet they only delivered on half of that. Because simply put your choices don't matter. You can't affect the outcome of 95% of all quests. And you're stuck choosing between options like 'Yes', 'Yes but sarcastically' or 'No, but actually end up as yes'. It's all very pointless and the game only creates the illusion of choice. Instead of branching off dynamically and rewarding players with meaningful choicesNot to mention that for an "RPG", you have very little choice when it comes to shaping V's personality. Practically none. V is always a sarcastic, confident jerk that is occasionally a compassionate joker. But what sticks out to me the most is the complete lack of any kind of moral compass or alignment. Your play style doesn't matter. The world doesn't care if you're lethal or non-lethalAnd yet in spite of all it's bugs and flaws I still had a good time playing it. And this part of the review will focus on CP77's redeeming aspects- . Right from the start, I was thoroughly impressed by how good it looked. I was fortunate enough to be able to play the game on Ultra, with all Ray Tracing effects enabled. And I have to say that Night City is stunning, and all the districts have their own unique architecture and style. The rich, luxurious plazas as well as the dilapidated and washed down outskirts were so beautiful and enjoyable for me to traverse. Big corporate ads, neon lights everywhere, and a surprising amount of buildings you can enterAll of the primary and secondary characters were also meticulously crafted. With an incredible amount of detail and polish to them. From the way their hair moves when they turn their heads. To their jiggling clothes, earring, necklaces, all that kind of stuff. They have believable and easy to read faces, with dynamic skin folds and wrinkles, laugh lines, and so on. In fact there's so much detail put into them that you could use a x8 zoom and look carefully at their eye implants and notice the tiny text that reads KIROSHIIt's also worth talking about Ray Tracing. Because this is my first time playing a game with RT on and it is jaw droppingly beautiful. I used to think that RT is just a fancy little trick for better reflections. But it's so much more than that. The difference is substantial, and in my opinion it pushes CP77 to the very top of graphics in gaming right now- . I didn't like the story very much, but I admit that it had quite a few memorable moments. It's an interesting take on the subject mortality and transcendence. And the game tries to tackle themes such as: loss of a loved one, depression, cheating death and most importantly - acceptance. As the main character slowly goes through all 5 stages of griefIn retrospect it wasn't actually that bad, and I felt a wide array of emotions. There was just not enough.. resolution at the end. No big satisfying sigh of relief. Though there was an attempt at a beautiful done tragic epilogue, which I likedDuring the game you meet a plethora interesting and authentic characters. I bonded with many of them but also disliked several of them. And I think that's a good thing, I like clashing personalities. Unfortunately some of my favorite characters were removed from the playing field too soonI noticed the presence of a lot of powerful and determined female characters. Most, have entire quest lines dedicated to them and even optional endings. For the most part they're really well written and help improve and enhance the story. With some exceptions being the awful Panam sex scene. And the most unlikeable character ever - Judy. She looks as bad as she sounds, and she sounds like an old senile granny. Her bipolar personality and cringy crack ho attitude is my least favorite part in the entire gameJohnny Silverhand is a complicated character, but he definitely doesn't seem so at first. I think most people will actually dislike him initially. But ironically, he is the only sidekick in the game that goes through any kind of personality change and character growth. Some dialogues were really nice, just deep enough to get you thinking. But not corny enough for you to roll your eyes. You can seemingly bond with him during gigs and side missions. But there's no consistency and his replies don't really change depending on whether he likes you or not. But I ended up liking him. And of all the endings.. I think that the one with his epilogue is the most emotional one of the bunchAnd speaking of endings, there's so many of them, perhaps too many. It feels like a lot of budget was blown on these, instead of more interesting quests or deeper gameplay. It all comes down to just selecting a dialogue on the screen. None of them offered me that ease and comfort I believed I deserved. It seems like in my full 110h playthrough I've helped and supported absolutely everyone I encountered, except for myself. But it's true what they say, tragedies are always much more memorable than comedies- . I'm not entirely sure if the audio in my game was bugged or supposed to sound like it did. Many sfx are straight up missing, and that's during essential cutscenes. The sounds that do exist are pretty good and you never get tired of the ringing of your katana ripping and tearing everyone in your path. It's as if they simply ran out of time and had to release the game with a lot of missing sounds, even for the most crucial unskippable scenes- . The original score that was composed for the game is great! I like the dark, droning electronic music as it presents itself to the player. And especially the combat tracks are superb. Each gang has it's own theme that escalates and diminishes based on your play style. But the radio music is.. meh. It's a mixed bag that's usually a combination of mumble rappers as well as boorish and vulgar cringepop. There are some good tracks in there, I admit I bobbed my head a couple of times like a cavemanIn conclusion it doesn't feel at all like a game that was 8 years in development. Things are creaking at the seams and everything lacks polish. Bugs and glitches and missing features galore. But even with all that going on, I still liked it. It's fun, it's beautiful and I enjoyed my time in Night City7/10

author: 入 人 λ³ AVL3 גスℵ
review: With Cyberpunk 2077, I like to think CD Projekt RED tried to build a deep and complex fusion of FPSes, RPGs, immersive sims and GTA-like games, to transcend genre boundaries and deliver one of the most immersive and advanced game worlds ever. For fans of Deus Ex, System Shock, BioShock and Dishonored who have dreamed of combining the depth of an immersive sim with the width of an open-world action RPG, this was an interesting experiment. The game began pre-production in early 2012 and production around 2015... and, after a series of 3 delays, finally ended up shipping for PC, PS4, X1 etc. in December of 2020 - in the middle of the greatest recession and pandemic since the last century. It is also their first major non-Witcher AAA-level game in a very long time.The end result? Undeniably one of the most ambitious games ever... but beyond that, it's a solid FPSRPG with a decent narrative. The overall backstory and setting is all, of course, drawn from the original Cyberpunk RPG and is classic 80s cyberpunk - but don't expect anything more than that, the game scenario isn't in any way self-aware or delve beyond its source material into post-cyberpunk/satire, the game plays its cards straight (think "GTA3 written by Gibson and Sterling in the late 80s").We've got one of the biggest (circa 55 square km) and most meticulous dystopian cyberpunk game-worlds in the history of the medium. Night City is an amazingly detailed city with a great degree of thought put into authenticity, diversity (3-4 distinct architectural epochs were conceived and implemented) and believability, for a city that's 57 years into the future. I've been playing open world games for almost 20 years and I've seen some ♥♥♥♥ (anyone else remember Scrapland?) but this is one of the best I've ever seen.The player character also gets to know a huge number of characters in the world from many different milieus. Unfortunately, there's not a lot to do with them. GTA was arguably a major comparison point here and GTA4 nailed persistent in-game relationships in 2008 - ironically, unlike San Andreas, GTA4 isn't even much of an RPG at all. What I'm talking about is the fact that you can never go cyber-bowling with Jackie, or ask Panam on a date etc. There's some bars in the game-world, but they are basically just themed rooms which you only meaningfully interact with during quests. This isn't the only thing that's missing from the world - others have even drawn direct comparisons to Saints Row which suggest that Cyberpunk's open-world ambitions prove lackluster. But the game's 8-year development was clearly troubled and as far as I know much was cut as CD Projekt Red's management tried to aggressively ship the game as quickly as possible. For me playing it today, it's an excellent but flawed FPSRPG, a gorgeous game with one of the best RTX implementations I have  seen, and a game which truly shines on Hard difficulty... , as well as sub-optimal technical performance. I'm used to East European bug-ridden janky gaming so it only makes me laugh out loud, and I'm used to playing at 25-30 FPS (but if one has RTX and DLSS enabled, they get astounding improvements to picture quality for free), but I can see why other people might not like that. The game doesn't present any problems with save corruption, which would have been my only dealbreaker, but I should say I've experienced a few softlocks. From me, it's ultimately still a recommendation and I think it's one of my favorite games ever. But there are major caveats - RTX is highly recommended at least for now and be warned that until a complete patch ships later on, there are major bugs and performance issues.

author: SGM ツ
review: main story good, "open world" features badbraindance tapes useless aside from main story ones, non-functional clubs/food vendors, pedestrians do nothing except tell you to ♥♥♥♥ off or miraculously get hit by your car when you're 3 feet away from them, ai cars are on rails, car physics are done with low quality raycasting so there's no real suspension or anything, "police chases" entail about 3 ai cops spawning 5 feet IN FRONT of you because there's no car ai, not to mention how unplayable this game is without dlss at 1440p. the game also somehow manages to 100% max out my i7-6700k while in the city, with its impressive ai constantly telling me to ♥♥♥♥ off. my cpu is relatively old, but the fact that the cars are literally on rails and the pedestrians have no real coding, the performance makes zero sense. also 75% of the times that i launched the game, the performance decreased by about 40% after a few hours, 95-100 fps at 1440p down to 50 fps for literally no reason. ram usage is normal, same with cpu, game just slowly runs worse over time. there were only 2 times that i had truly game breaking bugs where i had to restart: early in the game jackie got locked behind a door so i couldn't talk to him to continue, and in the last missions i offed multiple guards and 2 didn't count as dead, even though they were laying on the ground and lootable, so i had to restart the entire mission to continue. outside of those, i had a few cutscenes with missing dialogue, jackie walked straight through a wall, and one t-pose npc in freeroam. while this game has a lot of ♥♥♥♥ wrong with it, it's still a great game. the hype is what's really killing it, because the fact that it was hyped so hard amplifies how bad some of the bugs are. it should honestly be labeled early access because it's pretty obvious that it is. cut/unfinished content and awful optimization, i have no idea how anyone with a non-rtx card could even run this game since they don't have dlss. but if you have a very beefy pc, this game is worth it, otherwise just wait for a lot more optimization patches.

author: ocaoyy
review: This game is a disappointment. I am not talking about the bugs. The game is stupidly filled with bugs but I wish that wasn't the case so the focus could be on why it is just a bad game. In summary, from the AI to the story, to dialogue choices, to gameplay mechanics, this game lacks so much. It's like CD Projekt Red just cut down on so much of the actual content that could've made this game what they promised it to be. Nothing you do matters. The only choices you make that truly "matter" are in the last mission. The AI is so bad in every aspect of the game that talking about it makes me wonder if they really put 80% of their budget into marketing and Keanu Reeves. I love Keanu Reeves, but I wish they spent more time and money on other characters like Jackie. The intro cutscene after your unimportant lifepath choice just shows how much they cut out from this game. Instead of spending time with Jackie and doing missions with him, you are given this lazy video about how you guys are best friends and did a bunch of ♥♥♥♥ together. I have a feeling they originally planned for you to actually do those missions and bond with Jackie more, but they ended up cutting it up into a short intro video. I am by no means saying the developers did not work hard enough. I know the team there was incredibly passionate about this game during development. But from a consumer standpoint, they should have delayed the game indefinitely. "Coming when it's ready" my ass. One of my friends said they would get Watch Dogs Legion instead of 2077. I thought they were crazy. When I imagined how Legion would turn out to be, I thought it would be another copy and paste Ubisoft game that had a map filled with a checklist of things to do, broken mechanics and AI, and a bland experience. Turns out I was describing Cyberpunk.Now, throughout my playthrough, I still enjoyed the game to a certain extent. I was completely immersed in my first 2-3 hours of gameplay. The first mission was amazing. Experiencing Night City during the drive with Jackie as the rain fell on your windshield was awesome. Seeing the neon soaked streets and advertisements got me so excited. But it seems like things only went downhill from there... The graphics and style is beautiful. It is actually pretty well optimized on PC, considering how large and beautiful the game is. There is so much detail and beauty in Night City. Too bad it's literally filled with only sex shops that you can't even interact with, and AI shopkeepers that don't give two ♥♥♥♥♥ about you throwing a grenade at their face. This game was hyped to stupid levels and it was 70% because of CD Projekt Red's promises and vision for the game, and 30% because of the fan base (which is to be expected from this kind of large project). I LOVE the Witcher 3, where your dialogue choices actually affect the story, the story wasn't rushed and the characters feel meaningful. I wonder how CD Projekt Red can fix this game. Will they completely rework the AI and add the features they promised? Or are they just going to add an online mode and some story DLC? This game had so much potential, and maybe it still does post release, but only time can tell.One more positive note. The language support in this game is phenomenal. I played the game in English and Chinese and the voice acting is incredible and the facial animations are brilliant and actually match what the characters say.

author: Council Spectre
review: If you're expecting an Epic, Cyberpunk themed, Singleplayer RPG, then don't bother. And look elsewhere. This game was promised to be an Incredible story with branching paths, and choices that matter. (SPOILER: IT DOESN'T) Outside of a single early story mission, (which they had on their youtube channel promoting this game) your choices do not matter in the slightest. Your characters background doesn't do anything outside of a small intro sequence at the beginning, and then as soon as you are done playing the intro, you're put into THE SAME cutscene and prologue that ALL players have. Regardless of what you chose for your own character. You're not given any agency in how to play the game either. Sure, the current mission objective might have an open floor plan for the current dungeon. But you're not rewarded for trying out new strategies or playing differently. Because there's no need to try out new things. All the areas are all the same copypaste enemies you'll see everwhere. There's no difference from the different gang NPC's you fight. They all have the same basic AI (That doesn't function properly half the time) and they all fight the exact same way. The enemy has a small caliber gun? they use close range shooting. Almost no cover except for reloading. They've got long range? They always hide in cover and take potshots from Obscene distances. They've got a melee weapon? OH BOY. Strap in buckaroo, cuz this game is about to rip your pucker a new one! The melee combat in this game is incredibly basic. And yet, somehow, they managed to make it feel clunky, yet fast. The hits and the animations from your melee attacks feel nice and smooth. But the hitboxes are stupid and hard to hit in fast paced combat. Meanwhile, when you're up against any enemies that like to fight you in melee range themselves, if you've got any of them that have the ability to dash using their cybernetics, you better believe that they'll be able to close distance faster than you EVER could with the same enhancements. And you better believe that those same NPC's are able to land hits on you, even when you're MILES away. All thanks to how their clunky hitboxes work.Combat is fun, and fast paced. But very repetitive. This is one of the few things that the game has going for itself. If you don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about anything except gameplay, then you might actually enjoy this game quite a lot. Especially once you get access to a decent weapon or two. But the combat pacing is somewhat inconsistent at times. Where you'll be kicking ass one minute, and then all of a sudden get your ass kicked yourself. And there is no inbetween. Balancing is a big issue with combat. But other than that, if you're able to turn your brain off and just go shooting. It's quite fun!The story is very, VERY, linear. And you have almost no agency in how you interact with the story. You're able to have small side options for dialogue with the NPC's when they're telling you their life's story. But these function similar to how you had alternate options in Mass Effect dialogue for any of you who might have played that series previously. But unlike Mass Effect, these dialogue options don't do ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for your own story, or your character. They're just little nuggets of lore for those who like to listen to that sort of thing. There's no different choices for story, based on what kind of character you built up over the course of playing. And while you DO get access to special dialogue options based on your character's background, they don't do anything either. You're simply given an option to pick that special dialogue option because you picked that character background, and the NPC's simply smile and nod, and keep going on their set script. There's no differences in dialogue based on who you are. And no differring outcomes in quests because you have a different background from another player. You'll all be playing the same game to everyone else. The only difference you get in choices from all other players is how the game ends. That is it. This isn't an RPG. This an Action Adventure game. With a side of story. You can't roleplay. You can't live life as your character, because there's no way to interact with the ingame world. No ways to interact with NPC's outside of your quest marker. And there's no freedom to play the game the way YOU want to play. Maybe one day this game will actually meet the promises the developers made to us. But as it stands today, That is NOT  the case. This game is good for you if you're able to get this on sale for at least 50% but don't pay full price for this.And if you're expecting a story-rich, open-world, character driven RPG? Go play Fallout New Vegas instead for like 10 bucks. You'll get more replayability and story engagement from that game, than this one. But if you want a bland, uninspiring story, looter shooter/beat'em'up then this is your game. (At least for right now)

author: bêhelit
review: Cyberpunk 2077 was among the most highly anticipated games in history. Its brought to us by the same developers of the Witcher games which, is probably what made this game as hyped as it was. With all this hype this game was destined to be a failure for some, for me however it was probably the best gaming experience I have had all year. Despite the amazing writing it is just average in some of its "RPG" parts, this did not hinder my enjoyment much, but it might lower yours significantly.The Characters are the heart of the game. The story is great and raises interesting points regarding AI, our possible future and body modification, but the characters in this grim world are what makes the ending so emotional especially with what happens while the credits roll.However, V, is the in my opinion worst written one. The 3 live paths did introduce you to him but never really gave huge insights to any bits of his past. Every other character is believable, and you get to know them greatly, from goals, past to personal struggles you get to know everything about the people living in and around Night City.The Characters of Cyberpunk 2077 are more than you might expect at first glance, the most prominent example here is clearly the man, the myth, the legend Johnny Silverhand. He is also the character most prominent throughout the story and the one that undergoes the most surprising but amazing development. The others are not much different though, they all are so well fleshed out and developed that once that ending hits, it really it's hard. CDPR's worlds were always about stories and not about you interacting a lot with it. What you experience in this game you experience in the quests, not in any side activities. There is not much interaction with the world. Its mostly a stage for the characters to play on. You have an apartment, but it does not feel like "home" because you just can't do anything with it. Just don't go in it expecting it to be a Rockstar game, because it is not. However, the atmosphere in Night City is amazing, driving through the rain as never been better in any game i have ever played. Its also very detailed, you know by looking around in which district you are, what people live here and how they live.

author: Astora
review: So far, I am loving this game. I am lucky to have a gotten my hands on a 3070 so graphics have not been a real issue for me like others. I think the gameplay is good, some have been misled by the marketing which makes the game look like a super intense fps. Although that is not the case it was not an issue for me since since I was expecting an rpg and definitely got one. The shooting itself is not that bad, no on par with actual fps' in terms of feeling impact, hit reg, etc. But it does remind me of looter shooters like early Borderlands or Destiny. Mostly in the sense of enemies being a bit spongy and always wanting to go for crits. Hacking to me is pretty fun, thinking of ways to distract one enemy while I blind another and kill the other is satisfying. Sneak is pretty simple but goes well with hacking. The skill trees are pretty vast and give you a good amount of options.I was very very disappointed by the driving early on, it felt very heavy kind of like GTA IV in that respect. However it did feel significantly better once I acquired better cars. Movement feels pretty smooth, you don't move like you're covered in grease. Which is what I felt playing the Witcher 3.The story to me is on the surface a little generic, heist goes wrong now go fix the wrong. But the manner in which it all pans out is what makes it so interesting for me. There are hints of foreshadowing, both subtle and very heavy-handed. The pace to me was well done. I heard people calling it a slow burn but things keep happening in at a consistent pace. It takes it's time introducing you new faces and giving you a perspective on how it is to live in this city. And that to me is the best part of the game, the atmosphere. Everything feels like it could be a real place or thing. Markets feel alive crowded, characters seem like real people (the doc is my favorite so far and Johnny being a mixed bag) and all the tech seems like something people would actually invent and use.The worst part is the bugs. Holy moly. I get that this game is big but I have had to reset the game about 5 times since I was essentially soft-locked. I have had a few quests either halted or go a different way than I wanted due to bugs. Very touching scenes were ruined due to visual bugs. Beautiful scenery has been tainted by various bugs. The ui has tanked due to some. These bugs are everywhere. However it does not ruin it for me, the times I reset sure were annoying but the autosaves never sent me back more than a few minutes.Overall if you are a fan of rpgs and can tolerate a mediocre shooting system then definitely... wait for them to patch it a bit more before buying. If you are expecting high flying action at every corner and are not one to sit through dialog then this isn't for you.

author: B R⭕K E N
review: Pro tips to enjoy this game:1) Watch the anime Cyberpunk Edgerunners2) Buy a pc that allows you to play with maximum graphics (mandatory)3) Drive a car at night in Night CityOne of the best gaming experiences you'll ever have.

author: ℣ĭŉćعŉ†_℣éǥẵ
review: Cyberpunk 2077 resembles a vast, futuristic Las Vegas. You come here and have a hell of a week, but then you wake up one morning feeling jaded and complicit, and you realise that the glitzy signs lead nowhere, the noise is meaningless, and when you look beyond the strip, there is only desert.

author: Ocelot
review: This game did not cure my cancer, bring my wife back to life, nor solved world hunger. 1 out of 5 stars, didn't meet unreasonable expectations :(ok seriously though here are some thoughts I have on the game.1-ultrawide support is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and this is disgraceful from a company as big as cdpr who have loved to crap on about all the extra features the pc version of cyberpunk will have. 21:9 is fine for gameplay but menus have lots of things cut off, dialogue options etc. This should have been ready to go day 12-the game is optimised-most people don't even know what that means....think about just how many things are on your screen at once, just how many lights, cars, people, buildings and more. It's a crazy amount of things to render, this game is next gen but sadly most people won't have cards capable of running. Let's wait for the 4080 and 4080 ti to come out then revisit this game with everything cranked to the max :)3-bugs, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ there's a fair few so far :( these range from random objects popping in, being unable to progress quests which forces me to replay from the last checkpoint and hope that it works next time around. So far CDPR have begun to fix these problems so there's at least hope on the way.4-this game should have never released on ps4/xbox, I'm sure you've all seen how bad it is...I've seen it person and yeah it's just terrible. What's even more terrible was people thinking this gigantic graphically intense game would run on a 7 year old console. The time, energy and money wasted releasing it on old consoles was all time that could have went into improving the pc version of the game. However because it was marketed so much for ps4/xbox there may be legal requirements they had to release it on those platforms.5-so lots of people will disagree or laugh at me for saying this...but I feel like there is just way too much going on the screen, my brain is struggling to absorb it all. There's a lot of systems to learn and I would have preferred if they dumbed it down a tad. but that's a personal problem on my part.If I think of more I'll update it but so far these are some of my gripes-so bottom line, should you buy the game at the moment? Yes but only if you have a rig capable of running it, if you would like to see how the game performs and some benchmarks check out this great teardown from Hardware Unboxed

author: Good boi Isaac
review: Oh well... admittedly it's difficult for me to write this review. Let me start by saying that I was and kind of still am pretty biased regarding CDPR and their games, and that's why it's painful to admit and accept the fact that in it's current state CP 2077 is very dissapointing by CDPR standards and in general as well.I'm a huge fantasy and RPG fan, and with the Witcher trilogy CDPR created one of my favorite gaming franchises. I loved all 3 Witcher games, Thronebreaker, played Gwent on GOG for dozens of hours and all of them are entertaining, quality, content rich titles. So my personal experiences with their previous products, the countless hours I invested in them, and the enjoyment I got out of them pretty much made CDPR my favorite developer studio, and they even topped it with their attitude towards their community and the continous support they provide to their games (patches and fixes years after release, free DLCs, paid expansions with incredible amount of content).As a lot of other gamers I highly anticipated CP 2077, I had a pretty solid idea what to expect, I was familiar with previous CDPR titles, and I knew it will be a heavily text and dialogue based RPG and did not expect a fast-paced futuristic FPS GTA or whatever, so I'm not one of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who compare it to GTA V screen by screen, neither I complain about the amount of dialogues or the slow-burning story.Furthermore I consciously didn't sit on the hype-train like a lot of dumbasses, I didn't expect this game to be some kind of miracle that would bring ground-breaking, never-before-seen innovations in it's every aspect, and would revolutionize the gaming industry forever. I remembered the buggy state in which the Witcher 3 was released so I expected to encounter bugs as well. My point is that I had pretty high, but not unrealistic hopes and expectations for Cyberpunk 2077.I knew it wouldn't be able to live to the unbelievable hype that was generated around it, but CDPR can only be partly blamed for that. The unrealistic hype was mostly generated by "gaming portals and journalists" (I do not wish to go into detail about the state of today's gaming journalism and the quality it represents because it's ridiculous and pathetic beyond measure) and the highly toxic gaming community itself (I'd love to address this as well, and share my opinion but I could rant on and on about this for hours, but let's just say that it's just sad that in 2020 it's common that developers receive death-threaths over the delay of a videogame by some basement-dweller, pathetic nerd... get a life dude.)So let's talk about the gameSo far I have played for around 60 hours and I still haven't finished the story but I usually take my time in RPGs and complete every side-quest, explore everything that I can etc so that's normal. I guess it's true that you can rush through the story under 15-20 hours but who in their right minds would do that in any RPG? :)Initially I didn't encounter that many bugs, only a few barely noticable graphical glitches but nothing game-breaking (the game only crashed once over the span of 60 hours) and I had a pretty stable performance and smooth experience with my RTX 2080 Ti, but bugs became more frequent and severe as I played more. Besides the mentioned graphical glitches I've seen wierd animations, missing textures, cars disappearing and popping out of nowhere, cars falling from the sky, quests that cannot be finished, unlootable items and so on.The hotfixes didn't bring that much improvement at least regarding those bugs that I experienced, but based on the state the Witcher 3 was released and the one it is in now I'm sure all of these will be resolved with the upcoming patches in the next months.The graphics are pretty solid with max settings, the city looks great, the characters sometimes are less so, but it's appealing to look at. It's nothing jaw-dropping and that's totally fine by me, it's very sad when someone thinks that good graphics = a good game. I definitely love the atmosphere of the game, the high-tech / low-life futuristic cyberpunk setting is great, you can feel the strong Bladerunner influence, and the great music and soundtrack complements the atmosphere very well.Moving on to the story - as I said I haven't finished it yet, so I can't form an opinion about it in it's entirety but's it's kind of a letdown so far. It's not the worst, I wouldn't even say it's bad, sadly it's just not that interesting to make me want to get to the end of it and it doesn't help that that the first 10-15 main quests and the story they cover have been spoiled by the trailers before release. Some of the side-quests are more interesting than the main story but the other gigs and jobs become just dull and repetitive quickly.My main problem is that Cyberpunk 2077 lacks a lot of mechanics that in my opinion would be a must in such a world/setting. Character customization is not that bad as some say, there are plenty of options, but I have to agree that I have seen far more detailed customization possibilites in other games. Ok, you can choose the color of your teeth, the size and shape of your ♥♥♥♥, but what's the purpose? You can't even see your character outside of the inventory screen, not even during sex sequences.In a world where body modification is not just possible, but pretty much a common thing with cyberware, implants etc and where looks in general are above all else, the fact that you can't alter your appearance later on during the game is just pathetic. You can't even get a haircut which is pretty much inexcusable nowadays, especially that even the Witcher 3 offered such possibilites.Since Cyberpunk 2077 is an RPG, your clothes and equipment obv. provide stat boosts. If you want to use items that provide better stats you constantly have to change them and because of that most of the time your appearance is ridiculous, and you look like a homeless who dresses from a lost and found bin. Why isn't there an option to change the looks of your clothes while keeping the new stats? A lot of other games utilize such functionality (transmogrification) and even tough this is not a fantasy RPG, changing the appearance of clothes can be easily explained in a sci-fi setting as well, for example with some kind of holographic technology or whatever).Another big problem is that sadly there is not much to do in Night City, there are plenty of side-quests which are fine, you have tons of gigs and other side-jobs but these jobs are almost identical (apprehend or kill a cyberpsycho, kill some gang members here and there, retrieve some intel from somewhere etc) and they become repetitive very quickly and besides this there is nothing. There are a few collectibles, you can buy cars and motorcycles, there a few races and underground fighting pits or something like that and with that we are at the end of the list.Once again I'd like to mention that I know this is not a sandbox action game, it's an open-world RPG. I don't want to play pool, or bowling, or things like that like some peep mentioned comparing it to GTA V, but in 2020 I expected more. It was emphasized that sex and sexual themes are very important, well besides some romance options during side-quests there is 1 female and 1 male prostitue in Night City on the same street. You can bang them and that's it, you can't even go to strip clubs or anything like that.Just to mention the driving, I don't think it's as bad as some say, I didn't really have any problems with the controls or mechanics (besides that the first person view is useless :D) but then again I'm not really into driving games and driving mechanics are just do not matter to me in general.I expected a solid RPG but at the moment CP2077 feels unfinished, rushed, buggy and just very average which is nowhere near the usual CDPR quality and sadly I can't recommend it. You should wait at least a 1 year or a half and check back then.

author: Rexz
review: Fantastic world, rich characters lots of gore and story driven experience. On PC this game is a huge improvement from what it was like on console. I can recommend it as long as you have time on your hands to get through it all. Because there is a lot. There are many choices to make within the campaign, the way you interact with the world makes it your own experience in many ways. Some choices you make are smaller than others but it does all add up in the end. I'm yet to finish Cyberpunk, even though I'm not in any rush to do so, 60 hours into it and I still have way too much left to do before end game. Driving could be more responsive, as well as the perk system and leveling system could be better designed. Not really too bothered about it. Just throwing it out there.

author: Naeem
review: looks like a render demo for rtx gpus and not a game devs didn't spend time on gameplay and ai and just took money from nvidia and put rtx to make it look shiny game is unfinished and has game play mechanics from 10 years ago , unless devs turn it around do not buy it for full price or even half the price they are asking for it

author: Lukederhp
review: Panam > Judy

author: bc
review: Nice try with Edgerunners, now actually fix the game

author: Raisin Fighter
review: Zero replayability, I finished this game in about 100 hours and pretty much 100%'ed the game. After that there is literally nothing to do except just drive around and shoot people. Tried to play through a second time a month ago and it's rough knowing that your choices in the game don't mean jack. A lot of people are glorifying it 24 hours after getting it on sale saying that they have fixed the main glaring bugs, but that's not the issue. The issue is that this was supposed to be an RPG full of new innovative gameplay when in reality its just a linear action-adventure storyline. For a game of the future that is based around cybernetic augments it has pretty much no customization for your character other than your first time creating your character. The issue has never been the performance and bugs. The issue has always been the completely missing systems that were advertised prior to release. The negative reviews at launch were 100% warranted, but this game is average at best. The bugs weren't the issue for me, it was the emptiness in the world that ruined it for me.

author: Lady Archaon
review: So every couple of months I find myself wanting to play cyberpunk - and then I go to play, and realize I want to play something *like* cyberpunk 2077 , but not actually cyberpunk 2077. The character creator is boring and under-equipped considering that customizability is meant to be the point of the transhuman future, and frankly is one of the things I find most disappointing. Your options are limited, you can't control your body shape, the tattoo selection is boring, you have no ability to choose cyber limbs, or any of the other cool features that you see on NPCs, like exposed mechanical elbows or glossy skin tones. Also, the fact you can't change your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ character design once you get out of the creator ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sucks. They could have just paid a dozen furries for a couple of months and they would have built something 10 million times better.The majority of the skill tree is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ +x% to stuff; the combat feels (to me personally) as uncanny valley - not as loose and terrible as Fallout, but certainly not smooth and precise (although, to be fair, i just could be not good at it). The item system is grindy and the customizations are fine, i guess, but could be better.Hacking is fun, I did actually enjoy that part.As for the campaign, there's a pretty bug 2-hour long quest with a bunch of cutscenes and stuff you *have* to do to get out of the starting area into the rest of the game. This is the biggest thing hindering my replays - I do not give a ♥♥♥♥ about redoing Konpeki plaza. Once I did it once, every new iteration was boring. Having do redo the braindance ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ again, and then Konpeki is just tedious.The politics are also tedious. Obviously, people have a variety of opinions within the game, but they're just so shallow. All of johnny's impotent rage feels hollow, and since no-one else in the game really expouses any criticism of the world they live in, despite the obvious flaws. Not does the world feel politically well developed - it doesn't do a good job of showing abject poverty, or corporations trying to extract every single credit or dollar or whatever ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ currency the game uses, or really communicating the collapsing nature of the planet they live on, or the ways in which technology enables people to oppress people. Dan Olson's breakdown of privacy with crypto is a really good example of what they could have explored, for example. I overheard two cops in game talking about how they're rolling out mind-scanning tech and the other officer saying 'well i have nothing to hide' and it never came up again. Cyberpsychosis is also a poor way to model the impact of cybernetics disconnecting people from everyone else; but that's hardly CD Projekt's fault, so much as an issue with the original setting. I don't know how much the writers researched beyond the source material, but there is so much more depth and complexity that could have been explored within the game. Finally, the world - I feel like this world could really, really benefit from layered environments. Trying to get to the Arasaka float is actually a good example of how this was done right, in specific places. But this game really deserves the level of detail in vertical mobility that dishonoured or assassin's creed have,  especially once you get the double-jump legs. There is a considerable lack of environmental hazards which would really do a good job of selling the posioned nature of this city, and just a lack of crowding - if they had of crowded the city more with buildings then maybe they wouldn't run into issues with rendering NPCs, while really being able to sell the overpopulated nature of the city.Overall, CD Projekt tried - they really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ tried. But they ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ crashed and burned so hard, like a studio-sized icarus. They bit off more than can chew, even for a studio that really has successfully made some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ huge games before. I really hope they manage to fix some of these problems, or, if that's not possible due to the monumental cluster♥♥♥♥ they find themselves in, release a decent suite of mod tools. You know, the old Bethesda route - if you can't make a decent game, rely on the players to fix it for you. Fundamentally, a game like this thrives on customizeabilty, and they just failed to do that.If you have the cash and like triple-A games, try it out; otherwise don't bother. Your time is better spent.

author: Smooth Operator
review: After 30 hours, I can say that Cyberpunk 2077 has been one of the WORST gaming experiences I've had in MANY YEARS.The gameplay loop is boring, the movement feels clunky as hell, the combat feels like garbage, and the NPCs, vehicles, and enemies are literally braindead. Also, unlike in any other great RPG, there is zero sense of natural progression in this game.The game fast-forwards through the most meaningful parts of an RPG and let's you have almost anything you want without having to earn it through gameplay and character development.The open world of this game is beautiful but it's very superficial. To me it feels like a glorified loading screen for quests. It lacks a lot of basic features that other great open world games (not necessarily RPGs) have had for 15+ years. It's ridiculous. I can't believe it.Even if they manage to make this game playable by fixing most of the bugs it currently has, for me it will still be a mediocre game at best. It doesn't feel good to play, and the story is not engaging me too much or making me want to play it anyway just to see how it continues.I just can't believe that the NPCs and the vehicles have literally no AI. Police can't even drive cars and they spawn on foot right in front of your face. The wanted system is useless. All the vehicle rides are scripted. In the racing side quests the other cars literally teleport behind you if you leave them too far behind. And they slow down A LOT if you're losing.Every enemy is a bullet sponge and shooting at them feels like ♥♥♥♥. Why do developers keep making enemies like this!? It's not fun at all! Keep weapons powerful so that they feel good to shoot. I understand this is an RPG but they could have just made the weapons hard to use (like for example adding movement to the camera, so it's hard to aim), and then remove those effects via character development and progression.There's tons of more stuff I don't like about this game that I could talk about all day, but I'm tired of it. And sadly I don't think any of that stuff will change in the future. It would be too much work and the game was simply designed this way.A big disappointment.

author: Fëanor
review: There is a common reason why this game made so much noise and at the same time was so criticized. This reason is obviously the anticipation created in the pre-game audience. The expectation was so high before the game was released that Cyberpunk 2077 managed to turn the eyes until December 10, the release date of the game. Thus, this PR before the game led to positive and negative situations. We can say that the record number of pre-orders given by the audience before the game was released was actually an indication that the PR was very effective. This created expectation and the attraction of the trailers from afar were the most important reasons for the success of the game. But as I mentioned, on the other hand, we can say that CD PROJEKT RED, the producer company, was a kind of "hoist with one's own petard". Because a certain audience, who had great expectations, did not find the game as good as they expected, and this naturally caused disappointment.In this article, I will try to explain my own experiences and the positive and negative aspects of the game in my opinion, from an objective point of view.The game takes place in a fictional city called "Night City", which we can say is above today's standards, beyond our time (2077). According to the game story, the original name of the city is Coronado City; However, after the death of businessman Richard Alix Night, known as the founder of the city, the city began to be called Night City.There are 7 districts in the game named Westbrook, Badlands, Heywood, Pacifica, Santo Domingo, City Center and Watson.You start the game by choosing any of the profiles of nomads, street children, or companies. No matter what resume you start your character with, your character's name is "V" and other people call you by that name. Our character is a mercenary. You complete the given tasks with expertise and gradually increase your reputation in Night City. Personally, I would love to be able to make more choices about our own character's past, but the options are very limited and it is not possible to manage this scenario according to our own taste. However, depending on which of these 3 options you choose, you make a different start with a story. It's not just the stories that have changed. At the same time, the attitudes of other characters, maybe even NPCs, are linked to your character's background. For example, a nomad may be seen as oppressed and despised by the public when he is outside his camp; The street kid profile leads to more intimate conversations and recognition by people in the area where you grew up, and some of the dialogues really make the player feel like they grew up there and are one of those people.Although we will not be able to make detailed touches on our character's background, at the beginning of the game, it offers us a detailed selection page to create our character's appearance. Thus, we can design the appearance of our character according to our own tastes. I can say that I never got bored while playing the main story of the game. While playing the main quests, new calls for side quests are constantly coming, so you are never idle. It is possible to find really enjoyable side quests, they do not change the course of the main story, but the characters that are included in the main story but are no longer your business can ask you for help. Of course, it is up to you to ignore or help. Apart from these enjoyable side missions I mentioned, it is possible to find side missions that I can't really enjoy, that have no purpose and logic, and sometimes repeat each other. Since I didn't complete all of the side missions, I don't know how many hours it will take as a result of playing the game to the last level. However, as a result of completing the main story completely and doing some side quests, my story took about 25 hours in total. I think it will take 60-70 hours maximum if you do all the side missions. As I said, I was very satisfied with the story. But I wish the main story was a little longer.Another issue that disappointed me is that the choices presented to us are not very effective in terms of influencing the story. Our game is called an RPG (role-playing game), but whether it is really a role-playing game is open to discussion. As there are choices that affect the main story; Unfortunately, there are options that we cannot intervene in the event, no matter how hard we try, and are presented to us as decorations. However, some of the choices you make towards the end of the game can directly change the ending of the game. The roleplay part of the job comes into play more here. It is among the most talked about that the game has an optimization problem in general. If you are not playing on a powerful enough system, it is possible that the details of the characters do not load for a while and they are seen as inanimate beings made of cardboard, the appearance of some objects is really seedy and you may encounter some similar situations. I hope it is something that can be fixed in the future. Because it is a fact that there is a difference between low graphics and high graphics options. Especially this difference can sometimes make the image of the same character in different graphic options unrecognizable.If we leave the optimization problem aside, the atmosphere in the game, Night City, fascinates people. Cyberpunk 2077 has a really thoughtful and beautifully detailed open world. Apart from the missions, you can freely roam the city. You can shop for weapons and ammo, and buy new clothes. However, the fact that we could not shape the vehicle we have according to our own tastes was one of the situations that disappointed me. I do not know whether this detail will be added in the future, but if it does, I can say that it will be good news for many players, including me.While walking around Night City, you are likely to encounter gangs and even groups that clash with the police. If you want, you can fight with the gangs and defeat them and confiscate their belongings and if you find them, their eurodollars (the currency in the game). When other members of the same gang see you at another time, they may recognize you again and try to attack you. You can also help the police by attacking groups that clash with the police. Of course, it is up to you to ignore and continue on your way. Speaking of conflict, you can gain new abilities with certain points that our character has in the game. This will improve your hacking skills. If you do not want to use technical skills such as hacking, you can advance your skill development in a different direction and upgrade your weapon skills. I really enjoyed the combat parts. As someone who likes FPS (First Person Shooter) games, the feeling of hitting was enjoyable enough to satisfy me.CLOSING:This is my general criticism. There will be those who participate or those who do not. However, if we come to the issue of whether the game is as legendary as it is praised, or as disappointed as it is criticized; I liked the game. I don't think it deserves to be slandered so much. But it still had to go a long way to become a legend. There are a lot of bugs that need to be fixed and there is a clear optimization problem in the game, it's a fact. The story overall is enjoyable, but short. For a game released under the label of "Role Playing Game", we have very little authority to direct the course of the story. Side quests get very repetitive after a while, and after a while, it starts to become unsatisfying. Also, what happened with the PS4 version is really sad and a big mistake that needs to be corrected. For this reason, I believe that Cyberpunk 2077 is an unfinished game yet. I can definitely say that it is a promising game if the calls of the players are heeded and the game is enriched with more details.

author: kosmique
review: In midst of all the complaints about technical issues with the game, I guess I can consider myself one lucky person, to have this game running flawlessly smooth on max settings on my CPU. To be completely clear, I cannot get the game to stutter or lag, its just running smooth through all the alt+tabbing, steam overlay spam and whatever ... +230 hours without a single crash... I can just do whatever I want with my PC in the middle of playing the game... With that, it goes without saying I can only call this top notch quality, despite the globally terrible launch, which is kinda surreal to me... the few bugs i have encountered are all minor. Game boots up superfast and loads savegames in just a few seconds. So far,  I just simply cannot join the mob that is currently "bashing" the studio  (...and perhaps rightfully so, given the issues some claim to be experiencing). Everything is 100% over here on the tech side, I hadn't expected it myself. About the game itself: Its just pure freakin incredible. The world is ridiculously beautiful, very well designed and hits the cyberpunk theme just as it should. Pondsmith is a creative genius and the mastercraftsmanship on CPDR's side is once again just flat out unbelievable. Translating intellectual property, vision, concepts and ideas from authors and creators over to video game code at this caliber, CDPR remains the monster it has proven itself to be with The Wild Hunt at minimum. This game is definitely carved out of the same material as W3, and with time, we will probably be getting some nice addtional content at the same level we could expect from the studio's former flagship title. I'm quite excited to see what the future brings our way in form of additional stuff / ironing out a few "rather unripe" mechanics/systems...I also absolutely have to add, that this game already has the best easter eggs I have encountered in any game/movie/series. They implemented a wide variety of those and they nailed them...They seriously are a lot of fun! My favorites have to be the 3 seashells from Demo Man, the AI from Portal and of course Grove Street. There are just so many Easter Eggs to be made for this game and I could imagine a few that I have in my mind could really actually be ingame. :DSo there you have it, if you grew up during the emergence of the cyberpunk theme, love it, and always thought the world just needs more of this theme, there is zero chance you will be disappointed by this title. I'm still looking for the sockets in my head or neck because the immersion this game slams on you is UNREAL. Thats me at least :P If you cannot respect the level of detail and the level of "GO IN HARD" which CDPR WENT IN HARD with, on the theme, design, atmosphere & setting, than color me baffled but thats one brain dance i am not gonna take. CD Projekt gets all my Eddies for sure.Cheers to Night City. In my eyes, the best city.

author: VolKan
review: So, first off I want to say I was on the fence on wether or not to recommend the game or not, but ultimately I decided not to, mainly because:1. The price tag.3. The amount of bugs currently.2. The amount of times they pushed the release date.Unique settingInteresting storyGreat voice actingNot afraid to show gore and nudityGraphics, somewhatChoices seem to matter and have impactLackluster stealthLackluster hackingLackluster driving Lackluster parkourLackluster meleeLackluster gunplayLackluster customization (clothing)Lackluster looting, yes, looting.Now to go into depth on the above.The game is set in a world unique to me, I havn't seen a game quite like it, it really reminds me of Altered Carbon (a series) which I enjoyed watching so the world instantly dragged me in, along with the story which is also one of the main reasons I will be finishing the game despite the flaws. The voice acting is superb, the only one I don't really like is V's (male) but it's not too bad. The game isn't afraid of a little nudity and gore which is refreshing, gives it a little more realism when it isn't trying to blatantly hide or ignore those things.The graphics looked nice, not the best but passable at the very least. The first game I played with RTX on and it runs smooth enough, only time I experienced a drop in frames was when I died and respawned, dropped to 15-30 fps for a couple seconds until it went up again.I liked the dialogue options that gave different solutions and playouts of events and conversations, and required you to level up certain skill trees, not unique but it seemt more impactful here than in other games.The stealth is next to impossible with enemies being spawned with their backs facing a wall/obstacle or being placed in a way that doesn't allow for a takedown without being spotted 9/10 times, not only that but it forces you to stand up when you try to stealthkill which makes you announce your position whilst you have to choose to knock them out or kill them, and then let the animation play out, which is always the same basic animation, which has made stealth for me, an otherwise 100% stealth guy, resort to the guns blazing option.Hacking was also a chore, it's really just a time-consumption, there's no point. It takes too long, and it barely does anything for you except when you want to open a door or get some points, theres no point distracting enemies or blinding them, takes way too long to get any use out of it.Driving in the game is horrible, I don't understand why every game gets this wrong but alas, another game that makes your vechicle drive with soap for wheels.The parkour is uninspired, rushed and if you want to go dying light style and climb up buildings and jump across apartments then expect to fall through the map alot.Melee was a dissapointment, you'd expect a game where your arms are literal metal to have really cool melee combat but no, 3 stock punching animations and a couple melee weapons, yes weapons. Metal arm doesn't do the job. And for some reason if you pull out your fists you do tons of damage but hitting the quick melee button with your gun out is the equivalent of poking the enemy.The gunplay is servicable at best, enemies are bullet sponges, none of the things in the game that does damage actually feel like they do damage, except melee, but good luck not getting tired of that.Clothing. Maybe the simplest part of the game, has no purpose being there. What you wear is dictated by the stats it has, unless you want to purposely handicap yourself. There isn't an option to just pick a style or cover up what you're actually wearing with something else that looks nice. You're forced to look like you just put your clothes on blindly, thank god you aren't in third person or appear in the cutscenes.Looting is infuriating. Either you will be spamming Tab to get a hint at where items are for about 2 seconds, and then repeat that whilst spamming F, or you'll be rubbing your character up every square inch of the map whilst pressing F.And when you finish doing that you can have some fun time in your confusing inventory trying to find what you just picked up for 10 minutes.I also want to sneak this in here, when you alert the police 2-4 will spawn right next to you and gun you down. This happened to me three times and now I've just decided to completely avoid the police. And I'm not sure if this is unlocked later or not but you can't stealth kill the police either so you're forced to alert them if you want to free a citizen, which then spawns extra police next to you instantly.Also sound, sound is inconsistent and all over the place. Voices from people far away are played as if they were next to you, this goes for pretty much any sounds, not just voices. Sometimes sounds won't play at all.All in all my thoughts are that the game is too ambiguous, too many features crammed into it that barely function, shame.I won't bother mentioning the bugs since they'll be fixed within a week but just know there's alot, and you shouldn't be buying this game yet anyway, even if there were no bugs.With the release date pushed so far and so many times it is unaccetable that this is the state of the game, therefore ultimately; Get the game on sale.

author: Jon Umber
review: The amount of ridiculous, false criticism I've heard regarding Cyberpunk 2077 so far is astonishing and depressing. It most definitely is. There's ample roleplaying to be had here, and not limited to just whether you want to play stealthily or in open-combat.They most definitely do. I've replayed several story missions and been surprised by how much they change in general, but also by how the game recognizes small things such as reading a single e-mail which grants you a dialogue option with a character who's hiding something later, or asking a minor question which ends up raising suspicion of a snuff film compound you are later tasked with infiltrating, causing them to add more guards patrolling the perimeter.Stealth is good. So is shooting. Driving is fine. All three are far better than I anticipated for a game developer making their first game ever to utilize those features.NPC AI complaints aside, this is the best open world I've ever seen in a game, especially from an art direction and level design standpoint. It looks gorgeous, feels real, and features an endless number of carefully crafted nooks for the player to explore.I grew up just outside of New York City, and I've spent a lot of time there throughout my life. I know what a big city looks and sounds like, and Cyberpunk's Night City is the first video game city that truly feels like a real city does. The most minute of back alleys feel lived-in. Different cultures melt together, creating unique architecture, shops, NPC chatter, foreign language ads. There's detritus scattered about, clutter on fire escapes, empty bottles on back-alley porches. Nooks and crannies fold into each other, overlapping and intersecting. It bleeds realism, but at the same time, doesn't; the first time you see glowing, neon advertisements which stretch upwards into the sky, or see airborne vehicles zipping through the air, you'll know you're in a science fiction setting. It's just the right balance of realism and fiction; enough to feel familiar, but at other times, utterly foreign. It's a joy to exist in such a surreal place. Despite this complexity it never manages to feel overwhelming or too difficult to navigate.The detail in these areas is top tier. The environmental artists and level designers have created extraordinary spaces which satisfy both your brain and your heart; they appear to be real, logically, while also satisfying your heart's desire for an aesthetically pleasing place. I can't say enough about it. Walking through the city and taking in these spaces and grasping the stories these level designers are telling you just with a few pieces of clutter never gets old, and it subconsciously heightens every other experience I've had with the game. I may be deep into a story mission, focused on what's happening with the characters and how to stealthily clear this next room, but I'm also subconsciously noting what this person's living space is telling me about them—what kind of food they eat, the clutter indicating that they might be depressed, old framed army photos of them and their friends long passed. If you enjoy games for these sorts of carefully crafted spaces—the Bioshocks, and the Dishonoreds, for example—then you're going to adore it in Cyberpunk.Nearly all of the Main Jobs, Side Jobs, and a significant portion of the Gigs are high-effort, compellingly written stories, including some of the best characters written into a video game in years. Their production values are extraordinary; the standards in acting and animation in this game are higher than any video game has ever accomplished before. No exaggeration. They bring these characters to life, and although the city and the narrative is at times horrendously dark, these characters regularly bring light and joy to it. The missions themselves constantly put the player in interesting circumstances and always ask questions of them: How do you judge this person's crimes? What does identity mean? It gives you the means to affect not the world, but the characters you spend time with. You cannot save this world—it's already doomed. But you can save some of the people in it.Attributes, Skills, and Perks. Guns, Gear, Cyberware. Cyberdecks, Daemons, Quickhacks. The amount of systems in place, and the layers involved in each system allow for absurd amounts of depth and customization in the way you play the game. There's lots of synergy and how you spec your character is often mentioned in dialogue.I expected CD Projekt Red's first go at first-person shooting to be a sub par affair, but shooting feels surprisingly great. The unique reload animations which begin to proc as your skill with a weapon type increases always does a lot to heighten the experience. Once you begin receiving iconic weapons and skilling up a bit, everything hits an entirely new level. It feels fantastic and guns' sound design is amazing.Gushing aside, there are several things Cyberpunk 2077 does really excruciatingly poorly.Crafting is nearly completely broken economically. It's far too expensive to upgrade the gear you currently have. I was often forced by necessity to chuck aesthetically pleasing gear for a clownish, neon green, plastic monstrosities. The player ends up endlessly swapping out their old gear for new gear in this fashion because of how broken the crafting economy is. It also has the ill effect of making their character appear to be a complete clown with ridiculous, mismatched clothes when they might rather appear to be street-savvy, or a professional operator. The opportunity for roleplaying with clothing is thus completely lost due to this system's failure.The UI is also a mess. The way shards are sorted is particularly awful. I've currently got nearly 100 in two separate categories both titled 'Other'. It's impossible to locate shards by name because they aren't sortable, nor do they default to sorting alphabetically. If a shard pops up on screen, you'd better press 'Z' immediately, because once you have to search for it by navigating the menus it's pretty much gone for good. Even more severe is the fact that the quest log features utterly unhelpful blurbs, sometimes just one sentence which tells you nothing. If you set a quest down to do later, you'll often be completely lost as to where you left off. The only bugs I encountered through my 100+ hours thus far are minor graphical glitches, such as a character's cigarette getting stuck in the air, or my player character occasionally T-posing out of the car when I drive fast. I recently played Assassin's Creed Valhalla and that game was far buggier than Cyberpunk 2077. I haven't experienced a single crash or soft lock with Cyberpunk 2077, yet I experienced numerous such issues with Valhalla.So, yes. Cyberpunk 2077 is a flawed game. There are some systems and design choices here which either simply do not work as intended, or are broken in some fashion. But don't believe all the hate on twitter and /r/cyberpunkgame. This is an absolutely incredible experience and a top notch RPG. If you're a fan of games such as Deus Ex or Fallout New Vegas, chances are you'll really like Cyberpunk 2077. But if you have any doubts whatsoever, just wishlist it and wait for the devs to add more to the game, to patch it up, and for modders to have time to release mods.This game feels like the launch of Fallout New Vegas felt in 2010; a fantastic, ambitious game marred by its broken launch on consoles, and its rough edges and bugs on PC. And, like New Vegas, in time I'm confident general consensus will view this game as one of the best ever made. For me, it's already firmly in that pantheon.Feel free to follow  if you like my reviews.

author: Homer
review: Do not buy the game if your system is weak.Wait for optimisation and buy it in Sale.

author: CARTMAN_021p
review: I have not finished CyberPunk 2077 yet but i'm writing this review anyway. I LOVE it for sure. The many stories in the game is well written with many interesting characters to meet, and Night City is amazingly built with so much details and cool designs. Very fun to explore the different districts in the big city. The graphics is stunning but it demands a good machine to run in higher settings. I play most in medium and low graphics setting but it looks great even so. (Spec: i7 6700k, GTX 1070, 32 GB DDR4, SSD installation, @ 1080p)It feels like you are living in the future when riding around in Night City. Great sci-fi atmosphere. The sound is also really good in CyberPunk 2077 with matching cool music. You can go in stealth or full guns blazing in the missions. The gunplay feels good and you can upgrade weapons, clothes and even your body with cyber implants to get an advantage out in the dangerous world. The bad things i can say about this hyped game is the bugs of course. The game has crashed several times for me also but then i installed the newest Nvidia Drivers and now it runs better but i still experiencing freezes and crashes. The other bad thing about CyberPunk is the driving mechanics which truely suck's donkey balls ((:::EDiT 1::: Not "DK Balls" but not that good feeling. I got used to the cars a little. Bikes is really bad though)) ((:::EDiT 2::: Actually there are several cars that has much better driving mechanics. The car you start out with is terrible and also every bike but many other cars is fun to drive.))I wish CD Project Red would have made the driving feeling like the one R* made for Grand Theft Auto 4 from 2008 which i love. Even GTA 5 from 2013 has better driving than CyberPunk has. At least the cars. The motorbikes is horrible in GTA 5 even. Maybe the traffic system in Night City could be better also. The other cars don't behave correct and they often drive when there's a red light.Anyhow, i really recommend this sci-fi action RPG made by the Polish studio CD Project Red. Now is the time to smash the bugs and optimize the game as fast as they can.///Score: 9.5 of 10

author: Biscuit
review: Yeaaa...this ain't it chief. Lackluster "RPG" elements. A very visually beautiful world filled with good gun play and in my opinion very good main and side stories. Other than that this game blows for $60. Some of the jarring cons that personally stood out to me and what I can think of at the moment:-Lifeless NPCs with nonexistent AI. -You'll see 3 of the same NPC model within literally 5 feet of each other and all NPCs saying the same 5-10 voice lines. -Vehicles have a pre-set path so if you blocked them or try to shoot the drivers, they just stay there or the driver gets out of his car and runs. They don't even bother to drive away. -Police can't drive cars. They infinitely spawn right next to you no matter where you are. Wanted level doesn't event matter-Half of the keybinds in game can't be changed. Why would you put dodge on double tap and not be able to change it? THERE'S ALSO NO UNARM BUTTON UNLESS YOU DOUBLE TAP THE ALT KEY AND CHOOSE IT FROM A WHEEL.-The sensitivity setting sucks-Minimap is too zoomed in when driving. The amount of times I missed a turn because of it is insane.UPDATE (still one of the MANY things that I have experienced):-Can't customize character AFTER character creation. There are no barbers or any way to change your hair.-Can't customize car and there's no garage.And this is all hidden by the fact that for some people, the game is actually unplayable. Many game breaking bugs and glitches. I'm one of the lucky few that have experienced no crashes and only 2 instances where I had to reload a save to fix the game. All the other bugs were merely visual. This game is also very unoptimized. The fact that I have an i7 4790k, 32 gb ram, and a 2070s and it still runs, to me, overall ♥♥♥♥ is crazy. Changing to low setting nets me like 3-5 fps which doesn't help at all with all the stutters I get, especially when driving around Night City.

author: Nox
review: This is an early access game by all means. Extremely poor optimization with lots of bugs and glitches. Wait for a year or two for the definitive edition. It's not worth to play at this state.

author: Khissi
review: At 23 hours, now.  People are talking about bugs but, even with my fairly mid-lower end rig, this game is beautiful!  I don't find bugs so much as I find that it's not as intuitive as I'd wish and, sometimes, feels a bit clunky.  I do believe, though, that's because there is so much that has to be managed!  Anyway, that's my opinion.  However, Witcher 3 was the same for me.  I really had to work at learning the combat, the way perks work and this one has hacking and driving, as well!  I am a sucky driver in anyone's book, but I'm getting the hang of hacking and getting better at the combat.  The story is spectacular!  Twists and turns that I'm so glad I had no idea were going to happen ahead of time... it's just... go play.

author: Podcat
review: Great immersion in a fantastic setting, and lots of great characters to get to know. I've run into a few cosmetic or minor bugs (in about 90h) but otherwise no real technical issues. I am really in love with the game but areas I would want to see improved:- Balance feels like its sometimes all over the place. Some encounters I sink several clips into enemies and can sponge a lot and in others I basically get one-shotted. Its not always clear why and it doesnt always feel natural. to be fair witcher 3 was sometimes like this also-  Tie quest giving calls more to progression, and perhaps let you grab them earlier if you go talk directly to fixers. I got absolutely bombarded with new quests in the first 30% of the game to a degree that it was also immersion breaking- the clothing system works badly and you always end up looking like a total clown. It needs dyes or something at least to let you create a decent and coherent appearance (since its 1st person tho I understand why this got less prio). - link crafting upgrades somehow from inventory screen. It took me too long to get into crafting upgrades and it would be easier to spot if it was indicated there when things could get improved- Give Squama more screen time!

author: Gamezz4Fun
review: Played and finished the game in 1.5 version. There are still bugs in the game, and some quests are not that good, but when this game gets going then it has some of the coolest story moments, in a game. Compared to Witcher 3 it's definitely not at that level, but a really damn good game nonetheless. Thoroghly enjoyed playing through the game.Definitely worth playing the game now, if u refunded or not bought the game on release. It has good story, combat, enjoyable open world, good characters, excellent voice action and attention to detail in quests which is rare in this day and age. A game made for single player fan at heart.... love to CD Project Red....
